In Holy Week, 1836, three brothers of Protestant confession came from Rheinbischofsheim in the Grand Duchy of Baden --- Jakob, David and Friedrich --- bearing a letter from a Catholic parish priest from the Lower-Rhine Alsace, who recommended them for exorcistic treatment because they, their younger sister, and their whole household were continually tormented by evil spirits. From the conversations I had with the three young men in consequence, roughly the following emerged. Descended from common peasant parents and occupied from youth with agricultural work, they had always been healthy and strong. The eldest, Jakob, learned the smith's trade; the second, David, entered service in the army; the third, Friedrich, always remained at home. While Jakob was still abroad, David was one time seized by a very strange condition: he felt as if blown upon by a wind, and such a compression arose on his chest that he began to spit up blood. He was medically treated and was sent to the hospital in Karlsruhe; but all remedies applied were in vain, and he finally received his discharge. Arrived at home, his condition was not at all better, and at the same time extremely strange things happened in the house and in the stable. At the same time Jakob, while abroad, had begun to perceive what was going on in the paternal home; and now the younger brother Friedrich soon also began to be tormented, just like David; and also a younger sister, though not to the same degree as the brothers. In the house there were intermittent rumblings and bangs in a dreadful manner, and in the stable the cattle perished in an unnatural way. When the brothers went across the fields or drove with the cart, stones were often thrown at them from the air. Sometimes, they said, a thunderstorm suddenly stood up in the clearest sky; and on several occasions an unknown animal walked ahead of them and then, at a certain spot, suddenly vanished. \[Page 87\]

Physically Jacob suffered little, but he was a kind of visionary, and saw, as he said, the fiends coming. A moment later the brothers would be as if smitten by a breath, and feel an inner motion that increased to the point of hemorrhage; yet so that, when the attack had passed, they felt their strength restored, as if they had never lacked anything. Often it seemed to them as if they were beaten by invisible but still palpable hands; often as if they were pierced through the belly. They ascribed these things neither to the devil nor to actual spectres, but to wicked people. The seer insisted that he had positively recognized the apparitions as persons still living and even related to them; and the strangest stories were adduced in proof.

They had at the outset sought diverse medical help, but found none anywhere; what wonder, since they sought to drive out sorcery by sorcery, and went to those who were reputed to practice such arts. These assisted them on several occasions by sympathetic means, but only for a short time; because, as they alleged, the helpers were better paid by the others. What opinion I should draw from all these accounts as to the real ground of the matter I did not know. I regarded the two younger brothers, David and Friedrich, as hysterical; for their condition, especially that of the latter, pointed to a high degree of suffering. They otherwise appeared to be anything but timid, superstitious people; so that, since I noted they were Protestants --- among whom such things, especially in that district, occur even more than among Catholics --- I was inclined to ascribe the whole affair to a play of the imagination; yet on the other hand their calm narration, their ingenuous answers to embarrassing questions which I put to them, utterly disabused me of that view.

After I had at last deliberated, and after I had to some extent explained to them the meaning of the church benediction, I gave this to them repeatedly once or twice a day. They testified that they felt easier, indeed they seemed entirely free from their plague. I therefore dismissed them in Easter week with a letter to the pastor who had sent them to me; in which I begged him, in consideration of my ignorance concerning the true nature of the affair, to make on the spot inquiries into the relations of the family, into the circumstances of the people among whom they had been raised, and in general into everything that might throw light on the matter; also himself, notwithstanding the general prohibition of exorcism, at least to employ the exorcismum probativum.

At the beginning of June the brothers, to my no small astonishment, returned a second time and brought with them a letter from the pastor, who wrote that he himself had gone to their parental house in Bischofsheim; that he had there examined and investigated all the circumstances, but had discovered nothing significant as to the cause of the matter. He had had the brothers examined by physicians, and these, as the enclosed certificates showed, had detected no bodily disease. Twice he had written to the Vicar General for permission to perform the exorcism; but the latter had only answered evasively. He had now blessed the house, and it had indeed been freed from all haunting; the half-dead cattle were now well too; only the three brothers continued to be tormented, and he therefore repeatedly begged me to apply the exorcism. The medical testimonies ran as follows --- first, that of Dr. Kühn: the three brothers had, several years before, suffered from pulmonary hemorrhage and had been treated by him; but the prescribed remedies had been without effect, because the causes of the ailment could not be sufficiently ascertained. \[Page 88\]

Secondly, that of the physician Humann in Herrlisheim, who declared that he had examined the brothers stethoscopically, but had found nothing in them that pointed to an organic defect of the sick person, or to a physiological disturbance of the functions of her body as a whole. The brothers, once they reached me, now assured me that when they had left here on their earlier departure they had remained free of all attacks for two days; upon which, however, the evil had returned, and they were again as before in distress. During their previous absence everything at home had been topsy-turvy; there had been terrible noise, and all the cattle in the stable had seemed as if they were about to die. The distraught father had at once run to the Catholic pastor for help; but since he was prevented from assisting personally he had given him blessed palms; and when these were burned in the stable the animals immediately became healthy and rose up well.

The pastor had afterwards come and blessed the house again, whereupon nothing adverse had occurred since. Only they themselves suffered from the old malady, and begged me piteously to help them, since they firmly believed I could. I had therefore to return to the work, whether I wished to or not, which weighed on me greatly because of the obscurity of the whole affair. I had them tell their stories again, I asked fresh questions, I had them set their answers down in writing; but I could come to no foundation, any more than the first time. Their accounts partly confirmed what had been stated earlier, and partly added new details.

I have again forgotten many things; I will therefore set down only some of what I have written from Jakob before me. He wrote: when he was yet away in foreign parts, a man often came to his workshop by day and by night who showed him how matters stood at home; he always demanded that Jakob should throw money to him, and he would show him what he could do. If Jakob then wished to leave, he could not stir from the spot; nevertheless he was not otherwise prevented from working. The matter soon took a worse turn: the visitors became more numerous; they planned all sorts of things with him, and forced him to swear at night; he often had to carry coffins, was himself laid into them, or had to dig up corpses. They crucified him; but when it was over it appeared that it had been nothing.

Naked women appeared, carried out all manner of mischief with the others, sat on his face, etc., whereupon he then had actual pollutions. They would also have carried him off, it was to him as if he went out through his own eyes, and they led him to games and debauchery. They showed him how they had poisoned the well-water at home, and promised that if he married one of them they would make it right again. Thus it went on as in madness, and when the apparitions presently threatened to devour him, shot at him with pistols, beat him, tore one another's hair, then again came driving up with carriages and horses; another time a man loaded with golden and silver chains would appear and two golden rings would be placed about his arms; when they then rode with him into the clouds, climbed Mount Sinai, gave him nine golden keys, made three garments, set up a white bed before him; meanwhile again firing cannons, making music, launching an assault on Paradise, and desolating and destroying all things --- who could be wise after all that? He complained that these phantasms appeared to him almost every night; whereupon, every time, certain afflictions befell the other brothers. \[Page 89\]

He also wrote much about this, from which, however, likewise nothing rational could be drawn; the assertion remained steadfast: the principal persons were close relatives; among others, the father's sister, a notorious woman, with her equally notorious daughter. It was precisely this latter who was to marry Jakob --- but he did not want her. Even their own pastor was said to have been among the fiends. The thought occurred to me: since that notorious aunt had christened all three of them, perhaps the first cause of the evil had been laid then; and for that reason I renewed with them the baptismal vows. I continued to pray with them, instructed them about the churchly benediction, and pronounced it over them.

At last I resolved also to speak the exorcism contra maleficia over them. I can cite nothing remarkable of its striking effects; for the fact that Friedrich once or twice perspired under it, so that the sweat fell in drops, could well be explained by his suffering state. They likewise assured me this time: after each prayer over them they felt lighter, but it would come back again anew every day; it already brought relief when they were even only in the convent. They always thought: if I took it to the highest degree, it would surely be better, it would be altogether well. Almost three weeks thus passed, but no thorough help had been attained; the people's money ran out, and by their long absence from home the accumulating tasks demanded their presence ever more urgently; I could not and would not detain them for a single moment with empty promises. I therefore dismissed them with a letter to the pastor, in which I communicated to him everything that had occurred, and how I had never found a sure sign of a demonic influence. That the exorcism had remained without effect might well be due to the fact that the young people lived outside communion with the church; this defect could indeed have been supplied by my faith and my trust; but since that is only a divine gift which God bestows on whom He will, no one could accuse me on account of the lack of success. A magnetic treatment by a reliable and religious physician might perhaps be advisable in this case; the pastor himself might also, after careful consideration of all the circumstances, privately, and without telling the people what was going on, apply the exorcism.

They went away with this advice, and the narrator, when he wrote this down, had heard nothing further of them since. One must regret that this story could only be observed so incompletely and with so many gaps; for, had it been followed on the spot with attentive eyes for the requisite time, it would have afforded a profound insight into the nature of a most wondrous condition. As it stands, it appears as a popular, and, as one can hardly doubt, sincere report on the modalities of a disposition as it often occurs in witchcraft; and although it lacks sharpness of observation and the investigation of all the circumstances that occurred, it nevertheless, intelligible to a physiological tact, affords many revelations.

It becomes clear from this account: the house of these people, with everything that was bound to it in some relation, has been transferred out of the natural state in which it previously was into a counter-natural one; in which other laws than those of ordinary life prevail. In the midst of this new condition stand, to begin with, the three brothers, who had previously been healthy and strong, but are now reduced to a hectic appearance; and to them the younger sister attaches herself in the first instance. All are united to one another in a physiological bond, and within it stand in reciprocal interaction. \[Page 90\]

In this association --- and thus also drawn into the shared suffering --- is also the household's stock of cattle; which, so to speak placed at the circumference of the sphere of action, nevertheless, according to the testimony of the pastor, takes part in everything that occurs within it. Within the house itself things happen that wholly belong to the domain of haunting, and, however one may explain them, they show that this domain has been pushed to the border of two spheres. At the apex of the solidaristic connection stands the first-born; against his will he has become clairvoyant, farsighted and foreseeing; he therefore sees through the whole relationship that attaches itself to him as the members to the head.

Immediately beneath him stand the two brothers, again placed like members to the central organ; they are not seeing themselves, but when he becomes seeing they appear affected; they are, in relation to his knowledge of their condition, as if breathed upon, and are at once seized by an illness in which this knowledge becomes real in them. Congestions of the lungs appear which end in bleeding from the lungs; whereby, after the termination of the attack, as in all maladies of this kind, the powers rapidly restore themselves. The younger sister is also, though less deeply, drawn into this relation of action and reaction; the cattle, as if struck by the outermost emanations, give notice of their participation by rapid falling ill and recovery; and the haunting stirs itself each time as well, and seems to form the medium in which all those effects occur.

Yet the first impulse of the movement by no means proceeds from the centre of the association, and the knowledge of the deed is not realised by the deed alone; rather this realisation also comes to it from elsewhere. Even the clairvoyance Jacob possesses is not entirely his own; there is a man who comes to him and shows him things as they occur. He finds himself bound and held by its power, although it does not prevent his work. It seeks to master him, and employs against him alternately terror and bribery. Desire too it makes its ally; involuntary sympathy it is able to extract from him, only the accession of the will is lacking; and yet all this likewise shows, as the crucifixion does, finally as a haunting.

Opposed to the household association there thus stands another association, which actually effects the realisation, and this association is of demonic nature, its head being that objective apparition; for even the church's actio in distans opposes it and hinders its effect. The members who belong to this counter-association stand in a certain relation to the house itself; it is the ill-famed woman who took the brothers through baptism; it is the pastor who baptized them; it is the woman's daughter who suggests marriage to the seer, and who draws him out with her own eyes, as she had previously bound him, and leads him to play and feasting.

From this counter-association, then, issues the realisation of what is seen; it is the hostile demonic principle that works in it, and it is by no means strictly necessary that its members be aware of the particulars of the matter. They need only, perhaps by their moral demeanour, stand to that principle in an ethically sympathetic relation of some depth: and this principle can, by virtue of the will-less natural force that lives in them, make use of them as instruments to exercise its effects through them; as the like may happen through any natural mischief. Just as this kind of evil, exercised by the haunt-spirits in the frightful manifestations, nakedly comes to light; so, in those fable-like ghostly proceedings, the haunting has only entered into these persons and has personified itself in them. Thus the whole points only to an order of things higher and more intensified than that in which the foregoing phenomena stood. \[Page 91\]

There have occurred there the spooky (spukhaften) events, without their actual inner cause having come into view. Here this perception, as clairvoyance bound to the disposition, found itself appended. Now the thus-perceived world presses upon the seer, so that he who hitherto has behaved passively will now also put his will into it, and truly unite himself with it. He resists with all his might, but give such a disposition likewise the perverse will that meets the impulse, and one will fully understand that a tacit or express compact may come to pass. It was the 23rd of January in the year 1749, when in a smith's workshop at Mülldorf, in the Salzburg territory, they perceived how the objects there suddenly moved in an unusual manner; sometimes the tools, tongs, hammers, etc., at other times pigs' feet, pieces of brick, and sometimes also objects that had not before been seen there, flew about and fell down. One man was struck from above by a hammer; another by a flying brick --- however, everything so lightly that whatever fell seemed to have lost its weight and therefore caused no pain. All wondered at this; some were seized by fear, thinking readily that something supernatural was afoot. Only the smith's maid, named Anna Bayerin, who served there as nurse to the child, laughed and said that she feared nothing and that no harm would come of it to her. Clergy were called to bless the house and to free it from the devil's assaults; but there was no remedy until the said maid was ordered to leave. As soon as she was out of the house, it became quiet again. These occurrences, and new disturbances which took place in another house where she passed the night, caused the local magistrate to have the more respectable citizens sworn concerning the facts, and thereafter to order the imprisonment of that maid. I do not wish to defend the interrogations made of her to the hair, or to claim that they were entirely in accordance with law; nor that the confession of the accused always bears the stamp of probability. \[Page 96\]

The following, however, cannot, without prejudice to the truth, be denied. After the interrogation had, at least for the sake of precaution, been begun again from the beginning --- and that without the torture having even once been threatened either at Mülldorf or at Salzburg --- this crafty, and not, as some falsely spread, simple woman, after many evasions at last made the following confession: She said she had been seduced by a seamstress from Neumarkt (a little town between Öttingen and Landshut), and had devoted herself exclusively to the Devil by the words written in blood: "I am yours and you are mine!"

She further confessed that she had committed a sacrilegious abuse with the Holy Host, which she had often received and immediately taken from her mouth; that she had several times been carried off, by the Devil's help, to nocturnal dances together with her teacher, the aforementioned seamstress, and others; and that she there had received a lump of sugar, which she afterwards threw into a peasant woman's vat. Thereby it came to pass that the cream of the milk --- however much trouble one took in churning --- nevertheless did not make butter for over half a year; until the peasant woman --- who swore to all this on oath --- sold her cow and bought another; whereupon she made butter without difficulty from the milk of the newly purchased animal, while the purchaser of the old cow likewise made butter from that cow's milk. Finally, she declared that, with the Devil's help, she alone was the cause of the disturbances in the smithy.

I am not one of those who take delight only in the new, often to the detriment of the truth; nor have I sworn by the ancients, who are often credulous to the point of superstition. I know that the judges of past centuries, of whom it is told that they frequently condemned the accused to the stake on mere confession, are charged with a hasty and credulous procedure in matters of magic. Nor is it unknown to me that sugar is ascribed the natural power to dissolve cream so that no butter can be made from it. Nor do I mean to deny that the nocturnal dances and journeys from place to place are not always founded in truth; rather, especially among women, they are represented to them in dreams by the help of the imagination, so that when they awake they cannot be dissuaded from them.

However, just as I cannot, without exposing myself to presumption for want of reliable information, either approve or still less condemn everything that our predecessors have done; so it is nevertheless known even to those who otherwise know nothing that the public laws, and among them the penal procedure of Charles V, condemn magicians to the fire; and that only a hardened and unwise person could call their existence into question after a many-hundred-year calm observance. That the use of sugar, without the Devil's assistance, may, now and then, hinder the making of butter from milk is comprehensible; but that a small piece should possess such power that it could spoil a vessel for more than half a year --- a vessel which in the meantime had been cleaned several times --- and exercise these powers so long that the cow which had been in possession during the application of the sugar could not be sold, no reasonable person will concede. Whoever believes that those nocturnal dances and flights through the air really took place as often as simple women tell, and that they themselves were present at them, may be considered even more simple than the women themselves. \[Page 97\]

Only when reasonable witnesses, elevated above all doubt --- several of whom were present, awake and by day --- testify from what they saw with their own eyes that they were led away in their presence, and that they with their own hands drove them out of the house; if now against this authority of ocular testimony one man asserts: this never happened; I know that such a one, as one who shamelessly and without reason denies everything according to his own liking, as they say, deserves the philosopher's rod of correction.

Among the others those also seemed to me foolish, and asleep with open eyes, who, wishing to gain renown from the novelty of an empty shadow and to embrace a vain appearance instead of the truth, assert that the said seven witnesses might have been deceived in the repeated interrogations, by believing that the hammers and tongs moved without human hand, that they struck them and yet did not wound them; although they testified separately that they had seen these movements in no way caused by the above-mentioned maid, nor in any other way than a supernatural one. For with the same presumption I might then assert: a man who has been robbed only, carried away by his fancy, imagined this, but never possessed the stolen things; the thief dreamed the crime, and the witnesses were falsely persuaded that they had seen the theft.

It should be noted that the Bavarian seamstress, the teacher of the woman from Mülldorf, taken in at Neumarkt, confessed under the same circumstances that she had seduced ours and that she had gone with her to nocturnal dances; although neither could have had knowledge of the other's confession; whereupon she was also beheaded, and the body burned on the pyre. Nevertheless one might well have hesitated at Salzburg to condemn the other merely on account of the agreement of the confession, if the credibility of the witnesses had not testified to the materiality of the crime and removed all reasonable doubt; so that the truth was as clear as humanly possible. Yet no one should consider the maid simple; for by way of deceit she tore out a leaf from her prayer-book, which she had with her in prison, scratched her skin with a piece of wood instead of a pen, and wrote with her blood: I am yours and you are mine! --- with the intention of making it believed that the devil had restored to her what she had previously given him. She carried this off so slyly that it almost succeeded and one would have believed her. Nor should it be overlooked that both, the woman from Salzburg and the one from Neumarkt, at least to all appearance, received the announcement of the death sentence cheerfully; and both humbly requested the assistance of clergymen for their impending end and strengthening with the holy sacraments.

As we have already seen, the practice of magic has kept its higher schools and its initiations under the rein of a certain discipline. An analogous example of what there had taken place there is afforded by the prophets' school which prepared the uprising in the Cévennes, and which, having arisen from more than ambiguous motives, permitted a conclusion as to the manner in which the affair there unfolded, where the leaders frankly and freely surrendered themselves to evil. The peace of 1682 had been very injurious to the cause of the Calvinists in France; by the thousands the people in the south had returned to the Church. The most resolute among its leaders had, in the following year, raised an insurrection in the Dauphiné and in the Vivarais; this, however, proved very unfortunate, and the chiefs had taken refuge in Geneva, in Holland and in Germany to seek help for their cause. Jurieu, one of them, had in 1685 written an exposition of the Apocalypse to prepare the minds; therein he announced the overthrow of the Church within five years and the return of the Reformation in France. This produced the greatest excitement among those peoples in whom the new principle is rooted; and the signs of ecstatic states which appeared here and there in consequence of it probably suggested to the mass of the exiled heads of the Confession in Geneva the thought of ordering and disciplining these states and of making them an ally in the renewed war.

The scene chosen for this prophets' school was a glassworks called Peyra, in the mountains of the Dauphiné, amid woods and rocks. At its head they selected Du Serre, one of the most determined Protestants in that district; he, a native of the country, being often engaged in the affairs of the works, frequently came across to Geneva; there meanwhile a committee had been formed which promoted the insurrection; and two preachers, Henry and Perrin, were sent over to stir the people by their sermons. Du Serre now had fifteen boys entrusted to him by his co-religionists in the neighbourhood, while the same number of girls gathered about his wife. First he instilled in these a pronounced hatred of the Church, and then he revealed to them: that God had communicated his spirit to him, that he gives it to every one according to his good pleasure; but that he had chosen them in order to transform them into prophets and prophetesses, if they would prepare themselves to receive so great a gift in the manner prescribed by God. The children, in their innocence, were willing, and had now to submit to a strict discipline, in which especially regularly recurring fasts, continued for three days at a stretch, played a principal role; while lectures on the Apocalypse and on the Antichrist in Rome, and his near downfall, directed their minds that way, and familiarized them with the language of the prophets.

Under this training there gradually appeared in most of the pupils the phenomena of somnambulism; they threw themselves backwards upon the ground, their eyes closed; the region of the pit of the stomach and of the throat swelled, and they remained for a time in this rapt state. The others had witnessed, full of astonishment, the birth of the new prophet, and were moved by the longing soon likewise to attain, in like manner, to the same consecration. The people answered with the same cry, prostrate on their knees, and the mountains echoed it back. Then a prayer was said, and a psalm sung by all present. Now the presiding officer rose, the assembly did likewise, and after he had cried out, holding his hands over his head, "Throw yourselves backwards, without danger!" everyone threw themselves backward; while the prophet, as the number of those falling increased, let his arms sink lower and lower accordingly. Life of Magdalena Bavent

One may say here: the people fought for their conviction, even if erroneous, against a faith that had been forced upon them; and their leaders, though they made a grievous abuse of their power of enthusiasm, had at least for the most part passed through the same school, and had themselves been enthusiastic before they roused enthusiasm in others. But where from the outset pure depravity, recognized as such, lies at the root; where the leaders have given themselves over beforehand to the absolutely evil for its own sake, and now from it become seducers of others whom they wish to win for its realm: there the demon himself is present, and the whole act becomes demonic, and shows itself as such in its consequences. So it went in the tale of the seduction of Magdalena Bavent, which she set down in her memoirs, and which we will relate in her own words.

"Born in the year 1607 in Rouen, I lost my parents at about nine years of age; I was brought up by an uncle until my twelfth year, and then remained until my sixteenth in the house of a woman in order to learn to sew. At that time a convent according to the rule of St. Francis was established in Louviers, to which saint I had always had a special devotion. I therefore wished to be received there; my relatives interceded for me, and I obtained admission. I entered the convent with the intention, as I can swear on my soul, of serving the Lord there with all sincerity, and began my novitiate in that intention. But we had a terrible man who guided us, the priest David. He read with us the book of a Capuchin about the will of God; but he interpreted this in a most peculiar manner, in which our mistress-novices entirely agreed with him. Under the pretext of obtaining perfect obedience, which must also overcome the most severe and nature-contrary things, he introduced atrocious practices. He said: one must kill sin by sin, in order thereby to return to the innocence of our first parents, who before their fall did not know shame. Those among us were then regarded as the holiest and most virtuous who appeared quite naked in the choir and in the garden, and in that state performed dances. We were accustomed to touch one another; to practice every kind of unnatural sins as paganism had known; to abuse the image of the Crucified and the sacrament of the altar in every possible way." \[Page 101\]

The author took what he reports in this book partly from his own observation, partly from the records of the Parliament of Grenoble and from the testimonies of the arrested prophets, especially of the beautiful Isabelle.

At first I resisted these abominations, and was therefore regarded as a disobedient, headstrong, malicious, and refractory person, who was possessed of her own will. When once I was to go to Communion naked down to the belt, I had refused to do so, but I had to yield; when I wished to cover myself at the small grille with the altar-cloth, this was snatched away from me, and when I then used my hands to cover myself, David ordered me to fold them. My conscience kept making constant reproaches to me about all these things; David said these were not sins, and another confessor whom I asked for was not allowed me. I therefore left the convent; but inexperienced as I was, I took the position of a gatekeeper (pförtnerin) of the convent that was offered me; and so I remained, entirely given over to my indiscretion, in that office, albeit outside the convent, yet continuously connected with it.1) I had left at the end of January; at Candlemas David travelled to Paris, then returned at the end of Lent, and died on the Monday of Holy Week. Nothing had occurred between us, except for some licentiousness; but before his journey he had entrusted to me a little casket with the prohibition not to open it. Curiosity, however, drove me to disobey his command; and I found a paper in it, written by him in an unknown hand, but I returned everything to him on his return. I then tended him for a short time during his illness, which appears to have been a syphilitic sore; and on the day of his death he gave this paper to Mathurin Picard, and appointed him his successor in the convent, in his sense and spirit, and in a private interview recommended me to his care. This paper was the paper of blasphemies that was always used on the Sabbath. \[Page 102\]

\"So I was in the office of porter, but Picard was confessor and director of the convent. I had now fallen into worse hands than before; his insolence toward me grew quickly, and though I tried to defend myself against him, I could not; for he held me fast in the chains of hell. At Easter I was to make my confession to him; but scarcely had I begun when he would not hear me further; everything I brought forward he said were not sins. He feigned a passionate love that he harbored for me; he begged for reciprocal affection, and began to caress me. Since that confession I had no other kind with him; all were like that sacrilegious and damnable one. Yet I never loved that unhappy priest from the heart, and I do not know by what power he bound me to him and thus kept me bound. It is a misery when one does not leave to souls the choice of their confessor, and binds them to one who can ruin them.

Our relationship was known in the convent; even outside, many pressed to pull me out of the danger; but in the convent they would not allow me another confessor. It is true that I myself did nothing about it --- whether from timidity or a tendency to an unbound life --- which I ought to have done. He pursued me continually, and did not cease from me even in a violent illness, when I was senseless and more dead than alive. Yet because of my resistance he did not succeed in gaining his whole will with me all that time; except once, when he was ill, or only pretended to be ill, and then using force rather than persuasion he wrested my consent from me. What has been said about a similar occurrence in the church is, thank God, unfounded except for one attempt on his part.

That, however, was not the only thing he intended against me to rob me of my honor; there was another thing I did not suspect because I did not know his devilish arts. While I was ill he had me sign a paper whose contents I did not know. Once at the altar he put a host into my hand, and then, pressing my hand, he broke it so that the pieces fell to the ground. Likewise he wanted me to drink of the wine which he had left in the chalice after the completion of the Mass --- which I, however, never did. Once he said to me: 'My dear, I am building this church; after my death you will see miracles; will you not agree?' I said yes, without understanding the meaning of his words. \[Page 103\]

I was concerned only for my honor; he feared on his side that I might be pregnant: therefore he consented that I should go back into the convent, which was no difficulty, since he furnished a sum of money for it. I found there still the same filth in the novitiate as before, although Picard did not come and go among the nuns as freely as David had done earlier. Hardly fifteen days had I been there when he sought a pretext to come into the garden where I was with some nuns. He followed us, and after he had come to a certain spot he produced a host from a book he had with him; with it he picked up some drops of blood that had fallen to the ground, for I was then menstruating. He wrapped them up, called me out into the churchyard, and used my finger to push them into an opening near a shrub. He never spoke to me further about the matter; but I acquired a strong inclination to go repeatedly to that spot, and there I had many filthy temptations and practiced much impurity. Later --- I believe soon after I had taken my vows --- he demanded a copy of my profession; I wrote it while he dictated.\" \[Page 104\]

Then he said, when I was about to sign them, that I must now bind my purpose to his; if he should die before me, I must be willing to die likewise; if he were damned or saved, I must choose the same fate for myself. I was terribly frightened by this, and after much resistance I gave only an outward assent, up to, as I believe, the point of damnation. Meanwhile I continued to suffer many pangs of conscience, and I wished to make my confession to the confessor of the sick in the hospital we visited. Picard, who perceived this, hastened to put his design into effect. One day, when he handed me Communion at the grille, he touched my breast through the veil with his finger, and instead of the usual words said: "You will see what will happen to you because of this." I went to my place in the choir, but restlessness drove me into the garden, where I sat down beneath a mulberry tree. There appeared to me a cat which set its hind feet on my knees and its forepaws on my shoulders, and then barred its dreadful jaws over my mouth, as if it would take the Communion from me. Whether that actually happened I do not know; for I sat there for perhaps an hour, unable to make the sign of the cross or to drive the creature away. Picard saw me that same day, and when I asked: was that all the glory I was to receive that day? he answered: "You will see quite other things yet!" Two or three days later he said: "My dear! we have now seen one another; do you not wish that we should see one another again?" I said yes, to the ruin of my soul. In the night, about eleven, after I had already slept, I heard what sounded like a nun calling me. I rose, and when I reached the door I lost consciousness and felt myself carried to a place where, besides Picard, several clerics and nuns were present. He at once said: "Beloved, did I not tell you we would see one another again today?" I answered: "Yes; but I did not think it would be outside the convent; this assembly is also unknown to me." He said: "You must not trouble yourself about that," and so he drew from me a formal assent to everything that was there to happen and that he in particular would do --- the one and only formal assent he extracted from me. Yet my conscience would never be entirely pacified; Picard knew this well, and therefore never quite trusted me, nor did he ever initiate me into his secrets. The day after that event I disclosed everything to the confessor Langlois; whether he was aware of the matter or not, he did not tell me that I had been led to the Sabbath, and left me without counsel. Six months later I told him of my more frequent abductions; which was the easier to do because he had been given the monastery confessional, and Picard, on suspicion, had been removed from it. I had resolved to make a general confession, and had already made three quarters of it, when Picard learned of it and had me called to the confessional grille. He asked why I had stayed so long with the new confessor. I answered: to make a general confession. "Well," he said, touching my hand, "you have begun, but you will not finish!" He had spoken truly, for, as he afterwards confessed to me, he had cast a spell between me and the confessor; when I began, it was as if the confessor closed my mouth and drove the sins back. He seemed to be bound in my presence; I, however, as soon as I entered the confessional, was terribly tormented. It pressed down upon me with great force when I tried to begin; it struck my head against the walls and threw me to the ground. One could hear the blows I received; people saw me swollen and black and blue from them, without knowing whence they came. \[Page 105\]

After the Communions I was turned over, my feet pointing upward, and I was compelled to vomit up what I had taken. I wrote to Father Benedict, but the letter was taken from me. I wrote to the Bishop of Evreux; my letters, some of which still remain, did not make an impression until the fifth year of my torments.

If one considers this hair‑raising story of seduction, which embraces the events of many years, and in which many transitions may have dropped out owing to the unfaithfulness of memory, the horror that besets these depths of human nature will whirl and confound the spirit that looks down into them, unless it rests on the most secure foundation. If among the sacraments the Eucharist must be regarded as first, because it subordinates itself as the essence and core of the whole house of healing to its centre, then after it priestly ordination will follow first in order; for it must prepare the ways and the little rill in which the streams of this and all sacraments flow. Just as things stand concerning the sacraments in the Church of Light, so do they stand concerning the execraments in the demon's midnight church, in which the real substance of the sacramental is transformed into an ape‑like, lying mockery. Thus the deepest negation is implanted in the Sabbath's Eucharist, which therefore also holds the apex of these execraments; while the next place in the sevenfold order is occupied by the witchly ordination, which opens the ways through which the curse of hell comes upon the world. If now the consecrated of the Lord, priests and his brides, are to be transformed into the consecrated of the demon, his sorcerer‑priests and his paramours, then, before their luciferization takes place---to use the phrase of one from their midst---first their debasement must precede; only immediately, and indeed only after the full and unambiguous assent, the uncoerced joining of their will has taken place, will the reception and immediately the promotion to the priesthood occur.

To this end the asceticism that those priests of the abyss introduced into the novitiate was calculated: the novices were to pass, by an indifferent state of nature, into the contrary state, and sin was not to be combatted by good but to be killed by suicide through itself; so that, after shame, set as guardian, had been extinguished, the access of nature on that side would stand open. David had gone so far when Picard took his place. He had been pastor at Mesnil‑Fourdain near Louviers, and was regarded as a man highly experienced in the spiritual life. But, as Father Esprit du Bosroger, who knew him, related, he had been in league with a sect of false Illuminati; and he knew how to control his mien, gait, speech and all his actions so well that one might have taken him for an angel of heaven. His serious bearing, his downcast eyes, the long beard, the pallor of his face; the mildness of his words, to which those who spoke with him accommodated themselves; the warmth of his zeal, the measuredness of his actions, the restraint of his ideas despite all reserve, sometimes exalted by flaming words about God or Paradise; his sighs and his contemplative expression, the long duration of his Masses, during which he appeared beside himself; his prayers of thanksgiving interrupted by sobs and deep silence---all gave him the appearance of a great friend of God and a consummate spiritual man; and yet he was nothing but a great Pharisee and hypocrite, a wolf among the sisters of that convent.

He continued where his predecessor had left off. Nakedness, he said, was originally the sign of true innocence; for all sin is not in the body and in bodily actions, but in the discrimination of human craftiness. \[Page 106\]

"He who distinguishes is accursed and damned," says the Apostle; he who does not see sin has not committed any, for the spirit, closely united with God, has committed none. All human cleverness and earthly understanding, even shame, must therefore be mortified; the spirit must not crawl into reflections, meditations and distinctions about its actions; but, abandoning itself to passions and earthly faults, give them over to tear themselves to pieces in confusion, and then fly with the eagle to the sun.

No wonder that the woman Bavent, a spiritually limited but passionately bold girl, fell into the pitfalls of this gnostic; three or four others who had listened to him had, as P. Esprit relates --- who later for a long time was confessor in the convent --- the same fate; the others would hardly all have escaped him, had he not been led away by trials to Rome and Paris, and, after he returned, had not illnesses removed him from their path.

It is a general law of nature that opposites, so long as they are not abolished, only tighten themselves the more. The swiftest progress along this precipitous path will be toward the goal when, as happened at the first seduction, the sensual delight of pride -- to be like the Elohim -- adds itself; and the presumption to risk everything that can lead to the gratification of each of the two. This, therefore, is the great danger that immediately presents itself at the divergence of ordinary life-roads, and which he who penetrates more deeply from there must above all withstand. For the natural way divides itself at this point of departure, in that what in it had been intertwined with one another there separates; and from thence two distinct ways proceed, each in a different direction: one of which rises upward to the light, the other leads down into the night.

Just as at the divisions of lands and waters, it depends on a small elevation or depression of the ground whether the waters flow to the north or to the south, to this or that sea; so at these great forks of life there works a thrust of the deeper nature which takes refuge behind pride, and the titillation at the call of holiness, so that the downward way is chosen; at first under the delusion that it is the one which leads upward. In place of the serpent of salvation and light there is then the dragon of the abyss, which, having seized its tail with its mouth and appropriated self-consciousness to itself; and as it illuminates with its false, glittering light the inner being that it entangles, the deluded one imagines himself to walk in the light of Godhead itself. Examples will here most clearly set forth this unhappy relation, and we cannot choose a more striking one than that which occurred in the first half of the sixteenth century in Spain. There lived at that time Magdalena del Cruz, a Franciscan nun in the convent of St. Elizabeth at Córdoba; born in 1487 at Aguilar, entering that convent in 1504, and, having rapidly attained to great reputation for holiness, chosen abbess in 1532 and again in 1536 and 1540; but in 1541 brought before the Inquisition, which then instituted proceedings against her. \[Page 109\]

A witness in that same process may be heard concerning the reputation in which she stood, as follows. "The good repute which she enjoyed made acquaintance with her desirable to me; for everything I was told of her excited my admiration, and I heard all the world speak of her holiness. Not only the people held this opinion, but eminent persons: cardinals, archbishops, bishops, dukes, scholars, men of the orders of every kind esteemed her highly. I learned in particular how Cardinal Alphons Maurique came over expressly from Seville to see her, and in his letters called her his very dear daughter; how the Inquisitors of Córdoba showed her the greatest respect, and how Cardinal Quignones, General of the Franciscans, made the journey from Rome to visit and speak with her. Also I myself had seen how Jean Reggio, the nuncio of the Roman court, had arrived in Córdoba to satisfy his curiosity; and our Empress, the consort of Charles V, had called her in a letter her very dear mother, and the happiest being on earth. That letter, in addition to her portrait as a memento that she should remember her in prayer, was accompanied by the veil and the baptismal shirt of her newly born prince, Philip II; for the purpose that she should pronounce a blessing over both. People spoke of her throughout Christendom; the preachers praised her from the pulpits, and all others paid her homage in the same way, without giving room to any doubt about her merit and her holiness."

She was the object of the most tender affection of all the confessors of the convent, and of the provincial of the order; and those who were furthest advanced in piety believed they saw in her way of life a new path to attain sanctity. In truth she was amiable toward everyone, loving with modesty, compassionate and so good an example that she urged everyone to serve God; and indeed her company led many persons to enter a religious life. Her skill in conducting affairs was so great that people pressed from all sides to hear her counsel, and her convent was comparable to an office.

Other witnesses who testified to the same matters also spoke of her ecstasies and her raptures; they brought up her prophecies and the prognostications she had made: among other things, how she foretold the death of the Marquis of Billen, the cardinal's hat for her order's general Quignones, the captivity of King Francis I, and his marriage to the widowed Queen of Portugal, the sister of Charles V. All this had led to a biography of her being printed even during her lifetime. So it stood with her outwardly, and now one may marvel at the labyrinths of the human heart: she herself appeared on the 7th of May 1546 at her Auto da Fé to hear her final sentence, after the secretary of the court had read the extract of her trial, from which the following results concerning her inner life emerged. \[Page 110\]

Magdalena had testified that when she was in her fifth year the demon had appeared to her in the shape of an angel of light, and had proclaimed to her that she was called to become a great saint; at the same time urging her to lead a devout life immediately. The apparitions had thereafter recurred often. Once the spirit had assumed the form of the Crucified and had urged her to crucify herself with him; which she performed with the help of nails that she drove into the walls. But when he then invited her to follow him, she fell to the ground and had two ribs broken, which the spirit, always in the guise of the Lord, afterward healed. When she had been seven years old, the demon, continuing the deception further, encouraged her to begin an even stricter life. Burning with great zeal, she therefore one night left her paternal house at Aguilar and went to a nearby cave with the intention of living there as a hermit.

The next morning, however, she had found herself again in her father's house without knowing how it had happened to her. One day the spirit, constantly pretending to be the Lord, married her, and as a sign of the union touched two of her fingers; announcing to her at the same time that the growth of the touched fingers would henceforth be arrested; which accordingly occurred, and she resolved to relate the incident to many people as a miracle. At twelve years old she was already regarded as a saint, and to secure herself in this reputation she performed many good works and false miracles. She had visions of spirits who took on the form of those saints she especially venerated; such as St. Jerome, Dominic, Francis and Anthony. In their presence she fell to her knees, thinking them to be saints; at times she even believed she saw the Holy Trinity and other extraordinary things; and all this only increased her desire to be esteemed a saint. When this vanity had at last become predominant in her soul, the demon showed himself to her in the guise of a very handsome young man, confiding to her that he was one of the fallen seraphim, and that he had accompanied her since her fifth year. His name was Balban, and that of a companion he had was Pithon.

He made her understand that if she continued to stand to him in the same relation as before, she could enjoy every pleasure whose notion her spirit could conceive; and that it would then be his business to spread still further the reputation for holiness which she had already attained. Magdalena accepted the proposal on the condition that she should not be bound forever, which Balban granted without scruple. There followed a formal pact with the demon, in which she promised to give herself up to his counsel. From that moment the spirit, as an incubus, clung to her, until the extrajudicial confession which she made in her convent in 1543. Once he appeared to her in a black, hideous form; and when she, terrified by it, cried "Jesus!" that drove him off. He, however, soon returned, vehemently reproached her for her mistrust, but then reconciled himself with her again when she promised not to be frightened again should he appear to her in the same guise; which thereafter happened several times. \[Page 111\]

After she had taken the habit, whenever she went to Communion she gave a cry and feigned ecstasies which her fellow-sisters took for real. On one such occasion her feet were pierced with pins; she did indeed feel the pain, but restrained herself so as not to lose her reputation. For the same reason she several times had herself crucified in her cell, and inflicted wounds on her hands, feet and side. With the help of her spirit she sometimes left the convent and visited some other place; there she saw everything that had taken place and then told it to others to display her secret knowledge. Once she was said to have been in Rome, and to have received Communion from the hands of a priest who was burdened with a mortal sin. Meanwhile no one in the convent noticed her absence; for Pithon had entered there in her form in her stead. Her spirit foretold to her many future events: for example the captivity and marriage of the King of France, the wars of the Communeros and other things; yet not all that he thus proclaimed came to pass. She fell out with him from time to time: once, when he had made to her a shameful demand and she had rejected him, he in his anger tore her up very high and then let her fall back to the ground; so that she was carried back to her cell in a very bad state.

With regard to the deceptions by which she contrived to set herself in the reputation for holiness, Majolus's account points more to supernatural states, only intensified on the wrong side; whereas the extracts that Florente made in his Wunderscheu rather seem to betray a crafty trickster who was at first deceived and then deceived others and herself. The former assures us: on feast days she was often seen hovering three or more ells above the ground. Whenever, on the appointed days, she went with the other nuns to Communion, one of the hosts --- previously and carefully counted --- was always found missing from the priest who distributed them; it was then ultimately found, visibly to all, in her mouth. Often she carried the image of the newborn Redeemer in her arms, showering it with her tears; and in doing so her hair had grown down to her feet, and in like manner gradually receded again. Florente tells either a different incident, or the same in another way, when he reports that she, in an abusive apprehension of a mystical idea, made the nuns and others believe that she had conceived the child by the Holy Spirit on the day of the Annunciation and had given birth to it at Christmas from light. She then wrapped the newborn in her hair, which then, black as it had previously been, became red; but the child left her some time afterwards. \[Page 112\]

People now wanted the hair as relics in many places, and she gave some of it to several people. One day, when she was in the choir with the nuns, her demon, it was said, came in the shape of a dove and sat close to her ear. She then told the sisters that it was the Holy Spirit, and they thereupon threw themselves down to worship it. She confessed that for eleven years she had tried to make people believe that she took no food and contented herself only with the Eucharist. But this had been false; for during the first seven years she had secretly eaten bread and drunk water, assisted in this by some nuns trusted by her. During the last four years she had eaten various things that others knew how to procure for her. In addition she had persuaded others to eat meat on fast days, or even to work on feast days, because it was not forbidden; she had also made those with whom she associated closely believe that many priests and monks kept concubines without offending God, because it was not a sin to have such companions. She confessed many other false revelations, apparitions of souls, angels, and demons; many false prophecies, healings, and in general manifold abuses which she had made of her reputation for holiness.

She had carried on her charade for thirty‑eight years with success; at last her pretence that she did not eat became the rock upon which she foundered. Some convent sisters had grown suspicious, looked more closely, and in the last year of her office as superior discovered the fraud. They revealed what they had discovered to the provincial, the guardian, and the confessors; no one would give credence to their statements, and all declared the accusation to be slander. On the day, however, when a new election in the convent took place, the party of her opponents gained the upper hand, and one of them was elected abbess. This happened in 1542. Until then the alms that had been brought to her had been immeasurable; and she had applied them to the advantage of the convent, which she had almost rebuilt from the ground up. Now, since she no longer stood at its head, she used what she received as she pleased, because the donors had left everything to her discretion.

In the following year she became seriously ill; her conscience awoke, and after hard struggles she now made a confession, by word and in writing, of all the deceptions she had practised. The letter of a nun dated 30 January 1544, in the records, gives an account of what took place on that occasion. The physicians had declared that her condition left no room for hope and that she must prepare herself for death. When her confessor appeared to prepare her to receive the last sacraments, she was seized by a convulsive trembling whose violence put everyone in alarm. She begged him to return the next day; but when the convulsions recurred that day and the next, the confessor concluded that a supernatural cause lay at the root of it, and he exorcised her. The power of the exorcism forced the demon to speak through her mouth. He said he was one of the seraphim, that at his side stood a companion, and that several legions obeyed him. He had possessed Magdalena almost from her birth, and was of the firm resolve not to leave her; because she belonged to him, and he lived in the hope of dragging her down with him into Hell. The confessor then gathered all the convent sisters and asked them, in their presence, to confirm what they had heard. She then declared that she had had several demons since her childhood, and that she had kept them willingly since her thirteenth year, in accordance with a pact she had concluded with them on the condition of attaining the reputation of sanctity. \[Page 113\]

She added to this confession the account of a host of particular circumstances that aroused astonishment. The confessor reported what had occurred to the provincial of the order, who arrived at the convent before Christmas 1513 with several other members of the order. The inquisitors of Córdoba, having been informed of the matter, now intervened in the affair and asserted that the investigation belonged to them exclusively. The provincial had meanwhile put himself in readiness to administer the sacraments to her; and arranged that she should sign in her cell a statement in which she confessed several of her deceptions. Magdalena then received the viaticum and thanked God that she had been able to perform this act without an outward and striking incident; although she nevertheless always doubted that God would show her mercy.

The convent sisters had withdrawn; Magdalena was alone with the one who had recorded all these circumstances in her letter, and who had stayed behind to make the preparations necessary for the Last Anointing. Suddenly the sick woman told her that she felt much better, expressed an extraordinary desire to take food, and urgently begged her to bring something to satisfy her hunger. When the sister now brought her some nourishment, she seemed to return to life with joy. When the confessor visited her, she wished to continue her confession orally; the confessor prepared to set it down in writing in the presence of Father Peter of Vergara. But Magdalena opened her mouth only to retract everything she had previously declared; whereupon the two priests left her displeased. The nuns then urged her, for the sake of her own peace, to make a sincere confession, and she at last promised them. The confessor then acted as if he were dismissing everyone; but they positioned themselves so that they could hear everything without being seen by the patient. Magdalena then made various declarations, the confessor wrote them down, and obtained from her the promise to sign the written statement in the presence of the convent sisters. They appeared at once; but as they drew near, trembling and convulsions returned to her. The confessor therefore resumed the exorcisms; the evil spirit again began to speak in her and declared that he still possessed her person. Finally, on the 14th of December the patient calmly repeated in the presence of the provincial the confessions she had made and confirmed them; and the agents of the Inquisition immediately arrested her and led her to the prisons of the Office.

To the circumstances as Florente here relates them from the records --- though of course only in extract, passing over everything that seemed to him incredible --- Majolus adds some others, which likewise have no other attestation than this very testimony. During the investigation the demon, who --- according to another reporter --- usually took the form of a Moor, by no means abandoned his outward performances; he was present at matins, to the astonishment and consternation of the nuns, in her form, and undertook many other ministrations on her behalf. The nuns therefore conceived such an abhorrence of their former abbess that, after an inquiry into her case, they by many entreaties finally brought it about that she be removed from the convent, so that the haunting might at last cease. \[Page 114\]

In order to judge how much cunning fraud, self‑deception and indeed demonic besetting on their part have cooperated here; how much the credulity and partiality of their surroundings have contributed, one would at the very least have to have the records themselves before one; and even with their addition it would be difficult to assign to each of these moments --- which probably all acted together --- its definite boundary. She was, moreover, condemned to proceed from her cell in the religious habit, but without veil, with a rope about her neck, a gag in her mouth, and a burning candle in her hand, to the cathedral of Córdoba; where a scaffold for her Auto da Fé had been erected, in order from there to hear the reading of her sentence, as well as the customary sermon that followed. The sentence ran as follows: that she should be enclosed in a convent of Franciscan nuns outside the city, there to pass the remainder of her days. She was to be excluded from the assemblies of the community, and exercise no voice therein; she was not to be permitted to wear a veil, and every Friday was to dine with the penitents in the refectory. Without the permission of the Inquisition she was never to dare to speak with anyone, her fellow‑sisters, the confessor, and her superiors excepted; and only after the lapse of three years was she to be admitted again to the Lord's table, unless in the case of serious illness.
