The Possession and Exorcism of Johanna F.verbatim:
Born shortly after the middle of the sixteenth century, in Soignies on the Sambre, she then became a nun in the convent of the Black Sisters in the town of Bergen in Hainaut, belonging to the diocese of Cambrai. In the year 1584, when she counted twenty-five years, and Louis of Berlaimont was Archbishop and Duke of Cambrai, it was perceived and noted in her that she was possessed and taken by evil spirits; and the archbishop decreed that the ecclesiastical remedies should be applied to her. The struggle lasted nearly two years; at last she was entirely freed after hard resistance, and shortly before, in obedience to a vision, she wrote her self-confessions, which we here communicate in extract.

I know that by my father's curse I was delivered to the Devil. In my fourth year he appeared to me in the form of a handsome young man, desired to be my father; and because he brought me an apple and white bread, I consented to his request and took him for my real father. As long as I was still a child, I had beside him another who took care that I would not feel the blows when I was punished. That continued until my twelfth year, when, weary of the convent in which they had me educated, I returned to my mother. From there I was soon again bound out to a seamstress in Bergen, so that I should learn to sew there, where I then had almost my free will. Now my alleged father came to me, saying: because I had taken him as father, I must necessarily live by his will. Hitherto I had lived like a child; now, however, it was fitting that I live as he would show me; and like all people lived, even if they did not say so. If I did not do it, he would inflict upon me the pain which he showed me; if I consented to what he required of me, I should have silver and gold whenever I wished, and of food and drink whatever my heart desired.

At first I refused, then I yielded to him, and granted everything he wanted. Now a great throng of them appeared before me, whereat I was somewhat terrified, because I had never seen more than two or three of them together. They then made me take paper and pen and write down that I renounced baptism, Christianity, and all the ceremonies of the Christian Church. After I signed the document with my blood, they made me swallow it in a bitter orange. It seemed very sweet to me up to the last bite; that last bite, however, was so bitter that I could not endure it. From that time on I have been everywhere hostile to the Church, had a great dread of it, always sought to flee and avoid it, and to hide myself from it; otherwise, however, I have always lived in every wickedness and all sins.

When I had grown somewhat older and they began to speak to me of receiving the holy Sacrament, it was most abhorrent to them; and they tormented me almost until I promised them that, if I got hold of that, I would act according to their counsel and will. First I had to give and present my tongue to one of them, so that in confession before the priest I would say nothing more than what they deemed good. When I was to go to the Lord's table, they had made the holy Host altogether loathsome to me, and had made me abhor it; yet I was to comport myself with a false heart and flattery about it, as the others among whom I lived did. \[Page 117\]

Even during and throughout Mass I ate much sugar and confectionery, to the shame of the most venerable Sacrament. When I then received the Host at the altar, I immediately stepped to one side; and because, as long as I had it in my mouth, I was sorely tormented in my throat, I took it straight out and wrapped it in my neckerchief. At home I laid it in a little white linen cloth; though they wished that I should cast it into some unclean place. Afterwards, however, it was by a higher power taken away from my person. I could not comprehend why people of such wicked sort showed so much reverence and adored it: and no one could give me any satisfactory account of it. My questioning angered the evil spirits; they blasphemed the holy Host to the utmost, and I had to draw up a document for them in which I renounced that loose, vain Communion, together with the false god on the cross. I also cursed the sacrifice of the Mass, and vowed that whenever I saw the Host lifted up I would, with my eyes fixed upon it, spit in Christ's face, and blaspheme and revile him. In return I bound myself to worship their gods henceforth, and to observe all their ceremonies.

They put the writing, written with my blood, into my body; a third writing, to abide with them forever, they kept in their custody outside my body. Thus I was wholly and entirely separated from the Catholic Church, as if I had never been in it. Since it did not at all times suit that I should be able to remove the Host from my mouth at Communion, I agreed with them that they should all depart from me on that same day. For they could not endure the burden of the holy Host; it pressed upon them too strongly, and they held me on that very day to be unclean and unfit; but on the following day they tormented me all the harder for it. Whenever I wished to go to church, they made my limbs so heavy, as if I were dragging masses of iron behind me.

When I entered the order, I once more set up for them a new writing: in which I granted them full power over body and soul; I bestowed upon them both of my free possessions forever, and entrusted them wholly to their protection and shelter. Thus they had almost swallowed me up, and wholly transformed me into themselves; and I could do no good work any more, lived quite brutishly without any knowledge of God; yet they let me go on carelessly and without seriousness in performing what the order required. On the night before I took the customary monastic vows, they made me write a protestation: that my vow should be only a sham; instead of yielding my obedience to God and to my superiors, I gave it into their hands, to deal with it for their favor. I am, they said, not a nun at all, and would never be one in eternity; as proof of this I delivered to them the profession which I had made. Thus the longer I was with them, the more perverse I became. If sometimes good thoughts came to me, they tormented me with many godless things, and I had now to put my heart in writing to them as well; so that they might lay the writing upon what had been written, and govern it thereby according to their pleasure.

Now a cursed spirit came to me, who at first threatened me most severely, and demanded of me that I should grant him alone as much power over body and soul as all the others together had. He also brought three others with him, whom I was to permit to enter and depart my body at their pleasure; in return he promised to furnish me so richly with art and skill that I might confute everyone who came against me. I was rashly curious, and would gladly have learned the art which he almost loudly extolled to me. \[Page 118\]

I was also persuaded, and gave to the first of the three my memory, to the second my understanding, to the third my will; and they each carried them into me and placed them in their particular seat. Thus all my senses were bound, and I was transformed from a person into a devil. The loose knave then brought me another one, who was called the Enchanter; he had the shape of a Rübezahl, almost fair and pleasant to look upon. When I held this in my hands I saw and knew whatever I could desire. By means of it I also had knowledge of all evil and unjust doctrines and religions in every place and corner; I also saw and knew all their ceremonies and the falsely supposed worship of God that is practiced everywhere; of that one could write an unspeakable amount. To this I was moreover obliged: that, if every earlier obligation should become powerless, the one, strangely written in foreign and unknown characters, and as comprehensive as the others, should remain hidden and valid. After him followed another, called Freilehre; he gathered blasphemers, heathens and Saracens about him. He asked me why I still carried a piece of the Cross on me. I had to tear it from me with terrible railing and cursing; they made me trample it with my feet, and I had to renounce the crucified God who allowed himself to be hanged on it, and his blood, all the articles of the faith and the holy sacraments.

They set before me now meals of all sorts of foods, and I held myself the happiest person on earth; in this they greatly strengthened me, and I was entirely willing and ready. After some time they accused me that I had never asked any favor of them; I should desire to receive baptism in their fashion and manner, which I then did, so that I would become wholly and entirely their own. They then took off my garment, anointed all my limbs with a precious oil, as it seemed to me, together with other great pomp; then clothed me again in quite different garments, and I chanted with them their loose, doggish Mass and cursed devilish words. Since they also said they had no power to fasten me entirely in their service until I renounced all the graces I had received from the Church, I had to deny the sacrament of Confirmation. I was now also to receive Communion, in their fashion and manner, from their hands every month, and beforehand abstain for three days from every other food, except that which they gave me. They then took a morsel which had a very pleasant and sweet taste; with that they played much mockery and pomp. They did this upon a high elevated place, pronounced a blessing over it according to their opinion; then they gave it into my mouth, and that they called their Communion.

Against the Christian Communion they spoke blasphemous, scornful words; I had to throw the holy Host to the ground, and they spat upon it; yet I am quite certain I remember that I could never bring myself actually to hit it. They also let me take a piece of the holy Cross; I set it upon the top of a credenza, fastened the holy Host to it, and then said: if he were the right, true God, he must show it, and would not allow himself to be so miserably dressed and tormented! And I know well that I did all this with particular rage, scorn and hatred. I, wretch, held this pious God worse than the thieves who were crucified with him; for I could not once get into my head that a God should thus allow himself to be nailed to a cross. Therefore when I once saw a procession with the holy Sacrament pass by my room, and then saw the people with their many lights and great devotion and reverence, I wondered greatly how it came about that so many people would strive to accompany such a thing, which to me was so utterly repugnant, indeed an abomination. \[Page 119\]

And I began almost to laugh and to deride: Behold a wonder! how is it that the one whom the Christians worship is carried about by men; and moreover so mockingly and always in the shape of a naked man. Meanwhile they set up before me, by the one who called himself a sorcerer, all manner of panels and images, and they placed these their idols aloft with great reverence and diabolical singing; which, at that time, sounded very pleasing in my ears, and then I offered no canonical hour or prayer except what they put into my mouth.

When these their idols thus stood forth in their glory, they made me step up to the first tier; thereupon they raised a great clamor and shouting; and I pledged them my fidelity, and never to worship any other god than those to which they should point me. After such an oath they embraced me with great joy, praised and exalted me to the highest --- thinking they had never bound any creature so firmly to themselves as they had bound me. They also often gave me great feasts, and told me with what unspeakable joy they would lead me from this life into that life.

They were exceedingly angry at the images of the saints; and I had to suffer severely if I uttered my customary prayer, which they had taught me, in their presence. They otherwise held very rigidly and strictly to their statutes; I also had to confess my transgressions to one of them; thereupon I was punished without any mercy; and one after another came and inflicted some torment upon me. When a commanded fast-day occurred, they brought me meat and forced me to eat it; even unclean animals they thrust into my body when I acted against their command. All high feast-days, the Christians' times of joy, were fast-days for me; I had also to perform all sorts of practices contrary to Christian rites. If I had not observed one, then they made me so hungry that I became as if furious and raging about it, and yet everything I tried to enjoy I had to give up again, until they were satisfied with their sport.

In such heavy servitude I led my life; one after another who called himself a god I had to obey for a day or a week at a time. Yet one always remained with me who brought me every sort of delight, joy and diversion; and that pleased me well, and I was of good cheer. Another, who called himself the spirit of true freedom, likewise kept close to me; and for several years they contrived so that they would gladly have brought me out of the cloister, but they were not able to do so.

Now one came to me who gave me an image, wondrously prepared, and said: if this is to be the true god, to whom you shall sacrifice and serve, he shall be called Ninus. Such a proposal pleased me exceedingly, for he recounted to me in splendid words his power and authority in the world. Upon my assent he bade the others prepare the place for it. A whole host of them appeared, to whom I devoted my body, so that they might do with it altogether according to their desire and will. The wretched sorcerer-devil, whose services I had employed in this, now presented to me a palace by his specter. But to me it was nothing else but as if it were a glorious, wondrously beautiful temple; and in my eyes it seemed that no church could be compared to such temples. \[Page 120\]

In these temples I worshipped the idol which I myself had made by diabolical craft and instruction, and which thereafter was burned by the priests in the fire. Now one came to me who called himself the spirit of blood, saying: so that you might be altogether perfect and without blemish, you must not offer a dead but a living sacrifice from your own body. At this proposal I was appalled; I had never before seen this god of blood, as he called himself, and I rejected his demand.

Then he threatened me strongly: he would make me a shame before the whole world; and the cursed villains tormented me so miserably that I had to obey their will at any time. Then a devil came with a great retinue who called himself Beleal, and to whom I was to sacrifice the victim. They set him with great reverence upon a splendid throne and waited on him for service. The blood-devil placed me before him and demanded of me that I, of my good, free will, give him power and authority to enter into my body, and from the same freely and unhindered take out the victim. From three parts of my body a piece was to be cut from each, which could not be done without gruesome pains, but great grace and rich reward would follow; for this work would have greater force and effect than anything I had ever done. I would then become like God, and they would afterwards cause me to be worshipped in God's stead. To such high promises I yielded to their will.

They now laid me upon a table, upon which I first had to spread a white linen cloth in order to catch the blood; and now, with my miserable pains, a piece was cut out which I wrapped in the blood and brought as an offering to Beleal. The same game was played with me for the next two days. Ah, what a painful sacrifice that was --- pain upon pain! --- and I also had to put on an outward show before the people as if I were burdened with some other bodily infirmity!

Meanwhile many pious and Christian people often spoke to me worthily about the most holy Sacrament; I thought to myself: if I might see a sign of it, I would straightway worship it beside my other gods as well. That displeased the devils, and they punished me bitterly for it. They bade me take a host, of which I always had a supply; and I took it up to a place in the house. "Now we will, make and command thee," they said, "that thou now, in our presence, curse and deny it, and with drawn knife, out of spite and mockery, stab it through; then thou wilt see what little power it has, and how weaker it is than we." Then, with a hardened heart, I drew my knife and thrust it into the most worthy Sacrament. After that stab the blood immediately began to gush from it, and the chamber was filled with a bright radiance which surrounded the holy host; which then again was transported back to its place where the others were. Then I was very frightened, especially since all the bystanders at once fled away with frightful howling, tumult and trembling, and left me half dead behind. I then began to weep and to consider that I had truly been deceived and seduced by the devils; and when I reflected properly on the sign I at last fell quite into despair. \[Page 121\]

Then the devils came raging to me, saying: they had indeed hitherto certainly deceived and seduced me; I had pierced the true God, whom they themselves acknowledged thereby; the sin which I had committed could not be forgiven; nothing remained for me but to do as Judas did and hang myself. Since they now also threatened to take my life, I consented to be hanged by them. They bade me go up upon the roof of the house and put my leather belt about my own neck. I did so, and gave them full power to deal with me according to their pleasure. There were a great number of them who disputed over my soul; they hoisted me up to strangle me. But however they attempted it, it was impossible for them to draw the belt tight about my throat. They ascribed this to the protection of a sodomitical wretch --- the so‑called St. Mary Magdalene --- who defended me; and said I ought to yield myself to the loose harlot.

I said it in plain words, for it seemed to me I was already half dead. But however cruelly they tormented me, and thrust into my belly, they nevertheless never were able to kill me. The murder-devil then said to me: I should thrust the knife into my throat; thereby I would inflict on myself the due punishment. But it was not possible for me to accomplish such a thing; for I could not bring my arm to my neck, however firmly a whole swarm helped me thereto. The girdle I had to give them, and they afterwards always kept it with them.

I then returned downstairs, tired, weak, shattered, and half broken; was exceedingly sad, and ceaselessly what I had seen lay upon my mind; and I had to lie down to recover. They sent for the physician, and gave me medicines; but by bodily means I could not be helped. From that time forward it lay constantly on my mind that I would gladly have sought the opportunity to learn the truth concerning the venerable Sacrament. But because I was not myself, and could not use any of my limbs according to my will, they hindered me whenever I came before a priest; and caused that I straightway spoke the opposite, and set forth all manner of subtle, captious things.

From that time on, whenever I went to the holy Sacrament, a trembling and a shudder assailed me: and it was finally perceived that I did not lead the life that a believing Christian and a person of the Order ought to live. Then counsel was taken in the convent to keep me confined in a separate room, and to consider counsel and means to reconcile me again with God. Yet at that time they could have no knowledge of all that had befallen me; and I led the most miserable life, desiring only to drown myself or to kill myself, if I could have found the opportunity. The nuns of the convent who saw me in that evil state had pity on me, comforted me, and spoke kindly to me. My words in return were so exceedingly awkward, rough and unfriendly, that they appeared unpleasant to them; therefore they had to leave me in my condition. \[Page 122\]

My lord, the Archbishop, came to our convent, and I wished to take refuge with him; but they so blinded my face that he appeared to me very stern and terrifying. They also once showed me the abyss of Hell, together with the punishment that I would have to suffer for each of my sins; I saw in a deep pit nothing but fire, darkness, intolerable stench, hellish dragons and serpents, one of which I must swallow, because I had received Communion on Holy Maundy Thursday. They have done all this to me out of their great malice, and all this is not fancy or imagination, but truly happened thus; for I know and confess that I committed the sins written above with my own body and my limbs, as I have told.

But the power and mercy of God, who never abandons his creatures in their distress, did not regard that I had gone far from him; rather he caused me to seek and run after help, and sent me Saint Mary Magdalene, who did not forsake me in all my greatest anguishes. To her praise and honor I have related what sort of life I led at the instigation of the devil; so that it may be made known to all the world what grace and help I obtained from this my intercessor and protector. As witnesses of this I take my God and Lord, the pious Lady and all the heavenly host; on earth, however, the Most Reverend Prince in God and Lord Archbishop of Cambrai, and all his priestly coadjutors; then all my fellow-sisters who have seen me.

Thus far the unfortunate woman's own handwritten report; but what occurred during the two years she was under spiritual treatment outwardly seemed to confirm completely what she afterwards reported about the state of her inner life. In her delusion she had at first made a prostration before the archbishop and begged his blessing. There her patron saint had appeared to her in great splendor, and to her terror, and to the consternation of her spirits, had received the blessing in her name. They then pronounced the exorcism over her, and compelled one of these spirits of hers to speak; and he confessed in all their names that they would be forced to depart by the merit of these saints.

When it was soon noticed that the patient was utterly and entirely without faith, priests were appointed to her by the archbishop to instruct her in the knowledge of God. She, however, showed herself stubborn and contentious and disputed every point; and the archbishop had to have her sign the Creed with her own hand in order to move her to grant him some belief. She was then instructed in her conventual duties; the original of her profession document, which had been lost, had to be procured again, and she was required to make her profession a second time.

They led her then through all the churches and to all the relics of the diocese, and bathed her in holy water, through whose power and effect all manner of base and abominable things then issued from her: tufts of hair and many little creatures, like smoky worms, came from her --- all of which caused a very great stench. To curb her malice and to weary the enemies, she was put into a dark and narrow prison. But as the evil only grew, she was brought back into the sick-room, and Sister Barbara Deruillers was assigned to her as keeper. There the evil spirits tormented her severely again, so that she often screamed for three hours at a stretch. In the presence of her keeper she was hurled from the bed into the room, and with head, arm, or the whole body so fiercely thrown against the floor that one saw the marks everywhere. \[Page 123\]

She could often eat nothing for three days, and then they filled her mouth with poisonous vermin. Once she was dragged to the brook that runs just behind the convent and thrust under the water. The keeper cried for help, and they could not drown her; the fellow sisters pulled her out alive. Another time she was cast from her chamber out of the window onto the courtyard; again she was led to the highest rooms of the house in order to hurl her down from there as well. To guard against this, they resolved to bind her with strong straps and ropes to a stout wooden chair and to lay her arms crosswise in a stock; but all in vain. She slipped her body, arm and leg nimbly out of the bonds without any knot having been loosened or any wood having been displaced from its place; and then at midnight she was led to a part of the convent that is very narrow and to which few people ever come, where, after long searching, she was finally found.

Then for a time she was made foolish so that she knew no one, and constantly said: "I will die, I!" and therefore would neither eat nor drink. Then she fell utterly silent and wept without cessation; at last she could neither sit nor lie down, but went like a madwoman pacing up and down the chamber. When a fast-day came, she could not take any food on the previous day; then on the day itself such a dreadful hunger came upon her that she would have eaten her own flesh. Thereupon, again in the presence of the priests, raw carrion was brought to her; and they filled her mouth with fetid blood and rotten flesh so that no one could endure being near her.

Now, following an apparition of her patron saint, a kind of wall was built around her in her chamber; which prevented the spirits from coming to her past the middle of the room. Soon, in confession, they learned from her the pledges she had made to them, and these were wrung from her by the exorcism. Fourteen consecrated hosts, which she had gradually put aside, were returned; and among them was one with a bloody mark where the stab had gone through. A piece of the cross also had to be fetched again.

She finally relapsed once more, and pledged anew to her spirits that she would never abandon them; but soon after, by a new apparition of her patron saint, she was again brought back to the right way. Now the images of silver and of bell‑metal to which she had sacrificed were surrendered. When they immediately learned also what had been done with the cutting out of a piece of flesh from her body, the spirits were compelled to speak about it. At first they denied it, then said that the injury of the wounded would be mortal if they left her. But when the exorcism continued, the three pieces, wrapped in the cloth, were placed at the spot assigned to them. She was then tormented the whole night with unheard‑of pains, until at last in the morning they left her. \[Page 124\]

She remained free for three weeks or longer, during which, in the last nights, much blood and putrid flesh came from her. An almost strange condition in several places of her body then continued for another year and 23 weeks, with much pain. Her evil spirits were now by the exorcism gradually entirely separated from her. Only one, who had been the first and had then taken the father's place with her, would absolutely not depart. He told her that whatever she had hitherto said and done had all happened through him; if he therefore left her, she would come to notable shame, because she, who had all along been counted a reasonable, sharp‑witted person, would then no longer be able to speak a single word of her own.

This moved her heart and distressed her so much that she threw herself at the feet of her exorcist, begging him to let her at least keep that one. When he refused, she cried amid many tears: "O what a bitter parting that is!" Only when he promised her that he would be her father in the place of the one expelled---whom she afterward additionally set beside the archbishop as grandfather---did she permit that he too be expelled.

Now the liberated woman had become truly natural, purely innocent, childlike in simplicity; she had become entirely ignorant, without any knowledge of God or of creatures; she could not utter any other words than: "Pater! Haus! and beautiful Maria!" With the image of the latter that was handed to her she played like a child with its doll, and spoke to it. They therefore had to take her again like a child into instruction, and first teach her to make the sign of the cross. By the archbishop's blessing her tongue had to be unloosed again to restore to her the use of speech. The same had to be done to all her limbs so that she might be able to walk properly again.

A whole year was still appointed to her as a year of penance, during which she, being exposed to outward attacks of her spirits, had to suffer severe torment. Meanwhile she was taught again to read and to pray. At a comforting apparition of her patron saint, on the anniversary of the former one, her mind became keener; and she then received instruction, in part from the archbishop himself, in the catechism of Father Canisius, not without much wrangling and resistance on her part. For occasional relapses still occurred from time to time; in one of these she rushed so furiously with fists and feet at the archbishop that he had scarcely enough to do to save his life from her.

When she came in the catechism to the doctrine of the Eucharist, she absolutely would not give credence to the truth of it; and it required a private vision to remove all her doubts. For four months she was then taught the choir-singing, which she mastered completely. Meanwhile her bodily injuries, arising from the suffering, had in silence again become so serious that they were obliged to summon the physician Cospeau and some women knowledgeable in female conditions to see whether they could not procure her some relief. The counsel which these, together with the physician, held amounted to this: the injury is mortal; the prescribed medicines, however, only caused her further torments; and it came to pass that within a few hours her death was expected. But after first many pieces of rotting flesh had come away, she was restored to her former state. After several times more demoniac ecstasies alternated with others of a higher kind, at last the crisis drew near. \[Page 125\]

She gathered all the clergy about her who had hitherto stood by her; they likewise summoned her convent-sisters so that all might be present with their prayers; and in the afternoon, at three o'clock, the struggle began in the presence of her patron saints. She faltered and trembled, and behaved as one in the last agonies; she spoke from time to time with her tormentors and answered their words. At times she cried out: They tear me apart, they tear me apart! Then she was again plunged into the utmost fear and pain. Thereupon she suddenly cried: Ah, how will it fare with me yet, I can no longer endure it!

They comforted her and strengthened her with prayers. Finally there came a tugging at the ceiling and a delirium like that of a dying person. When she was asked what she was beginning, she answered: She herself then lay down upon her pillow and lay there as in wide stillness, and the struggle was decided. The parts of her body which had been cut away and thereby separated and set apart were again joined together in their natural places, and all her pains ceased. Those present sang "Herr Gott, dich loben wir" (Lord God, we praise thee)! She displayed many wounds which she had received in the struggle, and showed the shirt that was full of blood; then prayed her hours and went with the sisters into the refectory to supper.

On 6 January 1586 she had yet one last convulsion, in which Mary Magdalene appeared to her, and she was wholly and forever freed. The course of events was then written down; that and the sister's writing were read before the apostolic and royal notary Godfried von Liere; in the presence of the archbishop, Dr. Fr. Buisseret, the official, the canon Goubille, Dean Hollo, Mansent, the canon of St. Germain, Banay, canon of Andemie, the confessor of the convent, the sister Deruillers, former attendant of Johanna, the present abbess, the liberated woman herself, the physician Cospeau, one of the midwives, and finally some of the old convent-women; all of whom, so far as concerned them, confirmed the truth of what had been read as eyewitnesses; whereupon the summoned notary, with his own signature, on 6 and 7 February 1586 ratified the instrument. \[Page 126\

As is therefore said in the Apocalypse, that the followers of the Beast are bound to bear a mark on the forehead or on the hand, and that no one may trade, buy or sell without it --- so in those regions where the Apocalypse is thus being realized in the hidden darkness, it is already done to newcomers at the very entrance to their gates. All are marked, in order to distinguish them from those who do not belong to the fellowship; and this mark can be covered, but not removed without higher assistance than they possess.

The mark, however, consists in small spots on the surface of the body, never larger than a pea, which are insensible, without life and blood, while all around them they find themselves surrounded on every side by living flesh. They are sometimes recognizable by a red or black spot, or by a depression of the flesh, but sometimes also externally indistinguishable; and then only by knowledge of the place where they are usually set, or by an inner instinct of the experienced can they be found. If one pricks them with a needle, neither pain follows nor any drop of blood; whereas both appear immediately if one pricks round about them, or if one has gone deeper than where those insensitive bloodless spots lie.

Such numbed spots differ from those that have arisen from some disease in that the latter are widespread, usually lie on the extremities, the flesh softens and dissolves, and they remain visible in all cases; whereas the former often become invisible, harden in the flesh, in no way hinder the use of the organs, and can extend over the whole body. In Lorraine some had this sign on the forehead, others at the back of the head, on the breast, on the back, on the hips, on the eyelids, on one of the shoulders, and on the most secret parts of the body. They had received it without pain, at the hour when they had become apostate from the faith; and the marked spots were as rigid and bloodless as limbs struck by lightning. In Labourd more than three thousand such marked persons had been found, among them a great number of children who had been at the Sabbath. To many the marks seemed also to have a certain external shape: a small cloud, a toad's foot, a hare's paw, a spider, a dog's or a horse's hoof; which, however, Maria von Sains denies.

Concerning the manner of the marking the various testimonies did not agree; for most had taken part in the act in youth and could no longer remember whether it had been the women who performed it upon them, or whether the master himself had impressed the mark.

Among the sorcerers from Castile he had used a needle of counterfeit gold. Gaufredy reported: a special demon was charged with it, who with the claw of the little finger presses the mark; one feels a slight warmth which penetrates more or less deeply into the flesh, according as the act was more superficial or more penetrating. According to others it was the horn that performed the service; and one sees that all agree in the fact of the signing, but differ among themselves about the manner and mode according to their subjective apprehension, the degree of their vision, and according to the notions they have formed of the whole matter in their testimonies.

The following case, which Remy recounts, appears to decide the question affirmatively. When Nicolaa Laghernhard from the Garminger Mill went to Assencauria in August 1590, and was walking along the edge of a forest at bright midday, she saw in the adjacent field a circle of dancing men and women who, however, turned their backs to her. When she looked more closely, she noticed among the dancers some interspersed whose feet appeared to her shaped like goat feet. Half-dead with fright, she called out the name of Jesus and prayed that she might return safely and unharmed to her home. In an instant, all the dancers vanished, with one exception: Peter Grospetter by name, who also quickly ascended into the air, but in the ascent let fall a baker's brush, with which bakers are accustomed to clean the oven before inserting the bread. She herself was likewise seized by a violent gust of wind, so that she could scarcely draw breath; and when she arrived home, she lay sick in bed for three days. The talk spread quickly among the people from her relatives; and Peter, so as not to give the appearance of confirming the truth of the story through his silence, lodged a vehement complaint about it with the judge---but then let it drop, in order not to expose himself through the trial to greater prolixities and dangers. This increased the suspicion against him, as it was attributed to a bad conscience. The judge therefore inquired all the more earnestly into the life he led and his morals; and since he found sufficient cause, he had him arrested and brought him to a confession that was not entirely unwilling, as well as to the naming of those who had been with him. Very instructive and significant is what occurred in the convent of Louviers regarding such things. As a result of the errors and confusions there, many nuns had become possessed; they were exorcised, and from the statements of their spirits it emerged that Picard had applied six different kinds of magic within the convent. One was composed to keep the nuns in constant discord; another, to awaken in their hearts a disordered inclination toward Picard and la Bavent; the third, to shake their chastity; the fourth, to awaken in them an inner aversion to faith, hope, and love, and to provoke blasphemies against God in them; the fifth, to arouse in them a desire for the Sabbath and all magic; the sixth, to produce in them a contempt and abhorrence toward all sacraments. The sorely pressed ones at last found themselves compelled to obey; and a great multitude of persons drawn together were eyewitnesses as they were truly found in their hiding places, and authentic verbal protocols were drawn up concerning it. On 14 June 1643, in accordance with the declaration of the spirit in Sister Maria of the Holy Sacrament, who called himself Putiphar, in the evening between 7 and 8 in her chamber, from a wooden paneling of the walls that had never seemed to be opened, the first was drawn forth. The second, the last among those enumerated above, was found on the 30th of July under the high altar six feet deep under the earth. On the 19th in the evening at half eleven a third in the sacristy, from the same depth; and on the 24th of August at half twelve in the cloister between the four doors a fourth. On the 8th of September at eight o'clock in the evening another followed, nine feet deep under the pillar of the new building, brought to light in the presence of the Archbishop of Toulouse. Again two others on the epistle and gospel sides of the altar, from a depth of 6 to 8 feet; and yet a tenth on the 1st of December between 1 and 2 after midnight, in the interior of the choir, near the door; from a place that had more than twelve feet of depth. An eleventh and a twelfth then came still on the 22nd of January, and were drawn to the light from a depth of more than 7 feet, directly under the image of the Holy Virgin in her chapel,

The possessed now spoke with wonder, concerning all these magic instruments, those who had indicated their place even before they were found, circumstantially of their composition, of the inscriptions under which they had been fabricated on the Sabbath; they gave all their components, the ligatures and knots applied to them, the letters with which they were marked, and all other circumstances, without ever erring in the smallest detail. Before one began to dig, they designated some spot on the floor, and indicated: directly perpendicular beneath it, in a depth of 6 to 7, 8 to 9 up to 12 feet, the magic lay. One proceeded accordingly in digging, and always found it at the spot indicated by the exorcism. They stated: some were marked with the letters M. P. and M. B., the names of Picard and of Bavent; they testified that at a certain place lay the testament of David and Picard written in the Arabic language of the Sabbath; and everything was found exactly at the place they had indicated. In all these things deception lay very near, and it is obvious that all these results are utterly worthless, if one did not employ all prudence to exclude the possibility of fraud. Let us see how it was handled in this regard. The next suspicion that had to arise was naturally: that the possessed, who descended into the pit to bring the hidden thing to light, had themselves carried it down with them. The appeal to their simplicity, education, and conscientiousness could here give no sure guarantee; because all that became invalid in the paroxysm. Therefore, before they descended into the pit, for greater security, they were most strictly searched by other sensible, prudent nuns of good judgment, and moreover unmolested by the spirits. With them other thoughtful persons, clerics and doctors, descended into the trench, who kept them sharply under watch, and never permitted them to come near the place where the amulets were hidden. One was accustomed to give the searchers a pole with a hook into their hand; and all had to remain at a distance from the spot as far as the pole reached, and to bring the magic to light from there with the point of the hook.

More than that, the edge of the trench was lined with other people who paid very close attention to the hands and all the movements of the possessed woman, and who would not easily have missed any practiced deception. It was advantageous that the time of discovery always fell at night; for now many torches were lit, which, properly distributed, mutually dispelled all shadows on the walls of the pit; so that everything stood in full light, which would not have been achievable by day. The Bishop of Embrun, who was present everywhere, moreover had the Most Blessed Sacrament held over the heads of the exorcised possessed woman in the pit at the decisive moment; in order to strike down any deceit also through the terrors of sacrilege. Skepticism now had to yield to the evidence of the facts, and the commissioners, sent on behalf of the queen and the council of state, with the Archbishop of Toulouse at their head, issued an authentic testimony as to with what caution and deliberation the proceedings had been conducted in their presence; how they had placed the searching nun between them, and how the paper, white and intact at the first finding, had become moldy, dissolved, and dirty under their eyes.

And yet, despite all this praiseworthy caution, deceptions may have slipped in among them; not exactly such as were consciously devised and carried out by the girls, but begun in the paroxysm under the impulsion of the power possessing them, and completed with the skill that then entered in. All this was said so beautifully and compellingly that I cannot reproduce it, yet some apprehension always lingered in the background for me; so that when he demanded a pledge of fidelity from me, I always replied: "If God so wills!" or: "I have placed God in full possession of my heart!"

The next day, after Communion, a great dryness had come over me, and I complained of it to him. In the evening, the confessor had me summoned to the speaking grille; I went with reluctance. When I appeared, he asked me: how things stood with me, and what was passing within me? I answered: things stood well, and only good passed within me! He, in turn: "So something is indeed passing in you, and I want to know what it is!" "Jesus! my father," I said, "if something were passing between God and me, I would be bound to disclose it! For the left hand should know nothing of the good that the right hand does." He now commanded me, upon holy obedience, to tell him what I wished to conceal; and I said: nothing except that I had come to a full indifference toward all creatures. He found this well done, but warned me to be on my guard; lest under the pretext of the good I be led into evil. "But," I said, "my father! is there something in my behavior that perhaps arouses suspicion?" "I have no suspicion," was the reply, "but rather fear of deception; your fainting spells after holy Communion, the sadness on your face, your silence about the state of your conscience for fifteen days or three weeks, make me believe that something is the matter with you." "Truly!" I replied, "for some time now I have been withdrawing from men, because true consolation is only with God; from men, however, only hindrance comes." I looked at him without saying a word, for I did not know what I should do; but I thought to myself: this is a temptation, for I have today pledged fidelity and silence. He, noticing my uncertainty, said: I see well that you do have something to share with me after all! No, I replied, I am only pondering the words I have heard, and at the same time I rose to leave. I kept looking at him, and said once more: Farewell, my father! I am going now. He called me back yet again: My daughter! one more little word; come closer, I will tell it to you softly. I approached the speaking grille, and he gently took hold of the cord with which I was girded, and said to me: I see clearly that you have something to share with me; I will not let you go now until you have spoken the word to me, even if I should not depart from here until tomorrow! \[Page 213\]

I was greatly astonished, and said: It is true, my father! something extraordinary is taking place between me and my good angel. God imparts many graces to me through him; but I cannot speak of all this, because I have pledged fidelity and silence, and I fear otherwise to lose the consolation of his visits. The confessor replied to these words: In truth, my daughter! this angel is the devil himself! An immense trembling seized my whole body, my teeth chattered against each other so that I could not speak. The confessor spoke prayers and exorcisms over me, and in the end had to summon the worthy mother to my assistance. The trembling lasted perhaps half an hour; when it had passed, the father wanted me to abjure all the words of agreement and affection that I might have spoken. I replied: as I renounce everything that I might have said contrary to God's will. I, when I was alone, spoke words of courage to myself, and when all in the convent had become quiet, he came in his clarity; but with an expression of such raging anger as if he wished to destroy me. He reproached me as unfaithful, ungrateful, wretched; I knew not what misfortune awaited me; only repentance and a solemn vow of greater fidelity for the future could save me. He looked at me with a piercing, loving gaze: Promise me, he cried, only better fidelity for the future, and I will forgive your weakness! I felt a great tenderness toward him, but at the same time a fear of giving my consent, and without answering, I turned to the other side. But he immediately turned me back, and said: What is this, my daughter? How changed you are! Do you not wish me to take possession of your heart? I replied: This heart belongs to God alone; I do not regret what I did earlier in the confessional. If you are from God, then it will also be pleasing to you; but if you wish to remove all suspicion from me, appear before the confessor at the speaking grille in your full clarity, and reveal to him what you have undertaken for my guidance. If he approves everything and declares you to be an angel of God, then I promise you unwavering fidelity; if not, then leave off from me, unworthy as I am. \[Page 214\]

With every word that I spoke, the expression on his face changed; at last he became furious, and losing all composure, he said: Wretch! Is this the fulfillment of your promise from yesterday? What have you noticed in me since then that is hateful to God? I see, I have shown you too much love, you have turned the medicine into poison; once more, do not force me, after so much mildness, to turn to severity against you! Wier, whose testimony as a physician and Protestant one may here allow to stand,¹ even if he had the weakness of believing in the devil, has recorded several other cases of this kind from his own experience. In the convent of Kentorp, in the county of Mark not far from Hamm, the enclosed nuns, noblewomen as well as others, were seized by a possession; and the individuals in various ways, some more violently, others more mildly, tormented. In this variety, however, there was one thing common to all: that as soon as one was seized by an attack, all the others, even if they were in completely separate rooms, as soon as they heard the noise, were likewise drawn into it and miserably plagued. Anna Lemgon was one of the older and stout-hearted sisters who clearly explained to the physician Wier the circumstances of the whole evil. It began with her, who was one of the first seized, with pains in the left hypochondrium; she was held to be seized by epilepsy, and was sent to the convent of Nonnery so that she might drink from the skull of the holy Cornelius; she did so, and the nuns now falsely said that she was better. \[Page 244\]

But when she was soon more violently visited by the evil, and other nuns were likewise found drawn into it; a soothsayer was consulted, who gave testimony against the convent's cook as the originator of the evil. Now the malignancy of the plague increased; the convulsions became more manifold and more deeply cutting, and the seized were driven to bite one another, and so also other strangers, to strike and throw down; yet without further harm, since they seemed to themselves as light as feathers, and now noticed that they were not masters of themselves. If they were held back from striking or the other acts of violence, they were pressed in the heart; but if they were let loose again, they felt, even if they injured or bit themselves, no evil at all; so that it seemed as if it had become a necessity for them to rage against their own bodies. If Anna gave herself to prayer, she could by no means follow it with attention or move her tongue for it; but if she merely chattered off her hours thoughtlessly, then she was in no way hindered from it; it rather seemed to her as if she were thereby relieved and refreshed.

She could not think seriously about any good or evil matter; it seemed to her then as if she were stupid in spirit, without sense, without distinction, and without judgment. If a religious, God-consecrated man addressed her, she was as it were scolded by the devil on that account; but if she spoke with this one, or with another female person, about vain and trivial things, then she was wonderfully uplifted and exalted thereby. Although all were plagued in manifold ways, they were nevertheless all of good appetite, and the nourishment proceeded well. From here the malady now soon spread also to the nearby city of Hamm, afflicting not a few citizens of this city with various torments. When they were instructed by the pastor of the place in his room, and he had them recite the Ten Commandments, the Creed, and the Lord's Prayer; they began to question one another, and the demons now named themselves with jesting names, as one said: he was called Flederwisch, another Flatfoot, the third Rosenbaum; but he who now wrought mischief in the monastery at Kentorp named himself Hornuar.

At last one asked: The pastor wants to drive us out; what shall we do now? The other replied: I will ride on a black buck to that woman whom he named; I shall be a dear guest to her. The other said: he would go with the same conveyance to a second one. Both, sitting backward on chairs like fools, now seemed, as gesture and voice indicated, to ride to the aforementioned places; without, however, having moved from the spot. A third, rolled and drawn together like a ball, rushed toward the closed door; and as this was suddenly opened, he fell down the stairs, but entirely unharmed. In the place Houel near Hamm, likewise many possessed persons came to light. Also in another neighboring city the inhabitants were seized by similar attacks and plagues, on account of which many investigations arose there against individuals. As in this case the manifestation of possession often hovers midway between malice and jest; so the contagion that produced it hovers between a moral and a physical one. \[Page 245\]

Something over a hundred years later, in the orphanage of Hoorn in 1670, something quite similar occurred. At that time in this house there was a very large number of children, --- both boys and girls, older and younger, but none under twelve years, and mostly all of the most unruly sort ---, afflicted for several months with a severe plague; on account of which many doctors were consulted, who did not know what to make of the matter. \[Page 249\]

But the plague consisted in this: that the aforementioned children suddenly and unexpectedly fell to the ground, and as soon as they came to themselves, they were pulled and torn with such force that it was unbearable to witness: how they trampled with their legs, knocked their heads against the earth, struck about with their arms, gnashed their teeth, and howled and barked like dogs. In some, the belly rose and fell so violently that it seemed as if a living creature sat within it, which was moving; or as if little barrels were being rolled about in their bodies. They then had to be held by three, four, five, or sometimes even by six people; of whom one held the head, two others the hands, one sat on the legs, and sometimes a fourth had to press down the belly. When they lay still, they were stiff and rigid like wood; so that if one grasped them only by the head and the feet, one could carry them wherever one wished, without their making the slightest movement. This often lasted for several hours in succession, even into the night until twelve, one, or two o'clock.

One of them, the daughter of Tryn Lucas, one of the oldest orphans in the house, was seized by the plague early in the morning around eight, when the morning bell rang for breakfast. The attack lasted without any interruption until four in the afternoon, when the bell rang again for vespers. The sick girl thought, when she came to herself again, that she had only lain in the attack for a short time, because she believed she heard the morning bell ringing once more. These attacks most often came upon the children when they saw others seized by it; or also when they merely heard someone in the plague gnashing their teeth, or howling and barking. Some therefore were accustomed to run away at once, but mostly in vain; unless they happened to be near the gate and could leave the house. Thus, through hearing and seeing, so many often contracted it that there was scarcely enough household staff to be found to help them. Secondly, it also fell upon them very frequently, and almost always, during spiritual exercises, for example under the sermon, from which they therefore had to be kept away; then during the catechetical instruction, which the preachers gave in the house from time to time; but most of all during the prayers, which were recited aloud by the assistant masters. \[Page 250\]

Bekker¹ tells it from his own experience, to be sure in his superficial, arbitrarily rational manner; but nevertheless circumstantially enough to serve our purpose. A young man, about 16 years old, of dull comprehension, mentally and physically not of particular drive or vigor, had become conspicuous to his fellow pupils: through the strange gestures, eye-rollings and contortions of his body, which manifested themselves in him. He had let them eat ripe cherries in the middle of winter; and after first offering them to them, he had then eaten them himself. In the church he had shown them his empty hands, and then taken money from the pews, and asserted: that he did all this with the help of an evil spirit, which he called Serug. \[Page 257\]

They had once caught him at it, how he had drawn a circle with chalk in the school, and described it with some figures and numbers, which Bekker had seen. On being asked: what does that mean? he had stood long silent and still, and blinked with his eyes; but finally confessed: that he had drawn it to speak with him through it. Likewise, when asked: how he had come by the cherries and the money? he had replied, that he had given it to him. Asked: who this he might be? he had, blinking again and looking in front of him, named Beelzebub. Into a hole in the wall, which according to the rector's deputy was much too small to admit his hand, he had nevertheless thrust it in, and upon pulling it out had torn a stone along with it. More sharply questioned, he explained: that the spirit sometimes appeared to him, now agreeably as a maiden, now repulsively as a goat; that it had happened to him for the first time in Leeuwarden, where money for playing had been lacking to him, and that he had given him a handwriting.

The school authorities resolved to exclude him from it, and to inform the parents of the matter; who now agreed upon it, to keep him at home. A maid watched over him during the day, wherever he went and stood; at night he slept with his brother, who was a clever man, and entirely capable for this guardianship. They prayed for him in the church; the maid was accustomed to seat him in front of the pulpit, where he was exposed to the eyes of many people as well as the preacher. There he would then sit stiffly looking in front of him, often blinking, more frequently shaking with his feet, like one who is freezing, and suffering from a twitching of the sinews, as epileptics are wont to have; without, however, ever having fallen in the church.

The maid knew much to tell about him, but this rested only on her belief; because the father, who loved solitude, mostly remained in his chamber; but the mother, although very sensible and attentive, was very burdened with bodily weakness. He presented himself to Bekker as if he felt remorse and sorrow, but took no heart toward the one who scolded him more often; for which reason this one henceforth spoke more kindly with him, and once took him, with the prior knowledge of the parents, on a walk; after having previously bought him some sweets for him, with which, as he very well knew, his trust was most easily to be gained. He now told him on this walk: how his spirit Serug still kept him company, and spoke invisibly with him in various shapes; and that he, in order not to be tormented, still sometimes yielded to him in evil.

He wanted to lure him out continually, and although he had little desire for it, he had nevertheless been very well entertained by him twice at special places: first in the little house by the gallows at Leeuwarden, which then transformed into a beautiful hall; and then in Franeker, on the first piece of pastureland that lies northward from the road by the city moat. There was a pit there, which, except on the hottest summer days, is otherwise mostly full of water; that pit had suddenly dried up at that time, and been full of fiery flames. In it many devils had been flying about, who declared that hell indeed had such a fire as well; but they knew how to render it harmless. To a company of men and women who had been there, splendid fare had been served; there had also been music, dancing, and games. \[Page 258\]

People had spoken Hebrew there; a language which he understood as well as his mother tongue, but outside the assembly not at all. He named those present, among others a woman from Leeuwarden who already had a reputation for this. At night, after he had slept a little, his spirit would make him rise; and lead him along a height which he never saw by day, to that place. Once he had brought him to the sea dike at Harlingen, and made him thrust through two men with the sword that he had placed in his hand. Bekker asked: whether he remembered any Hebrew word at all? He said: Yes, one, "alley," which I use when I want to call him. Bekker replied: that is no Hebrew word, and wrote for him on a small coin the words: *Soer nimmenin Satan! Depart from me, Satan!* with the instruction: to ask the devil about the meaning of the words; and instead of the few shillings that he always used to give him, to demand from him a Hungarian double ducat.

He later reported back: that he had shown the words to the devil, and he had told him that they meant: he should go away from him; but the double ducat he had promised him if he would only first go out; but that he had neither been able nor willing to do. His parents had told Bekker that he sometimes fell into a faint, and then told much about the places where he had been. He asked to be called if it happened again, and now found him once lying flat on the ground, rolling about on it; holding his eyes now closed, now stiffly open; his body mostly drawn together, and in violent motion. After that he came to himself again, and began to speak weakly, but gave little account, except that he was better; though later on he knew how to tell much again.

Once around the summer solstice, when his brother awoke early in the morning, he saw him lying next to him in bed; with closed eyes in sleep, making all the movements of the mouth, the hands, and the body like one who greedily eats and drinks there. He named now the name of Serug, now of another spirit; and demanded this and that from one or the other tree. He then acted like one who receives something and bites into it; he praised the same and laughed, as if it tasted good to him. Finally, when he received something that did not taste good to him, he scolded his spirit vehemently, something like with the words: Now you deceive me again, and give me what you well know that I do not want at all! With that he drew back, and struck with the flat of his hand so forcefully that a mark of it could be seen on the wall, and from the rebound of it he half awoke. Only when he parted from the meal in the pleasure garden did he clearly make the gesture of taking off the garments that he had received there; and that he had to leave behind, in order to go home in his own clothes. Her mother had therefore summoned a known sorcerer to her. He had examined the matter, declared her bewitched, rubbed tree bark, and herbs incantated with words, and administered them to her in a cup; finally, he also gave her a bite in the arm. The woman now partook of her ailment, but from that time on it was as if needles were pressing out from her heart from time to time. She then suffered violent pains, until through the bite in the arm---which did not scar over---needles were driven forth by a secret force. More than thirty of them had thus emerged one after another; when a famous abbot, whom Gaufried, because he was still alive, hesitates to name, passed by on his way, and under the hospitable roof of the father was received, saw the sick woman, and heard her misery recounted by the distressed father.

It was soon pushed further forward, and now a lay brother in the abbot's retinue approached, grasped the protruding one, and drew it out bloody, to preserve it for all time to come as a witness to what had occurred. the hard objects in the lower abdomen before the vomiting. In more recent times something similar happened with Maria von Mörk in Caltern; at that time, when the conflict within her had not yet been resolved, she too had to endure this temptation.

She began on July 25, 1832, with an unnatural cheerfulness, which, except for the communion days, otherwise continued uninterrupted until the middle of September. In this state she committed various foolish acts, no longer called even her best acquaintances by their names, gnawed with great haste at her own hands as well as at those of others; and wept when one tried to deny it to her. From time to time she would then cry out in the midst of this frenzy: O my God! O, what misery is this! When she came to herself again in lucid intervals, she knew nothing of what she had said and done; and when her siblings made her aware of it, at most a dim recollection of it would dawn on her, and she showed herself extremely dismayed by it. \[Page 264\]

This agitation, whose focal point, as the gnawing reveals, had been in the plexuses of the stomach region, had entered only in the company of a new affliction, which had begun on the same day. For on the aforementioned day, one first noticed in her mouth lumps or pins and other similar things; on which she bit vigorously, and which she gave up again only after long efforts. This phenomenon repeated itself daily in frightful manner two to three times, and continued for eight long weeks until the middle of September. Pins, needles, spirally twisted wires, pieces of glass, horsehairs, nails of all kinds came forth one after another. Most came out of the mouth, following a stabbing pain that she felt in her entrails; whereupon these objects were immediately vomited up amid violent convulsions. The confessor, dismayed by these events, could scarcely bring himself to credit the evidence of his eyes; he therefore reported what had occurred to the parish priest of the place at that time, Mr. Eberl. This man had visited her more often earlier; her appearance had never led him to suspect any unusual state that had come over her.

When, therefore, the occurrence was reported to him, he must have felt struck by the communication; and, as was natural, he expressed his doubts about the truth of the strange things, and how perhaps some deception might have crept in. When it was replied in the meantime that similar doubts had also arisen earlier with the confessor, but that he had been compelled to yield before the evidence of the facts; he went there to take insight into the event himself. He found the afflicted one in violent convulsions; she threw herself, when the crisis approached, backward over the pillows; and since her mouth stood open thereby, one could easily see deep down into the gullet. The priest now had more than one opportunity to observe how the objects were driven up in it, sometimes placing themselves crosswise, resisting the expulsion; and gradually forced higher and higher up, finally entering the mouth, and then, as if blown out by a wind, being expelled.

Initially fearful, he soon gathered courage at the confessor's urging; and whenever he again caught sight of such objects---needles, nails, or pieces of wood---he reached into the gullet and drew them out deeply, so that any possibility of deception was entirely ruled out. To this day he still preserves many of the things that he thus helped bring to light.¹ Not only through the mouth did these objects leave her, but also through the lower passages; under great pain, the sharp things---as she called them in the local dialect---were expelled from her; and one could hear them, if metallic, clinking as they fell below. In the same way, similar objects emerged externally from her after she had felt the pain in her side or elsewhere, when she straightened up, as if they had forced their way through her skin. \[Page 265\]

In May of that year, a paralysis had set in at her left foot, so that she could not move it. In the following September, finally, a board nail more than three inches long worked its way through the skin of her leg, and the limb immediately regained its former flexibility. The same happened sometimes at the back between the shoulder blades; at other times, however, also at the head, where they opened a way out for themselves. It was remarkable in this that the straight pins did not advance, as would have been the case if they had been introduced from outside, with their heads turned outward; rather, the points were turned outward, so that, since they sat fast and could only be grasped with force, the confessor and others often wounded themselves bloody before they managed to pull them out. All these sharp and injurious objects caused her no bleeding, and left no suppurating wound behind; except when one had injured her through incautious removal of them. But once they were finally removed, the sufferer regained control of herself and felt greatly relieved.

Along with this phenomenon, there was also another closely related one, that of the strange infestation of the bed. On the bedsheet, under it on the mattress, on the straw tick, needles, straw stems, nails, hairs, pieces of glass, and so forth were found; and scarcely had the bed been cleaned when, sometimes in the presence of the very same persons who had removed the earlier objects, quite similar ones appeared in the same place, and the cleaning had to be repeated. As long as these bed infestations were around her, the sufferer found herself in such agitation and mental confusion that she not infrequently cried out with a distorted face, flashing eyes, and protruding tongue: she wanted to kill herself; she was damned anyway, she wanted to go with the men who were turning her bed topsy-turvy. Immediately afterward she would complain again of painful stinging in the eyes, in the lower body, on the chest; she howled and cried miserably, often tore out whole handfuls of hair, and wanted to jump violently from the bed out the window. It is noteworthy that the maids who made the bed never found the mentioned infestations; except when the confessor was present in the room. He had, as was natural, taken all precautions, as far as it was at all feasible, to keep such objects---as are usually found in the sweepings---away from her. All the women who approached her had been instructed to pay close attention to needles and whatever similar things they carried on them. But all caution proved useless; the things gathered around her, as if drawn to her. One day, as they were just cleaning the bed again, Marie suddenly began to tremble and called out quivering: Oh! Oh! The confessor asked: what was the matter?

Oh, she replied, now something ugly and large is coming and wants to get into my bed. In fact, one heard how something from the next room, continually striking against the floor, clattered through the open door toward the bed standing close by it. The confessor commanded: Seize it in the name of Jesus, and hand it here! Oh, she cried, it is already running away again, and now it is going into the next room! One of the girls present had the courage to follow it there and pick it up; and there it was found to be a piece of hard wood that had been wrapped with human hair, alternately striking the floor with one end and the other, thus coming along. \[Page 266\]

The confessor, dismayed by all these occurrences, inquired in many ways: how it could be that these strange objects came to her in this manner, and even pressed into her body; but she could give no definite information about it. She said: sometimes it seemed to her as if they entered through the eyes, sometimes again through the mouth; it also seemed to her at times as if they were thrown up against her breast and throat by a little man. Only this one thing was certain, and she maintained the same for a long time afterward: that each time abominable men of dark form surrounded her, and offered and presented to her shapes of various enjoyable objects and delicacies, chestnuts, pastries, and confections. Then she lusted after what was offered, and it was immediately forced upon her by the men; whereupon always violent stabbing and cutting pains would set in, until all that stuff was removed from the body again.

The whole matter had been sought to be concealed as much as possible on account of the sensation; but it came out nevertheless, at least in part, and the strangeness that lay in the entire occurrence made people suspicious; they suspected witchcraft and evil arts, and many who had previously wished well to the afflicted one withdrew from her. Therefore the confessor said to her one day: You see, Marie! how all these hideous things lead people astray; therefore turn yourself in fervent prayer to God, that he may take the plague from you. She promised to do as he had said; and then after some time, when she had gone to holy communion around the middle of September, she said: The Lord has said: I am to have the general prayer held for me in a church, then the torments will cease. The most instructive thing that has occurred in this way is what at the end of the sixteenth century took place in the Upper Palatinate. On 20 November 1694, the twelve-year-old son Theodor of the pastor Z. Döderlin there, at the church of Berolzheim near Weissenburg am Sand, had begun to complain of headache and stomach ache, with complete loss of appetite; but the mother, who believed he had perhaps eaten something harmful while playing in the garden, had given him a home remedy, which however on the following day had only produced vomiting and stool, with the expulsion of some worms.

It took another six days of all sorts of remedies to still the vomiting; but since fainting fits, heart palpitations, and epileptic convulsions followed, they called in the physician from Weissenburg, Dr. Wider, for counsel; who advised on worms, and prescribed helminthogogic remedies, mixed with stomach-strengthening and anti-epileptic ones. These too were applied fruitlessly for a whole month, and the symptoms of the illness multiplied; they therefore discontinued the medicines, and resorted only to a bloodletting, after which the patient's strength increased somewhat, and only the vomiting persisted. Wider therefore prescribed, on the 5th of January 1695, pills against it once more, as well as against the worms; whereupon the boy for the first time began to feel a large worm in his intestines, and on the 2nd became so deranged that it seemed his end was at hand. But when he came to himself again, he filled the house with weeping and lamenting, threw himself from the bed onto a bench, and rolled about on it, continually crying out that the worm would kill him with its bites. They gave him all manner of things, especially garlic juice, after which the worm ceased biting, and the boy stopped his wailing. The doctor prescribed what was fitting, but the worm proceeded once more to bite, now on the right side, now on the left; and the boy rolled about screaming again, and the pain nearly drove him to madness. \[Page 273\]

This continued for so long, until someone advised soothing the creature with milk; it then indeed desisted from biting, but was by no means thereby expelled. They immediately administered suitable medicines, of which, however, only the Marrubium album drove a millipede out through the stool. Since the tartar emetic weakened the boy immensely, he was conveyed under medical care to Weissenburg, where quicksilver and the decoction of Hypericum procured him three days of rest; but upon that the worm, ascending as far as the pit of the stomach, began once more to stir most violently. Only by means of milk could it be pacified; with bitter drinks it bit furiously about. Abstinence from food and drink brought on labored breathing, swelling of the face, and choking fits. They administered such violent purgatives that it seemed either the boy or the worm must succumb to them; all to no avail. They were therefore obliged to resolve on sending him back again to his parents. In the meantime, someone had made the proposal to the despairing ones, to assist the patient against the worm with warm cloths, and this proved effective: they could drive it or lure it backwards or forwards with them; it came sometimes as far as the gullet, and had to be repelled with vinegar.

From that time onward the boy could retain the foods that pleased the creature; the others, however, it cast back from the gullet. They obtained the judgment of the medical faculty at Altdorf; who, since medicines would not avail, proposed a dissection to be performed by a skilled hand; and since this did not seem agreeable, the most renowned physicians in Nuremberg, Augsburg, Frankfurt, Oettingen, and Switzerland were consulted, but their counsel remained wholly without effect. Full three hundred times a day the worm ascended into the throat; the belly meanwhile swelled enormously from sundry creatures, which from time to time could be felt externally; but these always remained below, while that one alone mounted upward. They placed the boy on his head, and had him inhale the vapor of milk. The worm, following after the milk, came up so far that it became visible to those standing by, but could nevertheless never be drawn forth; only another millipede was expelled. Only before the Marrubium album did the creature show aversion; its decoction always drove it from the stomach into the intestines, under great pains to the boy; which pains endured until it had reached the lowest bowels. But when it was just on the point of being expelled from there, it suddenly mounted back up to the stomach, and celebrated its happy return with some merry leaps. \[Page 274\]

It was equally sensitive to heat; a burning wax candle, the flame from the stove, the rubbing with warm cloths drove it to flight; and it immediately rolled itself into a lump, in which one could feel a movement like that of vipers. If one brought an even hotter cloth near, it fled to another corner. When the abdomen swelled, which happened several times daily, then the strongest man could not press it down; but as soon as someone pressed the head of the worm with a finger, the others, all of them smaller, fled to another place. Rue was so hateful to them that, if the boy smelled it, ate it, or laid it on the abdomen, they were all thrown into great rage and agitation. They likewise abhorred radish, vinegar, and everything bitter; but the sweet was exceedingly pleasant to them, and the scent of a musk ball made the larger worm leap up perhaps a hundred times in a quarter of an hour. From then on, however, he abated somewhat in his wildness; for although he climbed up into the throat more than a thousand times every day, and each time had to be removed by swallowing, whereby the noise he made could be heard a hundred paces away; yet he bit only when provoked to anger, and then only lightly.

Now one of those folk healers appeared, of the kind that the faculty is wont to call medicaster, who advised removing the bitter, but recommended sweet and fatty things.
