Namely: 162 larger and smaller centipedes, ten or twenty at a time; two moths; a white worm with a black head, while a similar one bored into the navel; four fast-running worms, each with twenty stinger-bearing feet; four hopping butterflies; four other swiftly moving red maggots resembling large ants; a white centipede; 42 dark-colored caterpillars of various sizes; finally, a full-grown beetle. Not all emerged through the mouth, but some crawled along the palate to the ethmoid bone, and were then driven out through the nose with a warm cloth. They were all very lively and so nimble that, if one did not catch them immediately, they soon ran away. They did not come mixed together, but the like kinds appeared together; the smaller insects were surrounded by the four larger ones, and by some smaller earthworms, as if by a dam; and some of them lived 3, 8, up to 12 days, until they finally starved to death.

The parents joyfully considered the boy already freed; but on March 26 an interlude occurred that led them to conclude it was sorcery. As the other children were playing in the garden on March 26, they found in a new bird's nest a white bird's egg painted with red figures; but when they opened it to eat, the yolk was black and sprinkled as if with gunpowder. For this reason they threw it against the fence and washed their hands; but as the parents and neighbors now came running up because of the novelty of the thing, suddenly a rooster fell down dead; two hens, however, were seized with convulsions, and on the following day the crossroads in the garden was found sprinkled with a black powder. That incompetent doctor now had the boy's abdomen covered with plasters, gave him all sorts of things unceasingly, and had the belly bound and pressed upward. Now, from that day until the end of May, four frogs of medium size were driven out from the boy's mouth, by applying stinking things from below but sweet ones from above; one of which had a beetle, a mealworm, and a frog in its stomach, the second slime, but the other two nothing in their stomachs. When the first one had been expelled, some friends advised: to bring the boy at night to the fish pond, where there were many frogs; in the hope that, if he still had more inside him, these might perhaps be lured out by sympathy with those in the pond. \[Page 275\]

Scarcely had he, however, come near the pond, when his belly swelled beyond measure. The worm, which for several weeks had not bitten, now began again its old cruel game, and rose up in the following days perhaps a thousand times; but the frogs in the boy's body answered those outside with the same croaking and the same motion; so that, on account of the uproar in his body, the boy from then on never again dared to go out at the time when the frogs croaked. After the expulsion of the frogs followed some toads, then 21 lizards of various sizes; the frogs as well as the toads were lively in color, and of different kinds. The larger span-long toad killed the smaller one at once with her breath, and filled perhaps a glass with her slime, which she then swallowed up again. Before the separation of all these animals went a feverish chill, followed by a tickling in the throat. Then the animals were vomited up lengthwise, without particular pain.

The last lizard was covered with a piece of skin from another dead one. It was now believed that the great worm too had in some way departed. But when the boy, after his daily prayer, went to bed again, which he had shunned for two days out of fear, and now fell asleep easily; he suddenly raised himself up, and cried: something bitter had flowed into his throat, from which his lower belly was swelling; at the same time the worm began to rage again. Since the insect nest was now destroyed, it ran up and down freely and as if in a fury, and bit most violently at the slightest movement of the boy. Whether it had been vomited up and returned, or had remained, had to remain undecided.

But when on the 9th of June friends who visited the boy brought him confections, the creature was thereby lured several times into his throat; and caused him such distress that he lay down on a cushion of the bench by the window in the sun; and there, holding a piece of confection in his hand, he became a little beside himself. The creature, lured by the sweetness, now sprang forth; to those present it seemed a viper, and the boy's body fell together at once. The housemates searched most eagerly for the viper in all corners for a whole hour, but could not find it. So that it might not slip into the boy's mouth again, it was resolved to convey him over to the house of a trusted neighbor; where he remained for eight days sound and cheerful. Meanwhile, some remedies were provided to the boy by a respectable person, which were supposed to be particularly salutary against sorcery: a water, a powder for fumigating, another with an oil to rinse the mouth, and an amulet. At the same time the remedies of the unqualified doctor were continued, and now the boy vomited up, from the 17th to the 21st of June, some shoe nails, half of a chain ring, seven pieces of bowls, stones among which two quite large ones, a ball of hair, pieces of white and red eggshells, two forks one of which was wound around with hair, a piece of a medicine glass, finally two large nails.

At all these things, as at the departure of the animals, were present the collector Knebel, the pastor of Trommetsheim, and many other most credible people. All the objects came singly, under sometimes hours-long exertions; which at the forks were so great that they produced an exceedingly strong hoarseness. The boy now felt nothing more, and the parents resolved to take him home again; but they placed him in another room, and he slept with a relative who watched over him the whole night until six o'clock in the morning. \[Page 276\]

Shortly after she had fallen asleep, the viper returned, however, to the horror of all. Since they applied triple doses of the medicine and manifold prayers, she soon departed again in that light ecstasy which overtakes the severely exhausted; after she had previously bitten his foot, so that he came to from it, and ran screaming into the father's study, showing the swollen foot and calling for help. Some theriac and the anointing with scorpion oil soon restored him, so that his parents took him to church on Sunday. But as he was on the stairs, from the lower story to the upper, the viper pursued him again; so that he hurriedly slammed the door of the upper hallway behind him and cried for help. Trembling as he was, he therefore could not be let out of sight the entire day; during which he then, in the evening, expelled one of the forks from himself. He spent the night in the house of C. Bambrucker, under the watch of his grandmother and constant prayer, peacefully. But early in the morning at 6 o'clock, he felt the viper in his body again, and one could plainly hear it hissing.

He was therefore brought home once more; the grandmother, who constantly remained at his bedside, did not take her eyes off him, in case she might see the creature at its exit. In vain, however---as soon as sleep and that kind of ecstasy came over the boy, it had gone out for the fourth time, and bit him so fiercely in the hand that the blood began to flow from it. The author of the *Specimens of British Prose Writers*, Barnett, relates an example of this from his own experience. Fifty years ago there lived in a village of Somersetshire an old woman who was generally regarded as a hag. Her body was dry, bent by age she went about on crutches. Her voice was hollow, of a mysterious but hypocritical solemnity; from her eyes went forth a piercing, stinging light that struck the one who looked at her with silent terror. \[Page 286\]

Suddenly a young, healthy man of 21--22 years from the same place was haunted by the Alp; so persistently and frequently that his health was attacked by it, and within 3--4 months he was weak, pale, emaciated, bearing all the signs of a life drawing to its end. Neither he nor any of his family had any doubt about the cause; and as he was resolved, he decided to wait for the hag while awake. For a long time he did not succeed in this; finally his resolution prevailed, and he now heard at midnight a soft, cautious step on the stairs. She came to the foot of the bed, climbed onto it, and then pressed herself slowly up along his feet. He let it happen until she had come to his knees and wanted to throw herself upon him with her full weight.

Now he seized her with both hands by the hair and held her fast with convulsive strength, while at the same time calling out to his mother, who was sleeping in the nearby room, that she should bring a light. While she ran for the light, the two of them struggled with each other in fury on the floor, for so long until, with the first glimmer from the stairs, the woman tore herself from his fists with supernatural force and vanished from his eyes like a flash of lightning. His mother found him standing there, still breathless from the exertion, holding both hands full of hair. When he, says Barnelt, recounted the incident to me, I asked him curiously where he had put the hair. He replied: It was clumsy of me that I did not keep it; that would have proven the identity of the person best. But in the storm of my emotions, I let it fall to the ground; and she to whom it belonged took care that it never came before my eyes again. But on that occasion I covered it over in such a way that she has not returned since to plague me. It is strange, he added, that while I seized her and wrestled with her, although I was certain that it must be she, yet her breath and her entire being seemed like that of a blooming young girl. The man to whom this happened still lives; he told me the story more than once; I can therefore vouch for the truth of the effect, whatever one may think of the cause.

She replied: she had already done so many times, and received various answers; later, however, agreeing, she had, in order to withdraw herself again from this promise, spent 15 days outside the house with a friend.

Lately urged once more to approach a bishop who was present at that place on this account; she had finally yielded, had gone to the bishop, and he had directed her to a Dominican, a pious, experienced man proven in the examination of spirits. But she would not follow this instruction; the father would demand a general confession from her, and also, to test her, would withhold communion from her for a long time; moreover, an inner voice had forbidden her to go to him. In the meantime she spoke various suspicious things again. She was without all sin, even without venial; God hearkens to her in all that she desires. She sees the inner man; God unites himself bodily with her, and she often falls into ecstasy outside herself. \[Page 292\]

She said to her hosts: they could attain the same if they would only renounce the imprint of evil with which they were born, and all high-mindedness and all vanity and discord. When it was replied to her: we do all that, she rejoined: You still have a veil before your eyes, I will pray to God that he remove it from you! Suerz now pressed all the more eagerly that she go to the father, with whom he had previously spoken, and she finally consented. He received her kindly; but she was at first somewhat abashed, and said nothing. The father then said: I have heard much of your rare virtues; I hope through you to gain closer knowledge of them for my own good. But she answered: I am a sinner; and to that he: That comes surely only from your humility; I hope you will not hide your graces from me. They are rare, these graces, on account of my sinfulness, said she; and he again: Your ecstasies and illuminations, the seeing through of spirits, the foresight, all that is well known to me; God does not grant such things to wicked people.

She now came two or three times out of herself before the father; he fell upon his knees and besought God for his help, and then he said to her: O blessed one, you who are so closely united with God, and enjoy his sacred embraces! She rejoined: In that you speak truly! So he spoke back and forth, and plainly recognized that she was exceedingly vain, thought greatly of herself, and had a mighty desire for praise and honor. He said to her now: It seems to me in all this that your humility yet deserves a higher reward; and it appears fitting to me that the body also should share in the enjoyment, as is the case with bride and bridegroom. By these words she was, as it were, transported out of herself, and said: You speak the truth, my father! and no one has yet spoken so aptly therein as you. The father then asked whether God was visible to her, how often and under what form he united himself with her.

She took pleasure in these questions, and said: she did not see her God, but felt him very well; she rejoiced for full two to three hours in his embraces, and gave things to understand that cannot well be repeated. The father said in response: It sometimes dreams to me that I come into company with many people; do you also have such dreams? She answered: Indeed! and when asked: what then the people did together? she replied: They worship God, eat and drink, and are in good spirits for two to four hours. She now went away very pleased, and promised to come again soon. They had been, says the physician, disturbed for many years by various devilish afflictions; when suddenly in the year 1564 a gruesome spectacle arose among them. They were thrown to the ground, entirely in the manner of the act; during the course of which they always kept their eyes closed, and only opened them afterward with great shame. A young girl of fourteen years, who had been enclosed in the cloister, had given the first occasion for it. She had often experienced these strange apparitions in her bed, and had been discovered by her giggling over them; and although she strove to ward off the haunting with a consecrated stole, it nevertheless returned every night. Likewise, in the neighboring domains of these realms, the magical emissions often occur. In the year 1589, there lived in Genoa a youth, who was otherwise well-formed, who suddenly burned with such fierce love toward a woman that he forgot God, and devoted himself only to this his passion. For three months, secret meetings and love letters were exchanged back and forth, until finally the youth fell ill with a violent sickness. Then it was astonishing, what and how manifold filth he spewed from himself in the presence of many witnesses: women's hair, egg shells, cotton, hair and straight pins, nail clippings and bone fragments, various iron scraps in no small number, all mixed with blood. One of the clerics, a Jesuit, exhorted him: that he should no longer allow himself to be bound by such a pernicious love affair; and finally questioned him, whether he perhaps possessed any belongings or letters from her? He confessed: that he had indeed received letters, but had torn them up.

The clergyman gave no credence to this assertion, and advised his own people to make search in his cabinets; and if they should find anything relating to the love affair, to take it away. As this matter became known to the patient through a secret voice, he demanded the key of the cabinet with terrible outcry: and when he had obtained it, he brought the same, at the exhortation of that same voice, to his mouth, to swallow it, if he had not been prevented therefrom. He then laid it under his pillow, and now lost the light of his eyes. The mother exhorted him that he, now made wise by experience, should give back the key. He therefore sought after it; but as he could not find it, he believed that it had been stolen from him; and he now began to scream and lament even more violently, as he searched the whole bed for it. Meanwhile, the cabinet had been broken open by force, and as two love letters were found in it, they were consigned to the flames; whereupon he immediately recovered the use of his sight, and saw the key lying before his eyes with astonishment. A case of this kind, of a poisoning turned inward through a philtre, which obtained a judicial investigation, is that which befell Maria Elisabeth de Ranfain, the daughter of a respectable house, of great beauty and even greater holiness, around the year 1622. Her parents had forced her into marriage, but after a few years her husband had died; a physician, Poiret, had now cast a violent passion upon her, and had given her such a philtre. She had felt its effect, but had suppressed it with prayers, tears, and vows. Poiret had now managed to administer a second one to her; various ills had thereupon afflicted her, and her parents had compelled her to send for Poiret; but as she distrusted him, she had dismissed him again. \[Page 301\]

This drove the physician out of his senses with rage; but Elisabeth soon fell into unnatural states. One half of her body showed itself stiffened in frost, and without sensation; while the other was in such violent agitations that, notwithstanding the delicacy of her constitution, four of the strongest persons could scarcely hold her. Now one saw her head (in the sutures of the skull) open itself, then close again to the astonishment of those present; while at another time it swelled up in a monstrous manner. The matter caused a sensation; the physician and his adherents spread about that it was all natural effects; consequences of the patient's cunning and confused imagination. Her bishop therefore had her brought to Nancy; six of the most renowned physicians of the city were called in; they examined the matter thoroughly, and at last gave their unanimous testimony to this effect: among the various symptoms of this illness there were some which could only take their origin in a principle foreign to nature.

The most insightful clergymen were now consulted by the bishop, and several respected bishops took part when the exorcism was applied. All declared unanimously: the patient was possessed by evil spirits, and only audacity could deny this truth. In fact, she was hurled into the heights with such violence that six persons could scarcely hold her down. She climbed in the trees, from branch to branch, with the ease of the nimblest animals. One saw her, entirely lifted into the air, turning herself about in a wondrous manner.

She fulfilled everything that was commanded unto her in the Italian, German, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew tongues, as we have already heard elsewhere; she read a sealed Latin letter, and pointed out the error of an omitted letter. Countless witnesses were present at all these proceedings. The clamor roundabout grew ever greater, the spirits of the sick testified continually against Poiret; this man at last made preparations for flight, whereupon Heinrich II of Lorraine, otherwise a mild regent, caused him to be arrested, and his trial to be instituted. The greatest caution and circumspection were observed in the matter. Magistrates, whom he had requested from France, joined with the natives to form a tribunal of ninety-four judges.

The accused found defenders; a doctor of theology wrote a book in his favor; a princess expended great sums for his liberation, and the Infanta of the Netherlands wrote on his account unto the Duke. The woman was not spared: she was accused of a hypocrisy at which the most shrewd wits would come to shame; whereupon her two daughters were also arrested, and she herself shut up on water and bread. All who took her part were slandered. A prince of Lorraine, who was a bishop, was to feed her secretly in his palace with dainties. What she did and said was twisted to the worst sense, she herself overwhelmed with every sort of indignity; her letters were broken open, and men wrote at their pleasure whatsoever they would into them; unknown persons pursued her with loaded pistols, but were disarmed in the decisive moment by a secret terror. In the morning rope ladders were found at her window, and footprints in the sand, and she was poisoned several times; a reward of a thousand pistoles, it was said, had been promised to whoever would kill her. \[Page 302\]

She therefore had to be guarded by watches. The prosecution meanwhile watched over her; the slanderous writings that were spread against her were refuted by the most thorough investigation of every action of her life; the exorcisms that the Duchess had instituted were at last continued at the instigation of the Bishop. The trial proceeded quietly on its course, and after the investigation had reached its goal, the 24 judges unanimously agreed upon the death sentence for Poiret. His friends managed to prevent the execution; the Sovereign ordered a new revision, with the same result; the judgment had to be carried out on April 1, 1622, and he died without showing any sign of remorse. When I was in 1567 at Poitiers, serving as substitute for the royal prosecutor at the great assizes, it happened that several gentlemen were accused before me. When I had now returned home and explained to my landlady the lawsuit in question, just as it had actually occurred---she being a respectable and well-regarded woman---she in turn recounted, as a highly experienced woman in matters of such arts, in the presence of the secretary Jakob von Beauvais, the following. First, that there were fully fifty kinds and manners of nestelknüpfen; one, by which one could bind a husband alone. The other, by which one could prevent begetting alone.

There would also be another kind whereby one loved the other, to be sure, but nothing was forbidden to it in the utmost degree; and another whereby they loved one another most fervently, but when they were to see one another, they would horribly scratch and strike each other. Of such a story it had been told in Toulouse concerning a couple who thus stood together for three years, then without having begotten children with one another. Moreover, the woman said that one could most easily hold back the man with it; indeed, one could hold him bound in impotence for a day, for a year, for all his lifetime, at least so long as the nestel remained entwined.

There would be people who could be entwined only for begetting, not for mingling; some for whom it would be impossible to effect the entwinement; others who would be susceptible to the matter only before marriage, not after it. She also recounted that one could knot people's urine, which she called nailing shut, from which many of them would then have to die. The aforementioned landlady of ours also told us all the particular sayings and words that belonged to each entwinement; which knotting spells were yet so indistinct and incomprehensibly twisted that neither a Greek, a Hebrew, a Latinist, nor anyone of the more recent nations could have understood them.

Piraitins in his eighth eclogue claims that one should make nine knots; she, however, knew only of one, and indicated of what leather and what color the knotting nestel must be. A striking example of this kind of progression, on a path leading swiftly downward, is Gilles de Laval, called de Rais, Marshal of France; who, of noble descent---from the houses of Laval, Roncy, Montmorency, Rais, and Craon---inherited vast estates; increased these still further through marriage with Catherine of Thouars; and thus became one of the richest landowners in the land, distinguishing himself not a little in the wars against the English at that time. At twenty years of age he had succeeded his father, and forthwith began a senseless extravagance. He maintained a guard of 200 men on horseback; a chapel of 25--30 persons; choirboys, musicians, chaplains had to follow him, along with a great number of other servants, everywhere on horseback, and for them, as for others, he always kept open table. Rich silver vessels, costly garments of gold brocade belonged to this chapel; a portable organ had to accompany the procession everywhere; his chaplains were called, as at cathedrals, deans, singers, archdeacons, scholasters, and one among them bore the title of bishop. \[Page 306\]

They were clothed in scarlet with ermine, had rich stipends, and he had several times petitioned the Pope for miters for them. At the same time he had mystery plays performed at great expense, or rather mysteries, as they were called then. He soon found those who fostered and encouraged his lusts in every way; besides many of lower rank, especially Gilles de Sillé and Roger de Briqueville. To cover his enormous expenditures, he naturally had to squander his estates below their value; and not one would have remained to him had not his relatives taken the matter in hand, procuring a royal prohibition against selling any further possession, and a prohibition from Parliament against anyone purchasing any. In this predicament he sought help from chemistry, which was to provide him the philosophers' stone; adepts soon appeared to him: quicksilver had already been fixed, but the philosophical egg broke before it could be hatched. He now sought help from the one reputed to be the possessor of all hidden treasures.

Trusted agents of this master also came to him; a physician from Poitou drew his circles in the forest; the Black One, as he said, had passed by him in the shape of a leopard; that he had remained silent was due to a fault in his preparations. He wished to return home to investigate more thoroughly; richly rewarded, he departed and did not return. A Florentine, Francesco Prelati, great alchemist and magician, took his place; and made use of a book from the Marshal's library. Later in prison he confessed how he had several times seen the demon in the shape of a young man of twenty years, who called himself Baron; how once he had given him a black powder with the command to carry it to the Marshal; and how on another occasion he had shown him a quantity of gold bars, which afterward proved to be merely a heap of sand and a yellowish earth. The Marshal on his side had made a contract in his own blood, in which he promised to give the demon everything he demanded of him, except his life and his soul.

He had worshiped him for this purpose, offering him sacrifices, incense, alms, and a feast arranged in his honor; and he sealed all this by immediately offering him, as a token of allegiance, the heart, the hand, the eyes, and the blood of a child. Now an old woman was noticed, who roamed about the country and the heathens, approaching the little children who tended the livestock or ran about begging, and flattering them, while always keeping her face half covered with a heavy cloth. She thus lured them to the castle of Raiz, where they then vanished without a trace. At first it was only peasant children and homeless ones who thus perished; but soon, with growing boldness, the city children too came in turn, even as far as Nantes.

Bodin recounts on p. 249, probably from the records: after the werewolf had in this manner slaughtered eight children for the devil, he at last also promised the ninth, his own, and indeed while still in its mother's womb, to kill it for him as a pleasing sacrifice by opening the same. Yet he did not attain to familiar intercourse with him face to face, and he was wont to say: the Unknown must be a common fellow, that he should shrink from associating with persons of rank. This speech of his, now, the sign of the cross that he perhaps made upon entering the circle; or the prayer that he always spoke, especially his Alma Redemptoris Mater; his attachment to the chapel that surrounded him; the secret resolve that he cherished, to atone in the end by a crusade---these were the reasons that his entourage adduced for why no such relation would come about. \[Page 307\]

Raiz meanwhile surrendered himself to the most shameful lusts that the imagination can possibly conceive; and so had the bloodthirst in him united itself with this lust, that the unhappy victims of his brutality acquired a true charm for him only in the moment of their death, and out of grim lust he continued what he had begun in despair. He himself killed his unhappy victims with his own hand; their cries, their rattling, their convulsions delighted him, as he strove to increase and prolong them, and to enjoy this lust all the more closely, he would seat himself upon the dying ones. In the tower of Chantocé a whole barrel full of calcined bones of children was found, whose number was estimated at forty, all of whom this Moloch had burned in his glowing arms. According to his own confession, the number of those whom he had thus sacrificed there and in the castle of Machecoul amounted to a hundred; others were found in the privies of Suze, likewise in Nantes, Vannes; so that the total number was estimated at 150.

They were all sacrificed to the demons Barron, Orient, Beelzebub, Satan, and Belial, while the office of Easter Day was sung to them. Soon after Easter, when he had anew vowed a journey to the Holy Land, but immediately thereafter in Nantes had again defiled himself with the same abominations; he was at last, on the order of the Duke, together with Prelat and some others, arrested. The accusation was brought by the procurator of the Duke, and the promoter of the Bishop of Nantes; six or seven family fathers, whose children had gone to the Marshal and not returned, were likewise complainants. The trial was conducted in the new tower of Nantes, before the Chancellor of Brittany, the Bishop of the place, and the Inquisitor of the kingdom, Jean Merri, on charges of heresy, sorcery, sodomy, and so forth; but before Peter of l'Hôpital, the President, in regard to all that pertained to his competence. He was at first very bold in confronting these; he said: he would rather be hanged by his neck than give account to the clergy, who were all stained with simony and shameful deeds. He knew the faith as well as they, and he wondered that the President should allow them to meddle in such processes.

He became, however, soon more pliable, and the censors of the church made him confess a part of his shameful deeds; the fear of torture accomplished the rest. He was confronted with Prelati, and the confessions proved Marshal, under tears and sobs, to him: Farewell, Franz, my friend! We shall never see each other again in this world. Pray to God for me, I shall pray for you! The convent in Yssel in the Netherlands, in which Marie von Sains lived, was full of obsessions and maleficia, but no suspicion had fallen on her; for one held her to be a saint without equal, until she, driven by a secret power, declared herself to be a sorceress, and was now arrested by the official of Tournay. But it still took another year and a half until she finally, in the year 1613, made the more detailed confessions about her misdeeds, which first of all ran thus: that all the maleficia of the convent had really been instigated by her. Then she also made confessions about her murders. She confessed: how she had murdered many children, or disemboweled them alive, in order to sacrifice them to the devil. Others she had strangled, the still-beating hearts of still others she had crushed and eaten with her teeth, especially those born of Christian parents. Many of these children, she said, I have secretly strangled in this city and the neighboring places, and then exhumed the buried ones, and carried them to our nocturnal gatherings. To many I have thus given death, or removed them from the way with poison that the demons supplied to me; others I have pulled the hair from, still others I have pierced the heart or the temple with a needle; which were thrown into the fire oven, others drowned, still others roasted on a spit, boiled in pots, thrown into the latrines, laid on burning pyres, thrown to lions, snakes, and other wild animals for food. Some were hanged by the feet, with the arms or by the neck, others also by the genitals; to some I have smashed the skull against the wall, flayed them and cut them up as if for salting; still others I have placed under presses, tied them to dogs, and thus let them be torn apart; or I have hanged them on the cross to the shame of the Savior, and to all this I then made use of these words: In mockery of the Creator I bring you, Lucifer and Beelzebub, and the whole assembly of demons, the body and soul and every limb of this child as an offering. Peter testified as follows: how, nineteen years before, at the time of the fair in Poligny, the most violent downpour had so scattered the herd he was tending that he did not know how he should find them again; and how, while searching for the cattle, he met and saw three black riders. The last among these, on being asked what drove him, after he had complained of his distress to him, bade him be of good courage, and promised him: if he would give himself over to him, he would give him a master who would assist him so that henceforth he would suffer no damage to his herd from wolf or any other beast, or from any other source. In confirmation of what was said, he promised him the recovery of all the cattle now lost, and in addition money.

He had accepted the condition, and had said he would present himself at the same place in 4--5 days. Since the cattle had indeed been found, he had also returned to his rider on the third day, who asked him whether he really wished to surrender himself to him. On the question from his side, who then he might be, he had replied: The servant of the great prince of hell; but fear not on that account! They had now concluded an agreement together, renouncing the Christian faith; whereupon he had offered him his left, black, and cold hand to kiss; but he had now knelt before him, and had greeted him---who later called himself Moyse, and forbade him all church attendance---as his lord. \[Page 312\]

This had gone on in such a way for two years, but the art of protecting the cattle had not been imparted to him; only the spirit, as it seemed, had taken care of it for him when wolves perhaps appeared. Soon after being relieved of the care of the herd, he had neglected Moyse, and had again taken part in church services for about 8--9 years; until M. Verdung induced him to renew the pact on the condition that the promised money be procured.

The meeting took place in the evening in Chastel Charlon in the forest; where many others, with blue-burning green candles in their hands, had gathered. One day Berdung, who also had a spirit named Guillemin, spoke to him thus: if he would only believe him, he would bring it about that he might proceed in his running with any desired speed. He allowed this, upon the promise of new monetary payments, and this one then anointed him, after he had stripped himself naked, with an ointment that he had with him; whereupon he immediately believed that he was transformed into a true wolf. It horrified him when he beheld the four wolf's feet and his wolf's hair; but now in his running he was borne along, swift as the wind, and this could only have come to pass through the aid of his master, who was immediately present at such a flight; although he did not see him until after he had regained his human form.

Michael, anointed in like manner, had moved away with equally desired speed, such that the eye could not follow. The second case has emerged yet more clearly and distinctly. In the year 1603 there was conducted before the Parliament of Bordeaux, under the presidency of the first president Daffis, a jurist then renowned throughout all France for his insight and ability, the trial of such a werewolf-man from Roche Chalais in the land of Guienne; and the records of this well-conducted trial de Lanere has excerpted in his book¹); from which excerpt the following circumstances stand forth as essential. \[Page 314\]

The ordinary judge had conducted the first examination on the spot, in the village of Paulot, upon the rumor: how there on the previous day a wolf had attacked a young girl, Margaretha Poirier; and how a youth of 13--14 years, Jean Grenier, in service with Peter Combaut, had boasted: that he had been the one who attacked her in wolf form, and would have devoured her if she had not driven him off with a stick. The attacked girl was re-examined by three witnesses, and had usually tended the cattle with Grenier. On such occasions, he had often told her: how he, transforming himself into a wolf at will, had already torn apart several dogs and two children; but that dog flesh was not as good to eat as that of children. One day, while they were again with the herd, a wild animal had thrown itself upon her, seizing her by her clothing at the right hip and tearing it; whereupon she had struck at it with her stick. But the animal had then withdrawn 10--12 paces from her, and, setting itself up on its hind legs like a dog, had looked at her with a furious gaze; so that she had run away in full terror. The animal had been thicker and smaller than a wolf, had also had a smaller head, along with brown hair and a small tail. The third witness, Jeanne Gaboriant, 18 years old, reported on various things he had said. When asked why he was now so black, he had replied: that it came from the wolf skin which Pierre Labourant, who lay chained in a mighty chain, had given him, and had told him thereby: if he put it on, he could transform himself into a wolf or any other animal. He had then done this many times, and had run about each time at the waning moon, on Mondays, Fridays, and Saturdays, but only one hour of the day, toward evening or morning; theirs, however, were nine, of whom he named some who ran with one another. 1) Tableau de la Constance p. 252--326. 470

This seemed sufficient to place the accused in custody; and when examined in it, he confessed voluntarily more than the witnesses had stated. He was the son of the day laborer Peter Grenier, whom he had left three months before because he had beaten him harshly; after which he had wandered about in the area of Courtras partly on beggary, partly in the service of various masters. Once a young man named Peter of the house Tilhaire had found him on the road, and had said to him: in the forest of St. Anton there lives a gentleman who wishes to speak with you. When he had gone with him, they had found him dressed in black, on a black horse; and when they had greeted him, he had dismounted, and had kissed him with a very cold mouth; then commanded him to present himself each time he desired it, and had ridden away. This had happened three years before, when he had been 10--11 years old; and they had seen him three more times thereafter. He had let him groom his horse, had promised him money, and had handed him a glass of wine, after which he had gone his way again. But before that, he had been marked by him with a sort of spit that he carried, under the buttocks; where indeed a small, round, insensitive mark, in the form of a seal, was found on him. He confirmed the statement of Marg. Poirier as completely true, and confessed: how once at the villages of de la Doubla he had gone into a house, and had carried a child in the cradle, which he had found alone, behind a palisade in the garden; had eaten as much of it as he pleased, and had left the rest to a wolf that had been nearby. So he named several others with whom he had proceeded in the same way; but without tearing their clothes, as wolves do, rather pulling them off. He ran at the waning moon, 1--2 hours in the day, and sometimes in the night; but also on church festivals, on the day before Pentecost, in Lent, and especially in Holy Week. \[Page 315\]

The Lord of the Forest would then give him, every time he wished to let him run, the wolf's skin and the ointment, both of which he kept with him; and he would immediately wrap the one around himself, and anoint himself naked with the other. Peter de la Tilhaire likewise possessed such a one, and they had run together four times; without, however, killing anyone together. His father, likewise a runner, had taken him along on the run several times, and they had once together killed and eaten a girl near Grillaut. After the running, he found himself very fatigued, and his hands and feet bloody, torn by thorns and thistles. The nail of his left thumb was thick, long, and claw-like; he had had to let it grow thus at the command of the Lord of the Forest. This one did not let him out of his sight as long as he had the wolf's form; but as soon as he, the accused, lost sight of him, he returned to human form.

He was now handed over to two physicians for examination, and they found him in spirit dull, limited, and ignorant; moreover, of a black-bilious and melancholic temperament; they declared, however, that in their opinion he in no way suffered from the wolf-sickness. At the same time, the fathers of the children whom the accused had named as eaten had also been summoned and confronted with him, and it emerged that they agreed with his depositions with regard to time and place, the form of the werewolf, the wounds, the aid that the relatives had provided, the weapons or sticks that they had carried, the words with which they had shouted at the wolf, down to the smallest details. Once he had selected the tenderest and fattest out of three children, and had recounted how the brother of the father of the three children had driven him off armed, and as he fled, had called after him: je karroumteray bien. \[Page 316\]

The children were presented to the judge; the attacked and wounded one was indeed the plumpest among the three; and Jean Roullier, their father, testified how the brother had truly used those words. They went even further, and had him led through all the villages and houses where he had run, according to his statement; and when in one of them he found the man who had spoken those words, he recognized him at once among many others, and seized him by the arm. Marg. Poirier was also brought forward; he recognized her at once among four or five girls, and she him in turn, and showed the officials and him the wounds at mouth and chin that were not yet fully healed. His father too was heard and confronted with him; the son wavered somewhat in his statements when he saw him, and it was ascertained that misery and imprisonment had made him dull. But after some rest, he stood by his earlier statement against him; which also went to this: that his mother had separated from him because she had once seen him gnaw on dogs' feet and children's hands. The decision of the Parliament was as wise as the conduct of the entire trial was exemplary. The court ruled: the boy, whom the demon had armed against other children, must not be given up as lost; all the more so, since according to the report of the clergy who had taken charge of him, he had already begun to abhor his crime; which was evident in many tears and gave hope of winning him back to God and a better way of life. Considering, however, that he must be removed from the sight of the inhabitants of the villages where he had committed his crimes, and placed in such a situation that on the one hand a nature so neglected and estranged from the fear of God need no longer be feared; on the other hand, however, that it might be enabled to bring him back to better paths, the council has sentenced Jean Grenier: to be locked up for life in a monastery of the city, to be of service to it all that time; and under penalty of death forbidding him ever to remove himself from this place of confinement.

His father and Peter, called Tilhaire, were detained for further investigation, but after a month's term, however, released. There in his monastery, de Lancre visited him later in 1610, and learned from him still much that was significant. He was then a young man, 20--21 years old, of medium height, rather small for his age; he had wild, small, deeply set, black, unruly eyes, whose expression showed that he was ashamed of his former state, of which he had some knowledge, and dared not look anyone in the face. He had very long, light, more than usually broad, somewhat blackened, and damaged and worn teeth from gnawing around with the animals. His nails were long, and some black from the root to the tip, among them also the thumbnail, which the forest lord had forbidden him to cut; and these thus blackened ones were also half worn down, and otherwise still extraordinary, because he had used his hands in the manner of feet. \[Page 317\]

He was somewhat dull-witted, yet not so much that he would have been senseless on that account, and he carried out quickly what the good Carmelites, who had taken charge of him with love, commanded him. He showed little spirit, and struggled with things that required only plain human understanding; like one who had always spent his time with the herds, and seen nothing of the world. He made no secret of the fact that he had been a werewolf, and that he had run across the land on the command of the forest lord; and he only said that this was not shameful to him, since he had ceased to be such. But he also confessed without concealment: that he still felt a great lust within himself to eat the flesh of children; especially that of young girls was a delicacy.

To the question: whether he would perhaps still eat such things, if he were allowed? he answered honestly: Yes. Also the clergy told how they, in the beginning of his stay in the monastery, had sometimes seen him secretly devour the removed entrails of fish. He also once had a wondrous skill in going on all fours, and jumping over ditches like the animals. De Lancre remembered thereby another boy from Saint Pa, who had run as fast as a fleeing dog; knew how to turn around so swiftly that one scarcely noticed it, and sprang over the ditches like a gust of wind. Grenier also assured him: how he had had a wolf skin, which the lord had given him in the forest of Droilha, in the marquisate of FronSac, and which he had hidden on the roof of a barn in his village; yet he had not always brought it to him when he had let him run. His father had likewise made use of it, and on that account, and because he had let him grow up so badly, he expressed great aversion toward him; he also never wanted to see him, although he came to the monastery several times. In contrast, he had a quite special pleasure in seeing wolves, and this affection might well be mutual; since in his interrogations he had often testified: how he had always left the greater part of the prey to the accompanying wolves. His forest lord, moreover, he abhorred and cursed at that time, and said of him: how he had visited him still twice at the beginning of his stay in the monastery, which had frightened him greatly. Physically Jacob suffered little, but he was a kind of visionary, and saw, as he said, the fiends coming. A moment later the brothers would be as if smitten by a breath, and feel an inner motion that increased to the point of hemorrhage; yet so that, when the attack had passed, they felt their strength restored, as if they had never lacked anything. Often it seemed to them as if they were beaten by invisible but still palpable hands; often as if they were pierced through the belly. They ascribed these things neither to the devil nor to actual spectres, but to wicked people. The seer insisted that he had positively recognized the apparitions as persons still living and even related to them; and the strangest stories were adduced in proof.

They had at the outset sought diverse medical help, but found none anywhere; what wonder, since they sought to drive out sorcery by sorcery, and went to those who were reputed to practice such arts. These assisted them on several occasions by sympathetic means, but only for a short time; because, as they alleged, the helpers were better paid by the others. What opinion I should draw from all these accounts as to the real ground of the matter I did not know. I regarded the two younger brothers, David and Friedrich, as hysterical; for their condition, especially that of the latter, pointed to a high degree of suffering. They otherwise appeared to be anything but timid, superstitious people; so that, since I noted they were Protestants --- among whom such things, especially in that district, occur even more than among Catholics --- I was inclined to ascribe the whole affair to a play of the imagination; yet on the other hand their calm narration, their ingenuous answers to embarrassing questions which I put to them, utterly disabused me of that view.

After I had at last deliberated, and after I had to some extent explained to them the meaning of the church benediction, I gave this to them repeatedly once or twice a day. They testified that they felt easier, indeed they seemed entirely free from their plague. I therefore dismissed them in Easter week with a letter to the pastor who had sent them to me; in which I begged him, in consideration of my ignorance concerning the true nature of the affair, to make on the spot inquiries into the relations of the family, into the circumstances of the people among whom they had been raised, and in general into everything that might throw light on the matter; also himself, notwithstanding the general prohibition of exorcism, at least to employ the exorcismum probativum.

At the beginning of June the brothers, to my no small astonishment, returned a second time and brought with them a letter from the pastor, who wrote that he himself had gone to their parental house in Bischofsheim; that he had there examined and investigated all the circumstances, but had discovered nothing significant as to the cause of the matter. He had had the brothers examined by physicians, and these, as the enclosed certificates showed, had detected no bodily disease. Twice he had written to the Vicar General for permission to perform the exorcism; but the latter had only answered evasively. He had now blessed the house, and it had indeed been freed from all haunting; the half-dead cattle were now well too; only the three brothers continued to be tormented, and he therefore repeatedly begged me to apply the exorcism. He acknowledged his error, to be sure, but the accusers did not rest until he was removed.

Mr. Barnard then prayed, and our hands were laid upon them, and the seized ones now said: it would become better for them again, and we were guilty of their torments; whereupon we were immediately seized and sent as prisoners to Salem.

We, however, who knew ourselves to be entirely innocent of all that, were exceedingly dismayed, astonished, and confused on account of the sudden assault; so that we almost lost our reason. Since our best friends, beholding us in such a state, believed there was no other means to save our lives, they persuaded us, out of love and pity, to confess that what those others said of us was true. But those were only confessions that were suggested to some of us by others, who said: we were witches, and they knew it, and we knew it likewise; and they knew that we knew it. Thus they spoke of Justice Bradstreet, who himself had committed thirty or forty suspects to prison, that he had murdered nine of them; he saved himself by flight. A dog was soon afflicted; the seers said: the brother of the fugitive was riding it. This one took flight, and the dog was killed. Another dog met the same fate, because they were seized by paroxysm when he looked at them.

Meanwhile, among the accused were also many of the very best reputation, whose Christian disposition no one could doubt; and the number of the accused in general became so great that one could not imagine them all to be guilty. Also the protestations of the nineteen executed had had their effect. Thus one came to consider whether the whole thing might not be Satan's work, who thus deluded the afflicted? The clergy, at the request of the authorities, held a meeting, and here, among other things, the question was put to them: whether Satan could not appear both in the form of innocent and godly persons, as well as in that of guilty and godless ones, in order to deceive those whom he had afflicted? and they answered that he might do so. Now one began to reflect; to be sure, in January 1693 twenty-six were still examined, but only three were convicted, and none more executed. Soon the convicted obtained a reprieve; on April 25 one confessed himself guilty, and yet the jury pronounced him not guilty. \[Page 355\]

And now, after the storm had lasted sixteen months, nineteen at the gallows, one voluntarily deceased, over fifty had confessed to witchcraft, over 150 still sat in the prisons, and more than 200 were yet under accusation; after the judges, like the best of the people, had been reviled, they finally desisted. The accused were set free in all the prisons, the fugitives returned, and peace was restored. With it now came the reactions as well. Since everything had proceeded from the house of the clergyman Parris, and he himself had been a strong zealot in the matter, many withdrew from his congregation and submitted a petition against him: that he had given credence to the accusations of the devil. He acknowledged his error, to be sure, but the accusers did not rest until he was removed.

A day of fasting and repentance was proclaimed, to atone for the congregation. On it, one of the judges stood up in their midst and publicly confessed: that in the recently occurred events he might have erred in many points, and he humbly begged forgiveness. Six of the accused women, who had confessed their guilt, signed a document in which they, among other things, recounted: We were brought to the afflicted persons, who, as they said, fell into their paroxysms upon our arrival. Mr. Barnard then prayed, and our hands were laid upon them, and the seized ones now said: it would become better for them again, and we were guilty of their torments; whereupon we were immediately seized and sent as prisoners to Salem.

We, however, who knew ourselves to be entirely innocent of all that, were exceedingly dismayed, astonished, and confused on account of the sudden assault; so that we almost lost our reason. Since our best friends, beholding us in such a state, believed there was no other means to save our lives, they persuaded us, out of love and pity, to confess that what those others said of us was true. But those were only confessions that were suggested to some of us by others, who said: we were witches, and they knew it, and we knew it likewise; and they knew that we knew it. Since we had now almost lost all understanding, all reason, and all mental faculties, we were not able to judge of our condition; and the most that we said was only an assent to what they chattered to us beforehand.

When we were afterward a little composed again, and they told us what we had confessed; then we certainly said again that we were innocent, and that we knew nothing at all of such things. --- One cannot depict more touchingly and emphatically the state of mind of countless ones who stood in court in such accusations, nor more aptly portray how people, often without malice, impose their delusions upon one another. The twelve jurors likewise signed a document in which they declared: "how they had not been able to comprehend or withstand the mysterious deceptions of the powers of darkness; and how they therefore feared, along with others, though unwittingly and unintentionally, to have loaded upon themselves and the congregation the guilt of blood.

They therefore pleaded with God that He would not impute this guilt to anyone; but all whom they had unjustly offended, they humbly begged forgiveness." That was now good and praiseworthy; but the executed were not thereby brought back to life. The entire narrative vividly illustrates how the good folk had entered the enchanted forest, and became all the more entangled in it the further they advanced. If we consider in this the view that was taken during the investigation: that the demon had caused the confusion; then one sees that he made use therein of two kinds of people as his instruments. \[Page 356\]

The first group consists of the afflicted: their actions were driven by malice, or at the very least, no suspicion had ever been cast upon them; they were clairvoyant, experienced their paroxysms, were struck down by them upon seeing the others, and their numbers grew through the ever-wider spread of the affliction.

The others were the tormentors. On their side the evil, probably with the Indian woman in the same house as Parris, had taken its beginning. Mather writes later, in his history of New England, the whole confusion to the Indian pawwaws or sorcerers, who had sent their spirits among the Europeans. That woman, who wandered about in the kitchen, formed according to him then the transition; and from her the evil passed in pursuit to the ever increasing number of the others. The allegedly acting and the suffering formed two rows; but in their midst stood deciding the red book in between. Who signed belonged to the first, who refused to the others; and if one of these decided upon the signature, he, like that woman, immediately entered the other row, and became spectral.

The evil also passes over to children, even spreads among the domestic animals; one of the two dogs places itself on the side of the afflicted, the other joins the tormentors. Now the question arises: Can one of the two rows give legally valid testimony against the other, without accusing itself? The left could only, if seriously repentant, direct its testimony against itself. The right, the afflicted, are possessed according to the presupposition; but there is no infallible sign by which one could distinguish the possession through immediate incursion of Satan from the obsession through mediation of a third. But if the first were the case, then the thus possessed could not testify against the others that they had obtained Satan through their mediation; these could rather with greater probability give testimony against them that they, the first-possessed, had transferred the devil onto them. But if even an obsession had taken place, two cases are possible.

The left had indeed sent Satan to the right; but this would have been received with conscious consent on the part of the possessed. The ones would then be possessed like the others, there would be only the difference of giving and taking, like that of incubus and succubus in possession; the movements in the neighborhood arose from the community of both, and one would have had the equal right to strike both dead, as was done to the two dogs.

Or the taking possession happened without foreknowledge of the seized; then the accused could reply: You see the devil in you only in our shape, your faith is thus deception, and your testimony false. In all these cases therefore no reliance could be placed on these statements; all advantage was however on the side of the evil, in whose interest the two lines, as the third, that of the judges, worked. #### A. The Good and Secure Practice

There is no lack, neither in ecclesiastical nor in secular courts, of examples of the most blameless administration of justice in such cases. We select from them only one, the case of del Vaulx in Stablo, because of its rounded completeness, and because the judge himself recounts it from the records. Chapeauville, canon in Liège, reports the following about this legal proceeding. In the year 1595, Johannes del Vaulx, a member of the old and famous monastery of Stablo, had been imprisoned by his prior on suspicion of poisoning and other crimes; which, when it came to the knowledge of the abbot and administrator of the monastery, prompted him to send me there.

I saw the man, who by God's grace had grown weary of the demon's tyranny, and who, in the first conversation with me and the prior, opened up his entire life to us with many tears. For when he had tended the herds of his elders, and his boyhood had already been stained with abominable crimes, after his fifteenth year had arrived, he had seen an old man in long and seemingly clerical garb walking through the forest, who asked him: whether he would serve him and obey him? He would, as a reward, bring him to high honors in the state that he himself chose, to which he had then boldly agreed at once. \[Page 363\]

Afterwards, he appeared to him in other and ever other monstrous forms, and also pressed into his shoulders two marks, which we examined; then carried him to the nocturnal assemblies, over many places, and provided him with poisons, with which he killed the cattle of the elders and of others, and also, in addition, human beings; and then accompanied him on his studies to Trier. On his advice, he then took the habit and immediately the orders of the priesthood; and removed the prior along with other order clerics, in order to gain the priory, by poison. But he had still many participants in his crimes and malefactions.

When I reported this to the prelate, he resolved: to have the case judged in the legal manner. He therefore sent the reverend Mr. A. Stregnart, suffragan, and me with a notary once more to Stablo; we interrogated him on all individual articles, and recorded his statements in writing. Since we noticed during the interrogation that the demon had taught him many pagan and heretical errors; we instructed him in the doctrine of the one and triune God, of the good and evil spirits, of immortality, of the future life, as well as in some other fundamental doctrines of our faith. The prelate wanted: that a thorough examination be conducted with him, so that, if he were brought to true repentance and stood by his statements --- but he accused more than 500 accomplices ---, these testimonies might have all the greater credence.

After weighing the confession and the accusations made, the prelate dispatched a commission to his principality of Stablo; whereby he transferred to his suffragan A. Stregnart, to me his general vicar, then to Father Oranus, pro-chancellor of his council and assessor of Liège, as well as to Mr. Molempeter, advocate of the fisc, all authority: to judge over the whole matter, to pass sentence, to execute the judgment; and if necessary, to call in the ordinary and feudal judges, knowledgeable in the laws and customs. In consequence thereof, we set out at the beginning of 1500 for Stablo, in a carriage which broke in two in the middle on the way; so that we had to cover the rest of the journey on horseback. We arrived still in the evening at the monastery, and visited the prisoner, who, upon our greeting, without returning it, at once brought forward excuses regarding the incident with the broken wagon.

Not his demon, he said, who had never done him any harm, had caused it; but another evil-minded one had committed it. At the break of the following day, he was examined and interrogated on the articles fixed by the fisc, and he persisted steadfastly in his first confession, not only naming his accomplices, but also specifying precisely: to which sodality they belonged; whither he had been nocturnally abducted with them; what criminal acts had been practiced there, what had been done in honor of the presiding demon; in what order the banquets had been held, the minglings had taken place, and the enchantments of humans, cattle, and fruits had been performed. \[Page 364\]

The names, status, and circumstances of the accused persons were thereby determined with the utmost precision. But we, in order to test the consistency of his words, and to close the mouth of slander, waited some days before visiting him again; then reminded him of his salvation, and warned him that on this account he should beware of falsely accusing anyone. Thereupon we read to him his statements and accusations again, but in reverse and confused order; so that we placed those whom he had put in the first row, say, under the second and third, and vice versa. But he then insisted: that he had not said so, that the words had not been correctly recorded; that the matters stood thus, whereupon he repeated his earlier statements in their order.

We held it thus more often, for he had accused both clergy and laymen. Thus he said: that he had often visited the Trier assembly, where D. Vlaet, electoral councilor, who was burned there as a sorcerer, had presided; and that he had also had at this place a beautiful and charming girl, a fisherwoman, as his beloved, who after every assembly presented him with fish. After we had heard all this most wondrous from him, we nevertheless interrogated him still more often in formal sessions, treating him mildly and inquiring of him in every way the truth about his life and his deeds; but we found him in all things so steadfast and consistent with himself that we dismissed all suspicion of madness in his mind.

Oranus, who now, as I write this (1616), lives at 76 years of age in great vigor, and I myself, we visited him out of Christian love moreover still often in the room wherein he lived; we questioned him often about everything that we had learned in part from writings, in part from his confessions. But he always adduced weighty reasons that proved that what he had confessed had not occurred through deceitful demonic impressions, merely in the imagination, as we suggested and as it seemed probable to us; but rather truly, really, hypostatically and personally encountered him, and he indicated certain signs by which he could recognize when he had actually attended the assemblies and committed this or that, and when merely in the imagination.

When we had communicated the records to the prelate, and he recognized more and more the importance of the matter, he commanded us: to open the instruction of the process against the accused, both clergy and laymen; which then throughout the course of this year, up to the tenth of January of the following, was done with equal diligence and equal attention. It had been impressed upon us: not merely to lay hands on old women and men from the common folk, but also against the notables of the place, the mayor named Kannerlink, the judges and the pastor, as well as some religious persons distinguished by age, spirit, learning, and judgment. On the 10th of January 1597, after an advocate and syndicus had been assigned to the prisoner, the articles of accusation of the fiscal were read to him before the assembled court, along with the responses that he had made and maintained thereto thereafter; whereupon he clearly, frankly, and persistently declared and confessed: that he could make no change in the admitted sorceries, nor in the accused persons, or render any retraction, without placing the salvation of his soul in danger. \[Page 365\]

Since the fiscal now urgently pressed for the pronouncement of judgment against the confessing accused, the terms set for the verdict were prorogued nine times on account of the importance of the matter; and just as often the guilty one was reminded of the peril of his previous life under the dominion of the devil, and how he had mocked the almighty God, his service, and his religion; he should therefore take care not to rob himself of all hope of salvation through empty and fabricated confessions, or false and slanderous accusations. He said again and repeated himself ever: that he could change nothing in what he had previously confessed, or retract anything whatsoever without lying and perjury. He hoped only for a merciful judgment; and that was his sole, fervent desire, that after renouncing the devil, reconciled once more to the almighty and merciful God, he might obtain his grace. The syndicus, dissatisfied with this, demanded that the clergy of Stablo, who, infected by the poison and still lying sick, be interrogated thereon. Aegidius Harsetanus, the prior, Mauritius of Offl, Quirin of Generet, Cornelius Neufforge, and Paschasius Lymburg were thereupon examined, all of whom testified: how they indeed considered themselves harmed by the poison that their fellow brother Del Baulr, or his companions, had placed in various places in the monastery.

The syndic now proposed: to proceed according to the records, and to condemn the guilty to be interrogated under torture; so that the confession regarding his accomplices might thereby be proven, and gain greater evidentiary force. This exhortation was made in the presence of the accused, who merely implored the mercy of the Almighty God. Accordingly, the following resolution was adopted: In the matter of J. Vilars, syndic of the Abbey of Stablo, plaintiff, against H. J. Del Vaulr, a member of that monastery, accused of sorcery, which matter remains pending before us, J. Chapeauville, commissioner specially appointed by His Highness; upon the counsel of those learned in divine and human law, to whom the state of the case has been communicated, it is resolved and pronounced: The aforesaid accused shall, before proceeding to the full resolution of his case, be rigorously questioned, and further interrogated under torture. Given on the 19th of March 1597.

When this decree became known, amid the bitterness of many of those accused of sorcery, the rumor spread: that we had been dealing with a deranged and senseless man. In order to dispel this rumor, we summoned the lords Ludwig von Viset, prior of Malmedy, a man of proven and tested truthfulness; Hubert von Verlemont; Gabriel Neufforge, steward of Stablo; Remigius Ultrapontanus; Wilhelm Rane, podestà of Malmedy; Adolph von Rahier, the schultheiss of Bodeur; P. von Noirfalli, schultheiss of Chenron; as well as other clerics, noble and esteemed men, officials and magistrates, among whom some were also suspected of sorcery. In their collective presence, J. Del Vaulr was now repeatedly questioned anew regarding the confessions and accusations. He always responded undauntedly, steadfastly, and aptly to everything put before him; so that he corrected all the errors and perverse narratives that we had intentionally fabricated, as well as the objections of the suspects, who made them vehemently against him; and, providing good reasons from all sides, he entirely refuted the opinion of his mental derangement.

Yet with this, his adversaries were still not pacified, but rather spread about: how, during the time of his imprisonment, he had written letters to the lords de la Bourlotte and de Goberville, as well as to D. de Wils, in which matters were contained that pointed to madness: in that he called them his nephews; and therein promised to do away with all enemies of the Catholic king through his arts and his secrets, and more of the like. \[Page 366\]

When earnestly questioned, he replied firmly and calmly: that at that time he had played the fool and the delirious, pretending kinship, and spoken of the fall of the king's enemies, so that he might be released from prison on the grounds of madness; on this statement he persisted during three and four interrogations. After all this was concluded in judicial and customary manner, he said, when the acts were repeated from the beginning and translated into the language of the country for those ignorant of Latin, repeatedly: all confessions and accusations written down here are entirely true; and everything he stated therein about persons was truly done and committed. Then he was confronted with J. von Frounille, the pastor of Stablo, whom he accused of sorcery. When D. Oran, extremely experienced in these legal matters, wondered at the categorical denials of the pastor, Del Vaulr removed all his wonder in my presence by explaining to him the secret of silence among sorcerers. A solemn oath is repeated annually over this in all gatherings, and it had not long been taken in that of Stablo; at which he had been present and had recognized the said Frounille very well.

Now the syndic of the court demanded: that all his statements and references, and the confessions of the accused, be read out again, and then the latter, under invocation of God, be questioned on oath and under threat of eternal damnation: whether he persists in his oft-repeated confession, or has anything contrary to testify. The accused, after the punishment for perjury had been solemnly explained to him, answered firmly: all his confessions and accusations are entirely true, and he can and will retract nothing of them. With this testimony the syndic would not be satisfied, but now moved for the application of the rack, not to elicit further confession, but to confirm the one already given; so that the guilty of the crime might have no cause to complain. The accused, when all his testimony was read out to him again, insisted upon it, calling God to witness under oath.

Proceedings now advanced to the rack; the accused testified under torture, as the articles of the fiscal were presented to him one by one, at peril of his salvation and damnation: that all and every one he had named had been accomplices in the sorcery; that he had seen and recognized them in the assemblies, and had committed and carried out with them everything he had stated. Earnestly reminded again to consider maturely all that he had said and confessed, and to accuse no one guiltlessly; after prayers and exorcisms had also not been omitted over him, he confessed openly and firmly: everything said and confessed is the pure truth, and no one is slandered or unjustly accused; this he testified on the mercy of God Almighty, to which he, after revoking the vows made to the demon, betook his refuge, and awaited forgiveness for his poor soul, which had hitherto been in a state of despair. Finally, the improbability of so great a number of accomplices and confederates was set before him; which we did to test his reliability, but he nonetheless stood by his word. After common prayers and new exorcisms, he was again urged to say nothing against the truth; under repetition of the solemn oath he remained by his testimonies and accusations, and avowed: that he would hold to them until the end of his life. \[Page 367\]

After all those present had unanimously reminded him once more of the consequences of perjury and the dangers of false accusation, and he had sworn for the second and third time that he had said nothing against the accused persons except what he himself had seen and heard; he was released from the torture and led to the hearth, unharmed in his limbs, for the torture had been only mild. We had also seen the marks on his shoulders at that time, and tested them with a needle, which we drove deep into them without his feeling any pain from it. Since all this had now thus taken place, the fiscal requested a legally valid transcript of what had occurred, and declared, after receiving it, that he would and must make use of it not only against the accused but also against every other person, as testimony and foundation for every investigation. He further moved that the defendant be summoned for the seventh hour of the second of April, in order to hear his judgment in proper form from the mouth of the commissioner and judge D. \[something\] v. Chapeauville. The notification of this summons was thereupon attested by Henricus Harsetanus, the cleric, with his own handwritten signature.

The judgment read as follows:

Whereas thou, F. Del Baulr, priest and abbot in Stablo, art convicted not only by many reports, witness testimonies, and public rumor, but also by thy oft-repeated confession, of having denied the faith and religion to which thou didst profess thyself at baptism, not merely with thy mouth but also in thy heart and soul, and in opposition thereto of having dedicated thyself to the demon, the enemy of the human race; whereas thou hast worshipped him at the nocturnal assemblies repeatedly; hast also concluded a pact and vow with him in order to commit maleficia, to obtain honors, pleasures, riches, and other earthly goods besides; and, to confirm the pact, hast obtained his marks on thy shoulders; whereas thou hast caused the death of several fellows of the abbey of Stablo, namely the lords Antonius von Salm, the prior of this monastery, Perpetuus, Aegidius Warsegnius, Anton Harsetanus, Heinrich de Rahier, Leonard Fronduille, Corbelius Neufforge, and others of the lay estate, namely Nicolaa, the widow left behind of Heinrich von Houfalize, the wife of the foreman of the same place, and J. v. Morimon, citizen of Stablo, by means of poison which the demon gave thee; and furthermore hast committed many other abominable crimes with demonic succubi, as well as with married and unmarried women; for which thou deserves not only to be deposed from all offices and degrees, but truly degraded and handed over to the secular arm, according to the ordinance of the holy canons.

We, therefore, in order that such crimes, under the pretext of thy priestly order and monastic vows, may not remain unpunished, but that thou in this life shalt undergo a punishment to some satisfaction for thy sins and vices, for the reparation of the scandal, as an example and terror to the wicked, and for the edification of the pious: do hereby decree by this our final judgment that thou be stripped of all office and every dignity, declared worthy of actual deposition, and handed over to the secular arm; as we now in fact do strip thee of thy offices and dignities, degrade thee, and hand thee over to the secular arm; while however beseeching the judges and officers of the secular jurisdiction that they, insofar as the law permits, may abstain from bloodshed.

In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost. Amen.

Given on the 2nd of April 150; in the morning at 8 o'clock. \[Page 368\]

After the reading of this judgment, the degraded and stripped of his dignity was handed over to Prochancellor Oranus and Fiscal Advocate Molempeter, whom the most worthy Suffragan had appointed for this purpose; who now, with the involvement of some notables, wise assessors, and honored persons, after reviewing and carefully weighing the records, decided: J. Del Baulr should be executed with the sword, but then buried in consecrated ground in the churchyard of the monastery. The reason for the mitigated punishment was: because he had been in a state of accusation for five years, and during this time had been confined in a dark dungeon, living on bread and water; and what is more, had proven through his tears and sighs that he felt remorse over the past.
