ocedures. Del Vaulr had gazed into the distance, and seen the accident with the approaching judges' carriage, and communicated his vision, before anyone informed him of what had occurred. He was thus clairvoyant, all his statements therefore rested on visions that had come to him; whereas what he reported about the state of his own inner being referred predominantly to clear, lucid intuitions. His soberly reflecting self stood in an entirely different relation to his mystically beholding self than the latter did to the equated spheres of other personalities; and the inner spiritual activities followed entirely different laws in their effects.

Had the visions all been realities, then to be sure these differences would have balanced out again in the general lawfulness of nature, and the unity of the whole human being would have absorbed the differences within itself. He himself regarded them as a rule to be real, and in translating them into the language of ordinary life had noted certain signs by which he believed he could distinguish the truly real from those that were only apparently so. But these signs were not infallible, not even for him himself; as Oran related to his friend and Delrio: he was nevertheless sometimes uncertain whether everything had not altogether merely transpired in the vision.

Thus in this daemonic vision, with the conviction of its ideality or reality, it is precisely the same as in the higher mystical one regarding the insight into its relation to truth and deception; whose uncertainty we learn from Maria of Agreda, who despite the long years of apprenticeship and the most earnest discipline in which she held herself on the path of her progress, yet sometimes became doubtful whether deception had not beset her. If in this kind of visions nothing at all blameworthy has shown itself, if all signs have declared themselves for their authenticity; if they have been indubitably accompanied by the infused higher light that awakens and sharpens the inner higher instinct, the discerning spiritual conscience, so that it separates deception from truth with all certainty; then, as we have seen above, the Church gives its assent: in such a way, however, that it holds the seer himself obligated to ascribe belief to the content of his vision, according to the measure of his conviction; but by no means compels others to the same agreement, as it demands such for its doctrines, but rather recommends them only as credible, as subsidiary support of the faith, for acceptance; leaving the measure of assent to each, and only rejecting unconditional repudiation. Should it now be otherwise with the daemonic vision? Del Vaulr had, with all the certainty that can enter in this domain, the conviction of the reality and truth of his own; and the court had to allow this conviction to stand, insofar as it concerned himself. \[Page 370\]

But otherwise it was constituted with regard to that part of them in which other actual human beings were drawn into the circle that she enclosed. Here his conviction, against the denial of these people, could not make itself valid; because they were not obliged to accept his visions as infallible truths. The court, therefore, could grant to the accusations from this source---however well they might be judicially confirmed---no other validity, especially in questions where life and death were at stake, than a mere subsidiary one, which could indeed support an accusation but by no means establish it. In truth, what are visions other than beholdings into the interior of things, which now represent themselves symbolically; because the hitherto seen exterior is now only a shell and expression for the newly attained and emerging interior. One could easily imagine that a magnetic somnambulist might have the visions of summer and of winter.

The center of the first would be the sun at the summer solstice. From this center she would see the streams of light and those of warmth descending toward the earth; these would set the electric currents in motion in her vicinity, which, now conjoined with the propelling ones, would quicken the three lower elements---air, water, and earth---so that they in turn would awaken the hidden germs of life, which now would burst forth at all the nodal points of the earth. As all those outer movements now arouse corresponding inner ones, and unfold themselves in the now flowing streams, the earth would then cover itself with green before her eyes, and in the midst of the thus unfolding vegetation the animal kingdom too would soon develop itself to her, each according to its time.

That would be a wild swelling, flowing, surging, waving, weaving, flaming and blazing and radiant life; to behold it from its outermost extension to the innermost fountainhead in closest proximity, but in all its members, all plant and animal genera, all natural forces and faculties, expressed only in symbols. The center of the second vision would be the winter pole of the earth, which, in the remoteness of the sun, has selfishly enclosed itself. From this center the binding, congealing forces of darkness and cold would take their origin; they would, if dealing with freedom, murderously destroy all animal and plant extensions down to their germs, and then, burying these germs in the congealed earth, frost them over with rime, pelt them with hail, and cover them with snow; even the element of air would, wingless and bound, lay itself down around the rigid waters for winter's sleep: for everywhere the magnetic force would only rule, and the ancient night would at last enclose everything in her gloom.

The one would be the summer dream of life of the earth, summed up in one intuition; the other her stony and iron winter sleep, felt in the innermost root of death. To these natural visions there must correspond two others, beheld in the interior of the spiritual realm. For the seer might behold the daylight side of humanity in general, or of a society friendly to him in particular, that is turned toward the sun of eternity, how it, connected with this its center, receives into itself its vivifying effluences; how the forces and faculties, touched by them, according to their orders and hierarchies, become ensouled and exalted in the warming ray, flowing: so that all spiritual pulses beat more strongly, all energies tense themselves more powerfully, all virtues, purified and transfigured, express themselves in their effects with joyfulness. That would be the vision of a superterrestrial Sabbath, held on the bright heights of the earth, and bringing before intuition the inner connection of all good on earth, and its deepest origin from the primal source of all blessing. \[Page 371\]

What, then, can the vision of the Sabbath mean, which is held upon the midnight-dark heights, other than a sight of the inner spiritual intercourse that exists between the night-side of the conjoined ones and the root-like evil, which through its influences demonizes all the forces of this side; so that, while all the self-willed passions of the most radical ones are bound together, these operate in every one through the power of all. That such a connection exists, given the continuity that prevails through all realms of being, is beyond doubt; here only what hides itself in invisibility in ordinary life is brought to light for contemplation; so that the entire web of attracting and repelling forces comes to the fore.

The form of the entire vision is also here a symbolic one; all vices appear, according to their kinds and species, in great images; all their connecting threads with the heart, which beats in them all, are concrete, demonic personalities; all the accessories have their own peculiar significance, and the inversion of all the distorted, mirror-reflecting forms is the ruling law. The interpretation of these symbols is, like that of the images in the second vision, a matter that demands great insight and experience. That the crimes which appear in the vision have concretely and really taken place is by no means a necessary condition: for just as the seer himself throughout appears personally withdrawn from the realm of action; so too do his images throughout express only in a general manner how the orders to which this or that person belongs, in their present disposition and position, find themselves driven to act in relation to the conditioning world-powers, and under ce

The Arras Waldensian Witch Trials.verbatim:
and without love, written down from the events of the day on the spot. In the city of Langres, in Burgundy, Robinet de Baulx from Artois, who had passed himself off as a hermit, had expiated the charges against him with death by fire, and his statements had run as follows: many men and women were his companions in the Waldensianism, the local name at that time for heretical being. Among others, he had accused a prostitute from Douai named Deniselle, and J. la Vitte, called Abbé de Pessens, thereof. The inquisitor in Arras, Peter le Brousart, had learned of this, and first had Deniselle arrested, and then also la Vitte, after he had learned of his residence in Abbeville, and had them locked up in the episcopal prisons. \[Page 372\]

The vicars of the bishop, P. du Hamel, J. Thieubault, J. Pochon, and M. du Hamel, to whom J. du Bois also joined himself, had interrogated the first one several times on the rack; where she then confessed her participation, as well as that she had seen the others take part. This one, while arrested, had attempted to cut out his tongue, but it had not succeeded for him; however, he was laid on the rack, even though at first he could not speak, where he then had to write down his confessions. He testified again against others whom he had seen at the Sabbath: two men and four women, among whom again three joy-girls. These were immediately arrested; but since the matter, through the multitude of the accused, seemed to be spreading far and wide, most of the investigators were of the opinion to give it no further pursuit and to release the prisoners.

But Master J. du Bois, dean of Our Lady in Arras, opposed this proposal, and the suffragan of the bishop, Brother Johann, joined his view. They went to the Count of Estampes at Peronne, who immediately came over to Arras and commanded the vicars to do their duty; otherwise they would have to answer to him for the consequences. Accordingly, the arrested ones were now again laid on the rack and otherwise questioned, and their confessions were sent by the vicars to Cambrai; where the doctor of theology, Gilles Carlier, a seventy-year-old man, one of the most eminent clerics of the Christendom of that time, as dean of the main church, as well as M. Nicolai as canon, resided; these were consulted for their advice in this matter. Their opinion is said to have been that, if the arrested ones recanted, they should not be subjected to the death penalty the first time; unless they had committed murders or abused the body of our Lord.

But Master Johann and the dean du Bois were of the opinion: All who had taken part in the Waldensian rite must die the death; also all who would be accused by them, if, in case of their not confessing, they were convicted by rack or in other ways, with witnesses. They gave themselves all effort to make this their opinion prevail, and I have heard the dean himself say: the third part and more of Christendom is infected by the Waldensians: he knows much of it, which he cannot say, and if he were permitted to speak it out, one would be horrified by it. All who had been accused thereon were real participants, and those who were not could not be accused. If objections were made against this view, whether by clerics or laymen, those who did so were called: such must be immediately taken into custody as suspected of Waldensianism. \[Page 373\]

The same also said: if it came to pass that some of the guilty were led to the stake, then it was not to be doubted how the devil would tempt them to that, that in the hour of death they would retract everything they had confessed and admitted, so that they would immediately be damned to hell. In all this he was supported by M. Jehan, bishop of Varut, who had been grand penitentiary in Rome in the year 1450; for which reason one also believed that much had become known to him. He also had such an imagination that, if he only looked at people, he judged and declared whether they had been in the Waldensians or not. For this reason he also held: bishops and even cardinals had been in it; and there were so many of them that, if they could draw a king or eminent prince into their interest, they would be powerful enough to rise up against those who did not belong to theirs, and to do them all injury and shame.

Both said also: as soon as anyone should be accused of this crime, no one might take his part; no one, be it father, mother, brother, sister, or whatever relative, under penalty of being himself regarded as an accomplice; moreover, those belonging to the Waldenses, if they learned of their accusation, might not escape the investigation by flight. Accordingly, they arrested yet another new accused person, and had the vicars once more admonished by the Count of Estampes to hasten the process. The vicars therefore assembled all the esteemed clergy of the city, together with the most skilled advocates, laid before them the records with all the depositions from the seven accused, and then proceeded, after the assembly had been heard on the matter, to the execution.

All the condemned were brought to the scaffold, save one who had hanged himself in the dungeon, and the mitre with the figure of the devil was placed upon them; Father le Brousart delivered a sermon to the kneeling ones, and thereupon set forth to them what they had done and perpetrated. They had, he said, anointed a very slender rod and the palm of the hand with the ointment, and had then flown over cities and forests to their meeting place. There they had found richly laden tables, there the demon in the form of a goat, a dog, a monkey, sometimes a man; they had worshipped him, and dedicated to him either their soul or a part of their body; and with burning lights in their hands, had kissed his behind. They had immediately spat upon the crucifix and trodden upon it, and the abbé de la Biche had been the guide of all the newly received.

They had at the same time pointed their behinds at the heavens and the firmament, in mockery of God. And after they had eaten and drunk their fill, carnal mingling had followed, in which the demon had taken part in the form of man and woman: sodomy and bestiality and all the stinking vices that the speaker would not name had been committed therein. Toads, fed with the consecrated host, then burned, mixed with the bone-ash of hanged men, moistened with the blood of children, and compounded with herbs and other things by the abbé, had formed the ointment. The Church had been forbidden to them; they had been permitted to take holy water only with the words: May it not displease our master! \[Page 374\]

The demon preached to them: there is no other life than the present one; for they have no soul. After he had thus reproached them and more, he asked each one in turn whether all this had not indeed come to pass so? All, even the abbé, affirmed it. Thereupon they were severed from the Church as infected members, and handed over to the secular court; and their property was confiscated for the sovereign, their movable goods however for the bishop. The four women were sentenced to death by fire in Arras; but when they heard the sentence, they cried out like desperate ones to Master Gilles Flameng, who was just then present: Ha, false traitor! thou toldest us we should only confess what was dictated to us; we should then be let go, and have no other penance to perform than perhaps a pilgrimage six or twelve hours distant.

Thou knowest, abominable one! that thou hast deceived us. They said moreover: they had never been in the Waldensian sect; what they had confessed had been extorted from them by torture, or lured from them by the promises of that M. Gilles and others, and much more besides. But that availed them nothing; they were led to the stake. They prepared themselves Christianly for death, but maintained to their last breath that they knew not what the Waldenses were; which words gave the people much to think and talk about. The same happened with the demoiselle in Douay, where she was executed.

Even the abbot of Depuysens held the same speeches, and said: he died without guilt; but his last words were: *Jesus autem transiens per medium illorum ibat*. He was 60--70 years old, was a painter, well regarded in many places because he was a singer and a poet. He had also composed ballads in honor of the most holy Virgin, and thus had become valuable to many. But whenever he had sung a holy song, he had always doffed his little cap at the end and said: With the permission of my Lord. Some had attested to this; I do not know what there was to it. Six men, among them Knight Robert le Fosne, governor of Arras, and seven women, among whom again several joy-girls, were immediately arrested in Arras. But the matter now soon spread elsewhere as well.

In Amiens, on the basis of the statements in Arras, several were likewise taken into custody; but the bishop let them go, and said: he would do the same with all of them; for he did not believe that they did or could do what they said. In Tournai, likewise, 3--4 persons had been locked up; Master Jehan Taincture, doctor of theology, wrote on this occasion a good treatise on the Waldensians, which I, however, have not seen. The prisoners were released after some imprisonment. In Arras, meanwhile, proceedings had continued; two of the richest men of the city had had to wander into the bishop's prisons; finally, Payen de Beaufort, a noble knight, one of the old bannerets of Artois, about 72 years old, was also seized. He had been warned earlier, but he had answered: and even if he were a thousand leagues away, he would come to answer for himself; he feared nothing on that account. \[Page 375\]

He had come to Arras; his kin had adjured him, if he knew himself guilty, to withdraw. But he had sworn the most solemn oath, and consigned his soul to damnation if he knew what Waldensianism was, and had taken part in it. Yet he was arrested on that same day, and wished to be led to the Count of Estampes; but the latter refused to hear him, and had him taken to the episcopal prisons. Jacques Guillemeau, his brother-in-law, who was accustomed to heal fevers with incantations, when he visited him there, was likewise detained as an accused. Meanwhile, the trial of three men and double that number of women had been completed; on the scaffold their deeds were likewise recounted to them, which this time consisted in practiced lust with the demon.

All questioned, they confessed the truth of these accusations, except for one of the women, who denied everything. Two, who had steadfastly persisted in their initial confession without wavering, were sentenced to imprisonment; all the others, led to the stake, died---as much as one could see---in Christian composure, but persistently denying all participation. Again, A. Sacquespée, one of the richest citizens and aldermen of Arras, and two others were brought in. Martin Cornille, receiver of the county, and Willaume Le Febvre, a rich man, fled, and were pursued by the count as far as Paris. M. Anton had earlier replied to the urging of his friends to flee in the same way as the knight of Beaufort. The count, for the interrogation of the new prisoners, had further strengthened the commission by adding new members; among them was Philipp H. von Savinses, a strict man in these matters; also the Duke of Burgundy had attached his confessor, the Bishop of Salins, an eighty-year-old man, and Baldwin, knight of Nogent-lès, governor of Péronne. Two others were now taken into custody, and Arras thereby became so notorious in all of France and elsewhere that the merchants lost their credit, and no one would receive travelers from there in the inns.

No person dared to leave the city either, out of fear of being seized as a Waldensian; indeed, the people, as soon as anyone so much as stirred, immediately accused him of Waldensianism. The Vicars therefore made it known: no one should have fear, for no one would be arrested who had not been seen by 8--10 witnesses; although it was later learned that it had indeed happened on the testimony of 2--3. The Vicars now invited the fugitives to present themselves in person and to give account and answer to the charges laid against them.

Thereupon appeared Wilhelm Le Febore, the son of one of them, with a notary from Paris, early in the morning before Jean Pochon, one of the same, in the church, and appealed against them in the name of his father. After the protestation had been made, both mounted up and rode to Paris; where his father surrendered himself into custody in order to answer the charges of the Vicars. But they were overtaken by the men of the Vicars and brought into custody; a fate that many of their friends shared with them, those who had known of their intention. They were first released only after they had renounced their appeal, but the fugitives were excommunicated as Waldensians.

Messengers had been sent to Amiens for more clerics and their counsel on behalf of the Lord of Beaufort and Master Anton; but no one came except Master Martin and the Inquisitor of Tournay; the others excused themselves on account of their age and other circumstances. \[Page 376\]

But it was said: the matter, hitherto unheard of, seemed to them grave and weighty; for out of 100 people, in and outside Arras, not one, it was said, believed that the accused had taken part in the Waldensian rites and actually carried out what they had confessed. The Vicars therefore turned, in accordance with the request of the prisoners, to Philip, Duke of Burgundy, in Brussels, for counsel on what they should do in the matter. He summoned from the University of Louvain the most eminent and renowned teachers, as well as from all over the land.

To them were laid out the processes of both those who had confessed and those who had not; for there were some who did not confess, no matter what was done to them. What they judged, I have not seen; but it was said: they had been very much at odds. Some had opined: the Waldensian rites were not real; others had held them to be a pure illusion, and judged that the people believed they were doing what they did not in fact accomplish. Others said in turn: it was all reality; they entered into it body and soul, and whoever once surrendered himself to the enemy permitted him all power over himself.

The Vicars now took their leave of the Duke, who gave them with him Toison d'Or, his chief herald, in whom he placed all his trust, to be present at the interrogations. For although those from Paris and elsewhere said: he was having the rich people arrested in order to seize their possessions; he nevertheless wanted to know exactly what the truth of the matter was, in order to decree what was necessary.

On 14 August 1460 they returned to Arras; and whatever the counsel of the legal experts may have been, from that time on no one was arrested any longer on the charge of Waldensianism, although countless people were still accused; the prisoners were also treated better, and up to September only 4 processes were decided, and laid before the Duke and his legal experts in Brussels.

In the meantime, papal bulls, procured through the fugitive Martin Cornille, were brought in; by which Pope Pius transferred to the Dean Carlier of Cambrai, Gregory Nicolat, canon and official there, and the two Vicars of Arras, Pierre du Hamel and Master Jehan Thienbaut, the right to pass judgment in such matters.

About that time in Mantes, Noel Ferre from Amiens was burned, who had testified much against those of Arras; and how he had been at the assembly where the burning of the town of Pernes had been resolved.

On 12 October the delegates from Brussels returned, with them Master Adrian Collin, president of the chamber of the Duke of Burgundy in Douai; before whom the prisoners were interrogated once more.

The vicars now assembled many clerics and laymen, laid the records before them, and on the following day pronounced the judgment over Beauffort, Tacquet, Cariens, and Aubry. Before an innumerable crowd that had gathered from a radius of ten hours' journey, the accused appeared with the mitre on the scaffold. The Inquisitor of Cambrai now first charged Beauffort: how he, persuaded by evil women from the fellowship, had himself carried on the anointed staff to the Waldensians; how he had paid homage to the demon there, but instead of his soul had given him only four hairs from his head; how he had then kissed the paw of the ape, and recognized an unnamed woman. He had been twice more in the assembly, and had heard the devil preach: how men had no other souls than the beasts, and when they died, all was dead; and how he had let himself be forbidden by him the church and all churchly things. \[Page 377\]

He then asked the defendant: whether it was not all so? To which this one loudly and clearly said, "Fa!" and begged for mercy. Since Beauffort was without mitre, the speaker thereupon explained to the people: he owed it to the circumstance that he had confessed everything without torture, and never recanted. Tacquet, as he then continued, had taken part more than ten times, had consigned his soul, had promised never to betray one from the sect, and if he did so, driven by torture, to recant it before death. Cariens had moreover killed four children, from whom the salve had been prepared, and the harmful powders. Asked: whether it was not all true? he had replied: everything he had just spoken was nothing; as for what he had confessed, he had been forced to it by torture.

Hugnet, the fourth in the row, had nine witnesses against him; but whatever torture had been inflicted on him, he had always denied it, and even now, when grace was offered him if he confessed, he had replied: he knew nothing, and recognized nothing. He had, as it was said, been put to the torture more than fifteen times, sometimes twice in one day; he had been led to a nearby castle, and told: he should be forthwith beheaded if he did not confess; he had only repeated what had already been said. Once at nighttime he had attempted to flee from the prison, but had been recaptured; and that was counted against him as guilt.

Beauffort was now declared a heretic, apostate, and idolater, and sentenced accordingly to seven years' imprisonment; however, he was to be publicly scourged on the shoulders with rods while clothed. He was further to pay 5,000 gold thalers, of which 76 made a fine mark, into the alms box at Mechelen for the war, and smaller sums to named hospitals and church foundations. Tacquet was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment, to scourging, and to smaller fines. Cariens, who had already earlier been under investigation for the faith, and in whom no sign of repentance had become visible, was handed over to the secular sword. Huguet, who heard his judgment kneeling and weeping, was condemned to twenty years' confinement on water and bread.

Yet the rumor ran: he had, as a former servant of the bishop, been much favored by the vicars. Many said: there were so many Waldensians in the church, at the courts of the powerful, and elsewhere, that it was a wonder. It was also believed that the Antichrist had already been born; he would soon rule, and all Waldensians would form his following. Yet in Paris, Amiens, Tournai many had been arrested, men and women, but released again without harm being done to them. Cariens was burned, but beforehand declared all innocent upon whom he had testified. The vicars now set free all those who had not been brought to confession by torture, twelve in number.

Against all of them witnesses had testified; they were interrogated under torture, some so often and severely that they were crippled; but they had persistently denied. They had to, before being released, swear their innocence on the Gospels; and for this, bring forward 4---5---7 honorable witnesses who likewise swore to their belief in the accused's innocence. They then still had to pay the court costs, and were mostly banished from the county. Only the Inquisitor P. le Broussart and the vicars of the bishop handled these releases; none of the others who were present at the interrogations took part in them, or were called upon to do so. \[Page 378\]

Martin Cornille, who had fled but now sat in the prisons of the Archbishop of Besançon, was now absolved by them from the excommunication that they had issued against him. A song that was found on the streets now harshly assailed the authors of the persecution. But on the following 16th of January 1402, a court messenger of the Parliament of Paris appeared in Arras to inquire into the injustice that had been done to the lord of Beaufort, as he had entered a complaint; as indeed Tacquet and others had also submitted complaints on this account; and also to make inquiry into the appeal that Beaufort had lodged with the Parliament before his interrogation.

Philip, his son, had brought the messenger there; both now went, along with the other three brothers and 30 friends, well armed to the vicars; and since these out of fear did not show themselves, the court messenger demanded the keys to the dungeon; and since the jailer refused them, he took them by force, freed the lord of Beaufort, and summoned the vicars to the 25th of February as the day on which they would have to stand to right before the Parliament in the matter of the appellant, whom he took with him to Paris. On the 1st, the vicars de Hamel and Thiebault betook themselves to Paris; but the matter was postponed, and they returned home. There they received letters from their bishop in Rome, who ordered: to set Huguet Aubry at liberty, which was accordingly done. Martin Cornille also returned, whom the Archbishop of Besançon, after some investigations, had set at liberty.

In June the matter of Beaufort was finally heard before the Parliament, and on this occasion M. J. de Popincourt, parliamentary advocate and legal counsel to the plaintiff, said in open session among other things: how, as often as a prisoner was brought in on account of Waldensianism, he was told: if he did not confess what was said to him, he would be burned; only in the case of an open confession would he be let off with a small pilgrimage. If he then refused this, he was put to the torture until he confessed whatever one wanted. He said further: when the lord of Beaufort was brought in, and had sworn against Dean du Bois that he had not been in the Waldensianism; the dean had knelt before him and most urgently begged him: to confess, otherwise no one could save him from death by fire and the confiscation of his property.

Pity for his children alone moved him to this urgent plea, the fulfillment of which would procure him his freedom again within four days. When he replied that he would then have sworn falsely, the dean countered: he would give him absolution. By this and by more he had then been induced to make his confessions. Later he had also been compelled to pay considerable sums to the Duke, the Count of Estampes, the Bailiff of Amiens and his lieutenant, without having been sentenced to do so. The Parliament pronounced the plaintiff free from the prison sentence imposed upon him, had the three still under arrest in Arras brought before its bar, and set them likewise at liberty.

Because of a fourth \[accused\], Le Febvre, witnesses were examined, and after he had cleared himself before the Archbishop of Reims and the Bishop of Paris, he too was likewise set at liberty. The same happened with the last of the imprisoned, Hotin Longs. Before this had taken place, the Dean of Arras, M. J. du Bois, while on a journey to Corbie, had been seized by a mental illness, and he had been brought to Paris as if out of his senses. He stood in the reputation of a good cleric, was still young, and many lamented him. \[Page 379\]

Others said again: it was God's punishment, because it had happened on his instigation that inquiry was made into the Waldensians, and some burned; he had also taken the most pains to prove the reality of the matter. Those who said this did not believe in the air-flight in this Waldensianism. Although he came to his senses again, there was yet no security in it, and he had to keep himself always in his chamber. Finally he became bedridden, and then his body opened in many wounds, and he had much to suffer. Some said in this connection: he had been poisoned or bewitched by the Waldensians. In February 1461 he died in full possession of his faculties, and certainly made a good end.

Meanwhile, in Burgundy, M. de Jehan, the Bishop of Barut, had been arrested in his birthplace, in order to learn from him what had actually determined him to stir up the matter with the Waldensianism in Arras. But soon he fled from this prison, and was, as he himself said, saved in a wonderful manner. He went to St. James in Galicia, and on the return from there he remained behind in France as confessor to the wife of Charles the Seventh. M. Paille, who had likewise taken part in the affair, withdrew from Arras to Paris; similarly Gilles Flameng to Douai; and it was said: it had been because they were all not gladly seen in Arras.

The process between the appellants, the heirs of the sixth of Beaufort and all those prosecuted on account of Waldensianism, and the defendants, the Duke of Burgundy and his ecclesiastical and secular judicial authorities, before the Parliament, meanwhile went its course. In the eighth year of King Charles VII, in the year 1491, the judgment was finally pronounced, which decided: that the said appellees had acted badly and abusively, had spoken, imprisoned, fined, proceeded, sentenced, and executed; and that the said appellants had rightly appealed. It then cassates all these processes, as well those conducted in the ecclesiastical as in the secular courts; the acts shall be torn up and destroyed, all made confiscations annulled and rendered void, the defendants personally condemned to make compensation, to the costs of the process, and moreover to a fine of 6500 Paris livres; of which 1500 francs shall be taken to establish a daily mass in perpetuity, for the souls' peace of the executed, in the cathedral of Arras; also a stone cross with an inscription shall be erected on the place of execution. The ecclesiastical courts of Arras were forbidden, in future processes, to make use of any extraordinary executions and cruel tortures. The sentence was solemnly proclaimed on the place of execution, a sermon held upon it, and on that day all work in the city had to be suspended.

One sees, this affair is just as instructive through its errors and blunders as the previous one was through justice, prudence, and thoroughness. Moreover, in order to pass a just and not hasty judgment upon it, we must first transport ourselves into the time in which it occurred. It was the middle of the fifteenth century, whose beginning had seen three popes at once on the chair and three emperors on the throne; only the outward expression for the weakening which the unity in church and state, amid the increasing power of multiplicity, had suffered in the wake of the earlier struggles between the two powers. \[Page 380\]

The ecclesiastical unity had fallen in Avignon into the power of French politics; that of the state in the emperor into that of the ever-increasing estates of the realm through constant encroachments; the consequence was a dissolution of the entire common and ecclesiastical order throughout all the European realms. In the church, therefore, the beginning of the newer heresies with Wycliffe and with Huss, and in their wake the Hussite wars. In the hierarchy, the disruption of the inner wholeness and cohesion, the rebellion of the members against one another and against the unity; at the councils of Constance and of Basel, the prelates and the lower priestly orders in strife. After the restoration of the see in Rome, constant struggles of its occupant with the unruly territorial nobility.

In the state, a similar dissolution of the old enclosed feudal state into its elements; the territorial lordship in conflict upward and downward, armed brotherhoods of equals against those higher and lower in rank, the struggle of feudal law with the public peace, of the old manner of warfare with the new, the gradual complete dissolution of the central authority. Between England and France in particular the great, centuries-long struggles over the succession, and in their train the great civil wars in both feudal states, that of the white and the red rose in England, Burgundy and the overlord in France; in both realms at last the unity, with the Tudors and Louis XI, triumphing everywhere; the world traversed by condottieri, Armagnacs, Landsknechts, black mercenaries; brazen outrage, violence, the impotence of the administration of justice prevailing throughout all Christendom.

In the wake of this fermenting dissolution of all elements of civil order and the prevailing savagery, then the greatest immorality; Venus the wandering strumpet dug out as the first among all the gods of heathendom; all cities filled with courtesans, even at the church assembly of Constance an incredible number of them, in the city where it had taken its seat; as Nider relates, on account of the presence of the many princes and their retinues, as well as the numerous craftsmen. In all this, France-ravaged Italy, standing closest to the contagion from the East in any case, going ahead with a good example; and out of the midst of this loathsome corruption, as the scourge of avenging Nemesis, the venereal disease developing itself. Added to this now the fall of the Greek emperorship, which had occurred beyond the straits.

Behind the storming Ottomans then at last Gog and Magog unleashed in Timur and the Mongols; Europe, and the sink of all vices in it, threatened with an inundation from the East, and these floods already breaking on the borders of Bavaria. Such was the state of European society at that time. Was it surprising, in this hopeless state of affairs, if serious minds came to the opinion: the world, now grown hoary with age and decrepit, was hastening toward imminent dissolution; the time was approaching that had been foretold by earlier prophets who had foreseen their agony in visions, and now it was inclining toward the end.

Had Christianity visibly lost its power, while the power of evil had strengthened itself everywhere; then the time of the Antichrist had arrived, to whom dominion was given for two times and half a time, and who should unite and assemble all his own under his sign. He was already born, this adversary; all signs seemed to proclaim his nearness, and the people believed, as we have seen, in his presence. What the coming times should behold in the light of day must now prepare itself in the veil of night; there he must recognize his own, enter them in his registers, and exercise them in all villainy. \[Page 381\]

At the courts he had begun this work of his; from there he had proceeded to the aristocracy; what de Rais had practiced in Brittany, what Lady Fowlis had practiced in Scotland, had not remained unknown; what had occurred in Avignon in the vicinity of the Prince of the Church, what doctrines had gained entry into the College of Cardinals, and what morals had arisen from them, which had later even raised Alexander VI to the throne: all of this had remained no secret; Master Jehan, Bishop of Barut, had seen it all quite close at hand as Grand Penitentiary. It was no wonder, then, that what had earlier circulated concerning immediate pacts of men with the demon, what had haunted here and there in the licentiousness of the age that recoiled before no crime, that it, heaped up and multiplied, should suddenly coalesce in anxious minds into the dread image of the Waldensians or Vauderie.

To the Bishop of Barut was joined the dean, M. Jacques du Bois, at that time a man of twenty-four years, of good repute, of whom that threatening song itself spoke: "Chascun cuidoit que iu keusses prophète, --- Sage comme un Salomon ou Sibille; --- Mais si du sens quy oneq feust en ta leste, --- tu a voulu semer une tempeste, --- tu beueras ton brassin ei brouct; --- Er sy seras des premiers à la feste. --- Folie fait quy folie com met."

Both, studying the Apocalypse in the course of the world at that time, may long since have arrived at the suspicion of a secret connection between a part of it and the demon; the ever-increasing audacity in crime of the century must have confirmed them in it more and more. Now had come the deposition of Robinet de Vaulx, born in Artois, who had testified against the Demoiselle and the Abbé la Vitte, the former a Sister of Joy, the latter---as it appears---a brother more than merely merry; and the word Vauderie, which at the surprising confusion immediately brought to their minds the Manichaeans, the worshippers of the demon, had been acknowledged by the Demoiselle at her arrest. Now they had found the trail, which they needed only to follow in order to find their view confirmed all too fully.

That the hermit had probably made his deposition under torture could, given the reverence that this faithless instrument---which the ecclesiastical courts should never have accepted---enjoyed at that time, by no means lead them astray. It was applied against the two prisoners as well; the gate of the secret had been burst open, and the mystery of iniquity now lay exposed before them. That a woman of the Vauderie, as the reporter says of her, and a frivolous cleric and wandering singer, designated by popular wit with the mocking name "de peu de sens," were little suited to serve, in a matter of such weight involving life and death, as foundational witnesses, had not occurred to them. If doubts arose in them, the torture, applied also against other arrested persons, immediately dispersed them. \[Page 382\]

If suspicion fell upon the instrument, then voluntary confessions appeared, either tricked out by promises, or also---since the matter lay in the intentions of many at that time and surely lacked not all foundation---here and there called forth by remorse, or also brought about by the simplicity of the afflicted in order to save themselves, coming in to pacify; and they found support again in the general belief around them. The surprise on account of the discovery made was, it seemed, so great that immediately the spectral image of the pact with all its terrors stood before them: how it possessed a third of the human race, how bishops and cardinals belonged to it, princes without doubt as well, and how only the Mighty One was still lacking to it, in order at its head to carry out all the plans of the abyss.

Since the poor testimony given by the Veltnerin was joined by that of the witnesses brought forward by her, who had been in Waldensia---a testimony which, even if given voluntarily, could only ground a suspicion of innocence---; the error thereby increased, and it was firmly established: All must die who had been denounced by four such witnesses. Whoever spoke against the system thereby rendered himself suspect of the vice; and it was soon likewise considered proven that no one could be accused unless he had truly made himself guilty of it; for which reason the contradiction to an earlier confession, made in the face of the flames, must also be invalid, because the demon had driven him to it.

Thus there developed a system of terror, before which nothing could stand once it had come within its scope; and this reached its height in the delusion of M. Jehan, who believed he could already recognize guilt or innocence from the physiognomy. No age may deem itself entirely secure from the possibility of falling prey to such errors; and should the present one, in the consciousness of its enlightenment, harbor such presumption; then one might remind it only of that twofold doubled attack of the disease which has befallen it in our days. The first at that time, when the Jesuits were supposed to be regicides from bloodlust, corrupters of morals and custom through their discipline, state-endangering conspirators from habit, accumulators of wealth from insatiable greed.

The order knows how to recount how the fixed idea of the delirious patient played its tricks on it; and since the attack, the specific smell will not yet depart from the nose of the Jesuit-sniffers. For the second and third, the attack has returned in the Revolution, once in the heads of the terrorists, who have armed their political virtue-logic with the guillotine, and subsidiarily assigned fire and water as helpers to it; and on the other side in the opposite siren idea of their battle-victims and the higher estates: that all this had already long ago been prepared for them by the dying Templars, and carried forward through secret societies, come to outbreak only in our days. And when finally, fourthly, the demagogic machinations emerged, how far, one believes, might this mania also have led, which could by no means lack defensible grounds, if torture had been at the disposal of those seized by it? All these examples show how dangerous it is for men, most dangerous for those who are of good will in it, to engage in such treasure-hunting in the depths of the human world of thought, in which God alone knows the way. \[Page 383\]

In the present matter of the Waldenses, it was the preserving instinct which, in the opposition of the vicars against this terroristic doctrine, first made itself felt; but the strict observance then still overcame the mildness. That emerged again in the opposition of the chapter lords of Cambrai and several bishops, but could likewise not make itself felt against the first zeal. Only the council of the prudhommes of Duke Philip of Burgundy in Brussels brought about a turning point. That the investigators had been sincere was proven by the circumstance: that they extended the investigation, without distinction, to the poor as well as to the rich and powerful; but that also brought about a swift conclusion to the matter. The Parliament of Paris took an interest in the affair.

The thirty years which the process lasted are filled, to a great part, with the perfidious, violent, but snake-cunning government of Louis XI and the fall of the House of Burgundy, and the death of Charles of Lorraine; circumstances which, as can scarcely be doubted, exerted their influence on the course of the legal proceedings. But as it has ever been in such matters, the Parliament has judged rightly, and Nemesis has not neglected to collect the debt fallen due to her.

The nineteen years of the reign of Elector Johann VI of Trier were, moreover---excepting only the years 1584 and 1590---years of unfruitfulness, of high prices, and of hunger; countless refugees increased the distress still further, and the plague soon made its appearance to clear things away. The people were in despair, and attributed their misery and the unfruitfulness of the years to evil arts and to the witch-folk. In the officials of the time, among whom the distress now also awakened gold-greed, they found all too willing help to render this their belief pernicious to many. Through the whole diocese, all cities and villages, there now ran---as an eyewitness relates---accusers, inquisitors, judges, minions, and executioner's assistants, who seized all suspects and burned them in great numbers; for scarcely one escaped who had once been accused. \[Page 388\]

Soon the terror spread also into the city of Trier, and soon spared not even the former blood-judges themselves; for Dietrich Flade, rector of the university and city schultheiss, who had led a great multitude of those unfortunates to the stake, was burned in 1586 according to the rules of his own judicial procedure. Him followed in death two mayors and several senators and judges. Canons of several chapters, pastors, rural deans had the same fate. In two villages at about the same time only two women remained; for the fury of the people and the madness of the judges had only ever increased; so that scarcely one remained whom suspicion had not struck. The notaries, the actuaries, and the innkeepers enriched themselves meanwhile; the executioner rode like a courtier on a high horse, clad in gold and silver; his wife vied in finery with the nobles.

The children of the condemned wandered forth, their goods were confiscated. There began to be a shortage of field hands and vinedressers; hence the unfruitfulness. Scarcely, men thought, had a worse plague ever raged in the archbishopric, or a madder foe wreaked havoc, than these trackers, who struck so many for whose innocence there was manifold likelihood. The persecution lasted several years; many of the superiors boasted of the multitude of pyres they had erected. Impoverishment was the consequence: now laws were given and enforced against the abomination, and now it died out, just as the war died out with the exhaustion of the money, so the fury of the witch-judges. In all this the Antichrist was indeed present, although perhaps more in the judges than in the judged: and so men easily came to the belief that he must really and personally have been born. That introduced a new error into the matter. The exorcists, aware of their power in the obsessions brought about by magic, came upon the idea of making use of this power to compel the demon against his will to bear witness to the truth, and thus to spy out the secrets of his realm through himself.

For the first time, to our knowledge, use was made thereof in the matter of the Count of Gaftedy: Magdalena von Palnd, his betrothed, had, against his will and at the age of fourteen, entered the convent of the holy Ursula, and had placed herself under the obedience of Father Romillon, a former Calvinist. As she thereupon fell into a possession, the peace of the convent was suddenly disturbed thereby; for five of the sisters residing there soon found themselves likewise possessed. Among them was one in particular who was most affected by it, Louise Capelle, from the county of Avignon, likewise descended from heretical parents, originating in St. Remi, near that county; a simple, pious girl skilled in household tasks. Magdalena was for a long time unsuccessfully exorcised in secret, but then taken to St. Baume, and there given over to continued exorcism to Father F. Dompt, a Fleming, Doctor of Theology at Louvain and a Dominican. With her had come Louise, to manage the household, who at that time was not yet suspected of possession; which, however, soon betrayed itself through tone and glance; while Magdalena, in her attacks, was repeatedly lifted into the air to tear her from the exorcist who held her. \[Page 389\]

On the eighth of December 1610, the spirits of Louise named themselves: first Verin the superior, and then Gressil and Sonnillon, his subordinates. On the day of the Conception of Mary, Verin began through her mouth to deliver a great eulogy of the blessed Virgin, concluding it thus: that he spoke not out of love for her, but compelled by fear of God, who is able to call forth all things from nothing. Catherine of France, an ecstatic sister, brought Magdalena there during this speech; and now Verin, upon beholding her, began to call out to the stronger demon who dwelt in the one present: "Though thou art my master, yet one greater than thou wills that I now speak in thy presence."

Then this one rose up raging in Magdalena, bellowed like a bull, and threw her shoe at the speaker's head. But Verin continued to deliver to her an eloquent exhortation to repentance and renunciation of the evil one, which closed with the exclamation: "Wonder, unheard-of wonder, that the devil himself saves souls, and serves them as physician and surgeon!" Magdalena, who might have seen collusion and deceit in this scene, remained unmoved; the bystanders prayed the Psalms for her, and this seemed to bend her hardened spirit. She burst into tears, and throwing herself down before the others, declared herself a perverse and wretched creature.

Now the ice was broken, and the work of conversion proceeded on its course. Verin pursued it with great insistent eloquence; and one of the possessed laid to heart for the other everything that could possibly be helpful to snatch her from the power she had hitherto served and lead her back to heaven. When the priest offered the Eucharist to both possessed ones with the words: "Ecce Agnus Dei, ecce qui tollit peccata mundi!", the spirit cried out from Magdalena: "Well for you a lamb, for us a roaring lion!" When the priest commanded him to adore his God, he replied: "What, should I adore this God, this God should I adore? I will not do it, I shall never do it, in defiance of thee, O Christ; in mockery of thee, O Mary, and of thee, O Magdalena, who art mine!" Verin now cried: "Ha, wretch, accursed one, like me! Thou hast no power over Magdalena, who will take the Lord as her bridegroom." "No," screamed the other, "she is my bride, and I will prove it."

So the spirits quarreled with one another; but the one belonging to the neophyte always drew the shorter end, yet avenged itself on her by from time to time calling forth the most violent paroxysms: it threw her to the ground, stirred up the most furious convulsions in her, and made known to the whole world through her mouth her most secret sins, which only her confessors knew, and at night it plagued her with incubi. Meanwhile Verrin continued his instruction in the Christian doctrine; at every section confirming the truth of what was said with a solemn oath. He held before her how she had three times renounced her God, who now might yet have mercy on her soul: O Magdalena! if the stars of the firmament could express thanks, if the leaves of the trees could understand these words, if the stones of St. Baume had a voice, they would all praise God for it; for your sins are many, like the sand on the sea. The hard heart of the sinner slowly softened; she had frequent relapses into impatience and despair; terrifying visions frightened her sorely; the demonically ecstatic girl did not cease, with great eloquence, to press upon her again and again. \[Page 390\]

Now she confessed herself once more before all those present, who had come streaming together from far and wide, as a sinner worthy of hell; and she laid herself down before the church door, begging the passersby to trample her as the most wretched creature with their feet. She now gave the signs on her body, one of which proved visible upon examination; and during the exorcism a number of spirits went out from her, though this did not lift her obsession; just as with Louise, after the departure of the two lower ones, Verrin had remained behind. Her torments returned in between with renewed strength; she was lifted up high by the demon, she lost---especially when she wanted to go to confession---often her sight and hearing for several days; imagination and memory were often bound to her, her whole body sometimes swelled up; her eyes became like burning lamps, distortions ran over her face, and for 15 days Asmodeus defiled her every evening under the exorcism, by calling forth the most obscene movements in her, during which she always believed she saw Louis Gaufredi.

During these proceedings, Verrin had testified several times: that it was Louis Gaufredi, at the church of the Accoules in Marseille, who had seduced Magdalena; that he had made her renounce her baptism and her share in paradise; that he had given her the demon, and possessed her handwriting. He had cried out like one in despair that the living God forced him to this testimony, and he swore: that everything he had said was true, and he had laid a solemn oath upon the altar sacrament thereon. The priests, who had been witnesses to this, had remembered the church precept: to warn the sinning brother three times, and therefore had him admonished three times.

Once it had happened orally through Brother Franciscus; then in writing through a more urgent letter, which they wrote to him as eyewitnesses and earwitnesses of the oath, and in which they promised him that if he came to St. Baume and there converted himself in quiet; then his sins should remain hidden, as if he had laid them down in the confessional. In the third, they had urged the Capuchins in Marseille to send three of their own with the guardian, and to bring the final admonition in a second letter to him. But the Capuchins did not want to involve themselves in this matter without prior consultation with Father Michaelis; all the less so, since the demon from another possessed woman in Aix had said and sworn: that Gaufredi was no sorcerer, and that Magdalena was not afflicted by any malevolent spell.; which Verin immediately declared to be a cunning trick of Lucifer, and the spirit of Magdalena confirmed it.

Verin, for his part, now allowed himself to be commanded by the exorcist to go himself to Marseille for the conversion of the sinner, and Louise felt that he departed from her like a wind; she truly remained free of him in his absence, however with the feeling of pain from the maleficium. Thus he went a second, third, and fourth time, always fruitlessly, and on that account broke forth into curses against him: because he surpassed all sorcerers in wickedness, therefore he was the head of all sabbaths. Cain and Judas were innocent in comparison to him, and the demons themselves were of the opinion that hell was not sufficient to punish him. He had abjured God and all angels and saints; now God made use of that to which he alone had not abjured, namely the demon, in order to convert him. The time of the last and worst heresy had come; all of France was already infected by it. \[Page 391\]

Meanwhile, Gaufredy had nevertheless resolved to go to St. Baume in the company of two Capuchins and Father Michaelis, and he arrived there on the evening of the 21st of December. It was decided to leave the exorcism of Louise to him, and Father Michaelis delegated his authority to him for that purpose. Verin began with a prayer in which he most urgently and heartily besought the Lord for grace for him; which moved the hearts of many, but did not please others, who believed that he should not be allowed to speak, and that he must be interrupted. But he continued and asked his exorcist Gaufredy: Is God almighty or not? The one questioned replied: This one is almighty. Then the other asked: Has the Church the power to command the demons? He answered: She has this power. Then he posed the third question: whether the demons could be compelled to tell the truth, and whether the oaths of the demons, sworn in all form and solemnity, were valid or not? He answered: They are valid, and God can compel the demon to tell the truth. Verin now said: Take good note of what he has admitted; but turning to him: Then exorcise me! It was done, and at the end Verin adjured him anew to renounce magic and to turn to God.

He then swore by the holy sacrament that all was true which he had said earlier, and Magdalena swore the same with a double oath. Then he said further that he must be guarded in St. Baume. The imprudent one had now ensnared himself; but on the following morning, dissension broke out among the clergy, which had already stirred earlier. Father Michaelis and the Capuchins excluded Father Romillon and the Dominican father Franciscus Dompt from their council, and in the course of the day the latter was told: he was proud, disobedient, ambitious, and striving after vain glory, and in all this sought only himself. Others judged again: he was all too credulous; still others judged differently.

Louise too was treated contemptuously, and Verin said that day to Father Romillon: she would follow another calling, and did not deserve this treatment. He also broke the silence imposed upon him against Father Michaelis. The Dominican father threw himself, in the presence of the other Capuchins, at the feet of Father Michaelis, and begged permission to return to his province, however not with complete humility: yet he wished to withdraw himself from the matter, because Father Michaelis would not listen to him, but rather to those who maintained: Verin must not be allowed to speak; Louise was not possessed, and the whole affair seemed more from the devil than from God. In this uncertainty they nevertheless continued; on the following evening Father Michaelis exorcised, Gaufredy renounced magic, and Verin said Amen. Later he cried: Adam, where art thou? Out of the depths call to God thy Lord, and he will hear thee!

He compared him, in the following days, when the struggle within him seemed to persist, to a man mortally ill who had lost his memory. He also said: the Antichrist had already been born, of a Jewess with an incubus; the magicians were his forerunners, and God wished to prepare His Church for the impending dangers. Meanwhile, Father Michaelis conducted tests with the two women, in order to convince himself and the councilors of the Parliament of Aix, who had taken cognizance of the matter, whether they were truly possessed. Berrin said on that occasion, when silence was imposed upon him: O Michaelis, God looses me, but you bind me. \[Page 392\]

Gaufridy meanwhile renounced his written pacts, but the spirits cried out: it was not earnest with him, and he was only playing the Pharisee; holy on the outside, full of filth within. He sharply rebuked the exorcists for demanding signs from him; he must indeed, as they said, be the Bridegroom of the Church, but she too must obey her Bridegroom, who had resolved to give her light through him; they, however, imposed silence upon him. When he caught sight of Gaufridy, he began to bark, like a dog in the presence of a wolf nearby, and announced to him: if within eight days his sincere conversion did not take place, he would be burned to ashes. They say Louise is bound in her imagination; but the earth would have to swallow her, and you would have to deliver her to the flames, if she were not possessed, and if she had not sworn those many oaths of her own accord.

Meanwhile, he always refused to speak in a foreign tongue; God would not have it, he would give no signs; for if he sent an archangel in his invisible form, they would say: it is the devil; but if in his visible form, it would be said: it is a man. When questioned, she denied everything; but when the spirit of one of them revealed that she bore the marks of the demon, she confessed and herself indicated the places of these marks. At first she had to be compelled to these confessions by exorcism, but soon she did so voluntarily. Besides the three, all the others in the convent likewise suffered various afflictions, and she had been the primary originator of all these evils; despite the extraordinary reputation for holiness in which she stood, suspicion had soon fallen upon her; she had been locked up, but at that time had confessed nothing. Now she revealed that she had brought it about through a double malefice, in order thereby to destroy the young foundation. \[Page 393\]

She confessed still countless other crimes of this sort; also how the exorcists had long since been well known to her, inasmuch as she had seen them in St. Baume, whither her demon Astaroth had carried her. We have already mentioned earlier what statements this resolute woman, who recoiled from no atrocity, had made; and how she herself had not shrunk from maltreating the Heavenly ones. While she continued unceasingly to make new confessions concerning the demons who obsessed her, she visited, according to her account, the Sabbath without interruption; and she always brought new signs with her, which the investigation conducted each time confirmed. Among other things, she also began to speak of the Antichrist, in which the three other demons assisted her. He was not begotten through man's agency, but through the demon; the earth had never produced a creature equal to him in wickedness. He travels through the air and performs signs and wonders. Maria de Sains knows him and has seen him in the synagogue, where he received baptism.

Now he is in his boyhood years; born in Babylon, raised in Capernaum in the land of Judea, he will one day rule the whole world from Jerusalem. Beelzebub has declared him to be his son, and they call him Creator of Heaven and Earth, also Christ, King and Messiah. On feast days he is brought to the Sabbath; there, said Marie, he kissed and embraced me and said: I was exceedingly beautiful, had beautiful smooth hair, and amiable and shining eyes; of all this he spoke like a grown man. When the time has run its course, this one will rise up against the Church; more will believe in him than have believed in Christ; the Jews will see in him their Messiah; he will transplant all the torments of Hell to earth, and apply them against the Christians; all heresies long since extinguished will revive, and Rome will fall. The Simona who is here in question, like Sains, born in the city of Lille, had entered with her into the local Brigitten Convent; her accomplice in all her schemes and intrigues, she had also accused herself of the same things simultaneously with her. Since she was still a novice, they had therefore taken away her habit for that reason; but during the year in which she was kept locked up in the bishop's prison, she had confessed nothing. She was then released at the urging of her superiors and relatives, and had gone to Valenciennes; where she hired herself out as a maid, and thereby kept her whereabouts completely hidden from everyone. A man from Lille had fallen in love with her there, and offered her his hand; she consented, but since she needed the consent of her superiors for it, he went to obtain it; with the prohibition, however, on her part, to reveal her whereabouts to anyone.

But he did not keep his secret to himself, it became known through the women; Father Domptius, who was very interested in questioning her likewise about these matters, brought about her arrest. On July 29, 1613, he came, accompanied by two commissioners assigned to him and Maria de Sains, to Valenciennes; where they visited the arrested woman, who, however, denied everything. Maria, meanwhile, insisted on her accusation; if this one were not a sorceress, there would be none in the world. She was confronted with her; but since she always persisted in her denial, they decided to call upon the possessed ones to speak. Almost simultaneously with this story in Normandy, another highly remarkable event occurred in Loudun, a small town that separates the provinces of Touraine, Poitou, and Anjou from one another without ever having belonged to any of them. There, Urbain Grandier was the first pastor of the town at St. Peter's, and moreover capitular at the foundation of the Holy Cross. He was one of those characters who, wherever they may be found, appear destined by nature to rule; for he combined great talent with an equal energy of will, and a rich vein of life dwelt in him within a tall stature. He was an outstanding preacher, knew how to express himself with grace and ease in social intercourse; a firm and penetrating spirit made itself known in all his utterances; thus he soon became a phenomenon in the little town. But he lacked the religious and ethical foundation upon which these gifts could develop. \[Page 403\]

A great inclination toward lust had been given to him as an additional trait, and he soon allowed himself to be mastered by it. Sixty unimpeachable witnesses testified in his later trial to all the adulteries, incests, sacrileges, and other godless acts that he committed in his church, in the vicinity of the Sacrament, without distinction of time of day, at every hour and in every moment. In order to gloss over this licentiousness before his conscience, he wrote a treatise against celibacy, which was found among his papers along with various obscene poems under investigation. The old men whose daughters, and the men whose wives he dishonored, became furious against him; and he now turned the entire cutting sharpness of his character against them, instead of doing anything conciliatory.

The complaint of the injured parties was lodged with his bishop in Poitiers; he was arrested in connection with it, and by the judgment of the officialate on the third of January 1630 was interdicted for five years in the diocese, and forever in Loudun. He appealed to the archbishop of Bordeaux, who acquitted him; however, with the advice to exchange his benefices. But he instead made his entry into Loudun with a laurel branch in his hands; he pressed his hard-won right to the utmost point, held the cold point of mockery toward his enemies everywhere, and involved them one after another in quarrels and lawsuits of every kind. Thus he became the tyrant of the place, an object of fear and terror to the weak and of irreconcilable hatred to the strong.

While the Catholics were thus averse to him in this way, and many did not attend his church, the Huguenots had taken his side. Loudun had been their stronghold in the earlier wars, and many of the Calvinists who lived there at the time judged not without reason that Grandier belonged in his innermost conviction to their sect, and that only the inevitable threatening loss of his benefices had held him back from openly joining them.

They therefore took his side without hesitation; it is true that in times when their confession lay wholly prostrate and Richelieu ruled with absolute power, these were dangerous allies. Thus stood things around him in the ordinary course of the world; but they had yet another side. Every person has a spiritual sphere of influence about himself, which, however, only extends in the inner circles, but in ordinary life, incorporated into the outer sphere of existence and enveloped by it, makes itself felt only through it and within it.

But if that interpenetration is partially suspended; if, without their being wholly separated from one another, a division nonetheless arises, and an overstepping of the inner over the outer occurs, whether in giving or receiving; then the intensive effects also disentangle themselves from the extensive ones, and spiritual rapports develop from the earlier physical sympathies and antipathies. Grandier, relying on his personal superiority, secured against the aversion of his fellow believers by the affections of their opponents, outwardly, as it seemed, unassailable, should yet not escape the fate of all pride, and Nemesis lay in wait for him on these night-shrouded paths. A convent of the then still new order of Ursulines had been established in Loudun since 1626. \[Page 404\]

Fourteen girls, all from good families, noble and non-noble, altogether of blameless life, had come together in one house; and, under the direction of a director, eked out, in their poverty, the continuance of their community through a pension school which they had founded. Things had proceeded in the usual tracks in this nascent convent, when the director died; Grandier, proposed as his successor, was rejected by the superior, and in his place Mignon, one of his adversaries, was chosen by the convent. The convent had been somewhat earlier disturbed by nocturnal apparitions, as the opponents said, or by the caprice of some nuns. Now disquieting signs began to appear, which were at first taken for symptoms of female illness and quietly sought to be dispelled.

The signs multiplied and became ever more unequivocal; the physicians had to be dismissed, and exorcists called in for aid. Dark rumors first flew through the town; soon the whole truth became known: fourteen nuns showed themselves possessed in the convent; the people took their children back, and while want and distress now entered among the nuns, they were regarded by some as those who had forsaken God, by others as fools and hysterical visionaries. The seal with which the nocturnal world is closed had been broken open for them; the first thing they perceived there was the magnet toward which the little town had long been accustomed to turn in hatred and love.

Their negatively demonic state sought about for an object on which it could complete itself; and found it in Grandier, brought into close rapport with them by his scoundrelly nature, pride, and hypocrisy. The relations of the sexes, which by day had friendly or hostile brought the female town into connection with him, had also here, conducting through the night, exerted their influence. For months the nuns saw him every night at their bedside, ceaselessly inciting them to evil; their statements gained credence when it was seen how, despite their bitter poverty, they remained blameless and fulfilled all the duties of their station with zeal and exactitude. In the exorcism the spirits named him unanimously as the one who had bound them in obsession. Into the mass of passions that had accumulated in the town, the igniting spark had now been cast. From the hearts the conflagration spread swiftly to the heads; everyone took sides for or against; Grandier and his closer adherents naturally did not remain idle, and great ferment began to stir in the little town.

When the royal councilor Laubardemont arrived in Loudun to carry out the decree that ordered the demolition of all fortresses in the interior at the castle there, he found the entire city in the most violent agitation, which his mission only further increased. 619\
Upon his return, he made his report on this to King Louis XIII, and the latter instructed him, in late November 1633, to select thirteen of the most honest and skilled judges from the jurisdictions in the surrounding area, and with them to decide the matter without appeal. It happened as the king had commanded, and Grandier was provisionally arrested. In such exceptional courts, politics is to sit in judgment alongside the law. But that is an evil alliance, where one of the allies indeed represents the accused, while the other, speaking in the name of the whole, places the reason of state into the scales. \[Page 405\]

In times when this politics has not yet fully emancipated itself from conscience and morality, it will not demand of the judges that they declare the innocent guilty against their conviction; but it will nonetheless always, in doubtful cases where the verdict wavers, not hesitate to intervene subsidiarly and tip the scales. Grandier's case had become a party matter, and this had precisely provided the occasion to allow that alliance to enter the court as a counterforce. The more his party reacted, the more it had to increase the power of the political element. The conscience of the judges found its reassurance in the fact that, as soon became evident, Grandier's case had from the outset been ethically utterly lost; and the trial, conducted in the ordinary civil forms, had to lead to his ruin.

Thus the investigation into sorcery soon took a ominous turn for him, and it could be foreseen that it must lead to an evil outcome. However much the defeated party reviled the verdict, it did not dare to cast suspicion on the integrity of the thirteen judges; it reproached them only with all too great credulity: a reproach that, in a certain sense, but different from how it was meant here, was not entirely unfounded.

The commissioner Laubardemont began by taking the depositions of the witnesses; among them also those who had previously been frightened away from their testimony. The possessed were separated in houses, and then interrogated in their calm periods; the speeches that they delivered during their paroxysms, which the exorcism, performed each time by the Bishop of Poitiers, brought about, were to count only as indications for the further investigation. Their entire lives were subjected to the sharpest scrutiny; never did the statements of 20 individuals conflict on a point.

Three and a half months of continued exorcism had demonstrated with evidence that they were truly in a state of obsession, for they had shown all the signs that the Church requires to determine the judgment on it. With regard to the understanding of languages, M. de Launoy de Razilly, who had long resided in America, gave testimony that he had spoken with the possessed in the language of some native tribes of that country; that they had answered him quite appropriately, and had also revealed to him several things that had occurred there. They astonished these by the quick answers they gave to the most difficult theological questions on grace, the vision of God, the angels, and the Incarnation, and indeed in the expressions of the School. They looked into the distance as they looked into the inner depths of souls: and while the superior Johanna, according to his testimony, revealed to Father Surin the secrets also of those whose guidance he had undertaken at his earlier residence in Marennes in Saintonge; the parliamentary councillor of Brittany, Kerioles, likewise made an experience of this gift that was decisive for his life. This man was sunk in all vices, without any religion or any faith; a raging atheist and of such rabid defiance that, when a thunderstorm rose in the sky, he directed the muzzle of his pistols against it, and once when the lightning struck his room, he, surrounded by fire and flames, while all his people cried for mercy, alone poured himself out in mockery and scorn. \[Page 407\]

All his thinking was forever directed only toward doing evil, and even more evil than all others; and he had once resolved to become a Mohammedan among the Turks, only so that he might have the opportunity to inflict all conceivable harm on the Christians. As all his thinking and striving were directed only toward atrocities and vices, so he also came to Loudun for such a goal and end; in short, one might well, in Surin's words, scarcely have seen a more despairing and vice-ridden man than this one. Immediately upon his arrival, he poured out his mockery over the nuns, and declared them all and sundry to be foolish. But God knows how to lead things to His end, and saved this bondsman of Satan through him himself.

Right at the first exorcism, where he was present, the possessed revealed to him his most secret affairs, which no one could know except himself; so that he was most profoundly shaken. He returned a second time, and was now so moved and turned within himself that he performed terrible penance, and from then on led a holy life.
